IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Women are more vulnerable than men to many of the consequences of alcohol use including neurodegeneration and impaired neurocognitive function which lead to poorer treatment outcomes. The proposed differences multimodal training and research will identify sex in the molecular and neural mechanisms of neurodegeneration in alcohol use disorder using imaging — positron emission tomography and diffusion tensor magnetic resonance imaging. provide the candidate with the expertise necessary to This project will identify sex differences in alcohol-induced markers of neurodegeneration (i.e., microglia and white matter) that lead to neurocognitive impairments to identify promising translational treatment targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance Statement: Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the second most common childhood leukemia and has a dismal prognosis. For over 40 years AML chemotherapy has changed little with the continued reliance on ara-C, daunorubicin and etoposide as frontline agents. The proposed research seeks to prepare a sound scientific rationale to incorporate prognostic gene expression scores into the risk stratification of AML patients and revealing additional layers of the molecular basis of AML prognosis to guide the development of more effective treatments for AML.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative  Discovering mechanisms to enhance adult brain function is of utmost importance when devising therapeutics to recover and refine normal brain function later in life. We found that temporarily depriving vision leads to recovery of plasticity in the adult auditory cortex, which can benefit auditory function. In this proposal, we aim to determine the mechanisms that allow recovery of adult brain plasticity, and whether temporary visual deprivation improves auditory performance in adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The major proteins found in the human eye lens are called crystallins and they become extensively modified during aging and cataract formation. These modifications include oxidation and a spontaneous chemical change, called deamidation. Our long-term goal is to determine how these modifications cause structural changes in the crystallins that lead to the large light scattering aggregates found in cataracts in order to intervene in the aggregation process and slow cataract formation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Narrative: Regulation of stem cell self-renewal is critical for tissue homeostasis and disease development and the goal of this project is to understand the collaborative role of HOTTIP/β-catenin-HOXA9/PRMT1 axis in hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) regulation and early pathogenesis of AML. Our proposal will characterize the function of individual components and their crosstalk along the axis in regulating hematopoietic self-renewal. The studies will provide novel mechanistic insights and potential therapeutic targets for modulating hematopoietic self- renewal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE During development, individual neurons extend highly branched neurites that innervate the surrounding territory with minimal overlap to form appropriate synaptic connections. Failure to establish proper neural networks has been linked to neurodevelopmental and neuropsychiatric disorders, including Autism Spectrum Disorder, Schizophrenia and Major Depressive Disorder. Our proposal will investigate the molecular mechanisms by which the protocadherin gene cluster contributes to neural circuit formation during development and may provide new insights into disease mechanisms, motivating the development of new therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Imaging mass spectrometry is a powerful technology that enables the visualization of biochemical processes directly in tissue specimens. Especially when this technology is used to study lipids and metabolites, many compounds with similar chemical structures are present that can obscure these analyses. Our lab proposes to develop novel instrumentation and gas-phase reactions to better differentiate and identify these compounds so as to more accurately determine their unique cellular functions in a wide variety of biomedical research settings, such as in studies of diabetes, infectious disease, cancer, and drug pharmacology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Age-related macular degeneration (AMD), the most common cause of blindness among the elderly, is characterized by retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) cells that are morphologically heterogeneous and with various degrees of dysfunction and degeneration. RPE cells, that are critical for photoreceptor functioning and survival, have very high energy demands and are exposed to very high stress and in fact, RPE mitochondrial dysfunction and impaired stress response have been implicated in AMD. This proposal will study how Pink1 mediated mitophagic impairment recruits Nrf2 stress response pathway genes to induce EMT and affect RPE structure and function in AMD, which can lead to novel therapies for dry AMD based on Pink1 and Nrf2 pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Currently, there is no effective treatment that can prevent or reverse the cognitive function impairment in Alzheimer's disease. This project will examine the biology of MG53, a tissue repair gene, in neuroprotection. Our findings with the dual function of MG53 in tissue repair and anti-inflammation shall provide novel means to mitigate neurodegeneration associated with the progression of Alzheimer's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Motile cilia are microtubule-based organelles that produce a driving force for cellular locomotion and extracellular fluid flow. In humans, paralyzed or dyskinetic cilia can lead to infertility, chronic respiratory disease, and laterality abnormalities. This project aims to reveal the detailed structures of the multiple dynein motors that power ciliary motility, helping to identify key aspects of their assembly and function that could be targeted for novel therapies of cilia dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Every 2-4 weeks, the outer layer of our skin, the epidermis, completely turns over and replaces itself, a finely tuned differentiation process that requires the precise regulation of gene expression by chromatin modifying enzymes. Any disruption of this well orchestrated process can drive the development of epidermal skin cancers, which collectively outnumber all other human cancers combined. This project will define the mechanisms through which dysfunction of chromatin modifiers can promote the initiation of cancer in the epidermis, so that we may ultimately harness the great potential of epigenetics-based therapies for skin disease in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative In order to improve quality of life and reduce societal costs of mental illness, there is a need to identify modifiable risk factors that contribute to increased vulnerability in order to inform new prevention and treatment programs. The current project is the first longitudinal study to examine how prenatal and childhood air pollution exposure impacts 1) neuroimaging biomarkers of corticolimbic circuitry involved in emotional processing and 2) subsequent risk of internalizing and externalizing psychopathology during the early adolescent period. By addressing these questions in a large, sociodemographic and geographic diverse sample of ~11,800 children across the U.S., findings from this study hold great promise for the potential to impact environmental health policy as well as identify early neuroimaging biomarkers of risk as potential targets for early intervention.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Children who are HIV-exposed yet uninfected experience increased risk of infectious morbidity, mortality, poorer growth, neurobehavioral delays and deficits, and altered cardiometabolic health compared with children born to women without HIV. To understand the short- and long-term health of this rapidly expanding and large population, we will establish a cohort of 1,575 child-caregiver pairs in Botswana, a high burden HIV setting. We will enroll and follow 1,100 children who are HIV-exposed uninfected and 475 children HIV-unexposed uninfected ranging in age from birth to 17 years.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This is a new U01 application to establish a Clinical Center (CC) for a prospective multiethnic HFpEF cohort from California central valley for multiscale novel deep phenotyping analyses. Our proposed study promises to contribute both technically and conceptually to the overall understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying the heterogenous disease in HFpEF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Homologous recombination maintains genomic stability by providing high-fidelity repair of DNA double-stranded breaks and other types of complex DNA damage such as interstrand crosslinks. This DNA repair pathway has dual significance for cancer as genetic defects in recombination increase cancer predisposition and as the types of DNA damages it targets are induced by common DNA damage-inducing modalities in cancer treatment. The proposed work will contribute to an improved mechanistic understanding of recombinational DNA repair, which will also benefit novel personalized treatment approaches targeting recombination-deficient tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The proposed program will train predoctoral students at the University of California, Irvine in a broad array of disciplines related to virus-host interactions. The program provides a research- based setting that includes formal coursework, seminar programs, research symposia, training in the handling of DNA and RNA viruses, training in the responsible conduct of research, and original laboratory research. This comprehensive training is intended to equip Ph.D. students with the necessary intellectual and research tools required for their future health-related careers in biotechnology, academia (including teaching), the pharmaceutical industry, public health, and related disciplines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE We will develop novel informatic methods to support continuous genomic reanalysis for patients with non- diagnostic exome/genome sequencing. These methods will enable the interoperability of computable phenotypes with existing phenotype-genotype association knowledge, automate genomic reinterpretation with up-to-date and diversity-aware phenotype and genotype (allele frequency) knowledge, and improve the accuracy, efficiency, and effectiveness of genomic diagnostics across diverse populations to reduce genomic health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Clostridioides difficile infection (CDI) is the most common hospital acquired infection in the US and has been designated by CDC as one of the five antimicrobial resistance most “Urgent Threats” to public health. Failure of antibiotics to cure CDI we hypothesize is due to an immune response of patients to CDI that causes more harm than good. We propose to test if treatment can be improved by blocking the damaging immune response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: There are few effective therapeutic options for lung cancers that lack activating mutations in actionable receptor tyrosine kinases, and there is an urgent need to develop a better understanding of the biological basis of lung cancer growth and metastasis. On the basis of the preliminary results presented here, we postulate that lung cancer growth and metastasis is driven by a novel secretory pathway activated by TP53 mutations and mediated by a therapeutically actionable Golgi protein, Golgi reassembly and adhesion protein 55 kD (GRASP55). If proven true, these findings would advance our understanding of the mechanisms of lung cancer progression and may lead to new treatment strategies designed to target secretion in cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Despite consensus on a clear set of effective kidney-protective strategies to reduce the risk of acute kidney injury (AKI), these treatments are often underutilized during surgery because perioperative risk of AKI is underestimated; as a result, AKI affects 18-47% of surgical patients and is associated with adverse outcomes including chronic kidney disease, major adverse cardiovascular events (MACE), increased healthcare costs, and death. This problem provides an excellent opportunity for machine learning (ML) because ML has already been shown to predict AKI better than clinicians, but these models have not yet been implemented in the perioperative period because of multiple technical and logistical barriers that we have developed technology to overcome. We propose implementing and updating innovative models that predict and alert clinicians of impending perioperative AKI during surgery when preventative treatments can be provided and, in the process, use these models to better understand the landscape of risk and design new treatments for AKI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Non-human primate (NHP) models are ideal animal models for preclinical, translational stroke research; however, limitations on imaging modalities that can map neural activates in deep brains of awake monkeys are hindering the current research. We propose to develop a wearable, whole brain functional mapping system based on the emerging photoacoustic imaging for ischemic stroke research with NHP models. The success of this study will allow us to answer important scientific questions about stroke with NHP models, and pave the way for new stroke therapy development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The high prevalence of weight regain following intentional weight loss is the most significant and unresolved challenge in obesity medicine. This project will utilize qualitative data to design and then pilot, an adaptive intervention to prevent weight regain following weight loss in adults with obesity. This line of research will ultimately improve the health and clinical care of adults with obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Older adults with HIV (OAH) experience more co-morbidities than their HIV negative peers despite viral suppression with antiretroviral medications, and inflammatory changes with aging in the setting of HIV remain incompletely understood. New biomarkers are needed to identify OAH at higher risk of geriatric syndromes, and recent advances in understanding of cellular death processes, including necrosis-mediated cell death, have allowed for measurement of cell-free mitochondrial DNA (cfmtDNA) as a novel biomarker. The goals of this proposal are to investigate cfmtDNA in plasma and urine as a biomarker of geriatric syndromes in a longitudinal study of OAH, evaluate the immunostimulatory potential of cfmtDNA, and foster the career development of a physician-scientist who has, and will continue to, dedicate her career to HIV research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patterns of DNA methylation changes between species can be used to understand which regions of the genome are functionally important and relevant for diseases, yet are currently unknown. In this project, we will construct evolutionary histories of DNA methylation from three major cell types from two distinctive regions of human and non-human primate brains. This will help us determine how DNA methylation has changed during human brain evolution and how it underlies neuropsychiatric diseases. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Infectious disease epidemiology has increasingly needed to understand the dynamics of infection in small, highly structured populations, such as hospitals, schools, nursing homes and workplaces. The tools and evidence based for the dynamics of these populations are, however, underdeveloped when compared to those for large, population-scale epidemics. The proposed research program will extend our understanding of the stochastic dynamics of these populations and support the development of a broader range of tools or methods for studying pathogen transmission in these populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In definitive radiation therapy for head and neck cancer patients, there is often significant uncertainty about the malignant potential of cervical lymph nodes during treatment target identification. We will develop an advanced machine learning method through analyzing PET and CT images and patient clinical characteristics to accurately predict lymph node metastasis status. This tool will be deployed in a prospective randomized trial to show how strictly irradiating these identified lymph nodes, rather than the entire at-risk cervical neck, is oncologically sound and associated with improved quality-of-life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Live-attenuated vaccines against dengue have struggled to achieve high efficacy and safety in children without previous dengue infection and in children under 9 years old. We do not yet know the immunologic determinants of protection in natural dengue infections, nor do we understand how age impacts the development of neutralizing antibodies in previously uninfected children. The findings of this study on infection risk and antibody targets in younger and older children, controlling for prior dengue infection, will inform future vaccine development and improve vaccine safety analyses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are currently few data pertaining to fracture risk and the association of bone density and fracture risk in US Asians. This study will examine fracture incidence in Asian women and will assess the accuracy of bone density and its combination with clinical factors in fracture risk calculating tools for predicting future fracture events. Findings from this study will inform ethnic-specific osteoporosis care for US Asians and minimize both under- and overtreatment in the clinical management of Asians who require osteoporosis counseling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human AML shows evidence of a hierarchical cellular organization, with a minor fraction of self-renewing leukemia stem cells (LSCs) at the apex of this hierarchy that must be eliminated to eradicate the disease and achieve long-term remissions. Although a number of cell surface markers have been characterized on AML LSC- enriched fractions, none are specific for LSCs or facilitate their rigorous purification making it difficult to further characterize LSC biology and to develop methods for more specific therapeutic targeting. This proposal seeks to rigorously characterize LSC properties and identify biological programs that contribute to AML pathogenesis, response to therapy, and clinical outcomes.

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will increase our understanding of how pathogenic bacteria protect themselves from invasion by mobile genetic elements, such as viruses and plasmids. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIH's goals of improving the control of disease, enhancing human health and advancing our understanding of biological systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal explores a novel mechanism of presynaptic RNA binding proteins controlling target mRNAs to regulate learning and memory. Furthermore, because RNA binding protein dysfunction is known to play an important role in many neurological disorders such as Fragile X Syndrome, Autism, and Alzheimer’s, my studies may also give new insight into the role that RNA binding proteins play in neurological disease. Illuminating the importance of 1) presynaptic transcripts in learning and memory and 2) RNA binding proteins as memory regulators may reveal pathways suitable for pharmacological manipulation to treat diseases that cause cognitive dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Mitochondria are the energy sources of cells and are abnormal in patients with diabetic retinopathy (DR). Recent studies demonstrate that mitochondrial transfer from stem cells can rescue damaged cells from bioenergetic abnormalities and cell death. In this proposal, we will “normalize” bioenergetics by mitochondrial transfer and prevent retinal vascular pathology associated with DR, this may provide a novel breakthrough approach to treatment of DR.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Black young adults use cannabis more frequently and are more likely to have a cannabis use disorder than White young adults, yet very few studies have examined why these differences exist. The proposed project tests a cascading model that examines stress and discrimination exposure, reactivity to stressors, and cannabis cognitions, inside the laboratory and in the natural environment, as contributors to health inequities in cannabis use and problems. Results of the project will inform culturally-responsive intervention efforts by identifying modifiable and proximal treatment targets for Black young adults and will ultimately lead to a reduction in the pronounced and growing health inequities in cannabis use and cannabis use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Autism Spectrum Disorder affects 1 and 44 children, and racial/ethnic disparities profoundly impact access to care. Though most research has focused on child and family factors, other contextual factors such as neighborhood, state health policy, and educational system determinants are likely drivers of structural disparities in care. In this research we propose to identify cross-sector, modifiable determinants of autism diagnostic and treatment disparities by combining Medicaid data with information on neighborhoods, state policy, and state educational data, and we will use a stakeholder-engaged consensus panel to turn data into actionable interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE/ PROJECT NARRATIVE Substance use and HIV have linked throughout history, from the first described cases of HIV/AIDS in the 1980s among men who have sex with men (MSM) also using psychostimulants through the present day, which is why it is so important to study the intersection of substance use and HIV. However, self‐reported substance use and the number of substances used is not always accurate and measures to quantitate substance use in hair samples are more objective and can be correlated with clinical outcomes, including HIV risk, HIV outcomes, and inflammation. Our laboratory at UCSF (the Hair Analytical Laboratory) has been analyzing HIV medications in hair samples for over two decades and proposes in this application to direct that expertise into developing hair assays for substances in order to 1) become a reference laboratory to provide hair assays of substances to groups studying substance use and HIV; 2) analyze hair substance use levels in a cohort study of MSM who use substances in relationship to self‐reported use, urine toxicology screens, and clinical outcomes for those at risk of or living with HIV; 3) assess the contribution of substance use as measured in hair with chronic inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the acidic environment of the vagina – created by members of the vaginal microbiota – bacterial pathogens such as uropathogenic Escherichia coli (UPEC) can overcome acidification and colonize the vaginal space. Colonization of the vagina by UPEC can lead to urinary tract infection, or infection of the cervix and uterine horns, which can have adverse sequelae during pregnancy. This proposal will elucidate how UPEC uses its several acid resistance systems to establish a niche in the vagina and will explore the potential of overriding these acid resistance mechanisms as a prophylaxis against genitourinary tract infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: RELEVANCE Mitochondrial dysfunction is a root cause of developmental and metabolic disorders, cancer, and aging-related neurodegenerative diseases. While molecular chaperones provide the first line of defense against protein misfolding and aggregation, their function (or lack thereof) in disease states remains poorly understood. The broad and long-term research objective is to provide a molecular understanding of how mitochondrial protein quality control machines protect the organelle from damage and to exploit this information for the development of new therapeutic strategies against unmet human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The oral medication metformin is best known for its ability to treat diabetes, but more recently it has been found to have many additional health benefits such as inhibiting cancer growth and extending lifespan. Despite these well described effects, the ways that metformin promotes healthy aging and extends lifespan remain unknown. This project will determine the mechanisms by which metformin produces benefits on longevity with a focus on the drug’s effects on the cell’s powerhouse, the mitochondria, with the ultimate goal of exploiting metformin action to promote healthy aging in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project narrative  A mosquito’s sense of taste contributes to its decision to bite human hosts. The focus of the proposed work is to discover molecules that the fruit fly uses for taste, and build on these discoveries to uncover mechanisms underlying taste in the mosquito, Aedes aegypti, which spreads dengue, zika, yellow fever and other diseases that infect millions of people each year. The long-term goal it to use these insights to develop new strategies to control the spread of insect-borne disease.

PHR: Project Narrative The post-COVID landscape holds several advances in HIV care and treatment, chief among them the advent of telehealth and the FDA-approval of long-acting injectable antiretroviral therapy. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative ! The hierarchical processing of acoustic information downstream from primary auditory cortex where it is integrated with other sensory inputs to support sound-driven decisions is largely unknown. The current project will address this issue by identifying an intercortical circuit from auditory to parietal cortex that displays the transformation of acoustic representations that ultimately supports auditory psychometric decisions and multisensory integration. The findings from this proposal will have novel and long-term clinical relevance regarding hearing-loss induced cognitive deficits that reflect impaired processing within higher cortical areas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite increasing incidence of Clostridioides difficile infection (CDI) in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) patients, the mechanism by which IBD confers susceptibility is unknown. The aim of this proposal is to define the role of the gut microbiota and the microbially derived secondary bile acids in conferring susceptibility and contributing to the severity of C. difficile infection during intestinal inflammation caused by IBD. The work in this proposal will directly impact public health through the development of novel non-antibiotic therapeutic and preventative interventions aimed at substantially reducing morbidity, mortality, and health care costs for IBD patients with CDI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Those who are blind or visually impaired suffer from an inability to transform visual information into behaviorally relevant representations to guide selection of appropriate actions. This project seeks to derive the algorithms for sensorimotor transformations that can guide technologies to restore visual-motor behaviors through neuroprosthetics. This project also seeks to uncover the underlying mechanisms for these algorithms that provide targets for restoring sensorimotor transformations in neurodegenerative diseases or neurodevelopmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are racial disparities in birth mode among women with a prior cesarean, with Black women more likely to have unplanned repeat cesareans compared to White women, potentially contributing to higher rates of maternal morbidity for Black women. The proposed study will examine how hospital characteristics and processes of care shape racial disparities in birth mode among women with a prior cesarean. Results will contribute to a better understanding of the circumstances associated with labor after cesarean ending in cesarean delivery, and help to identify potential interventions to improve the quality of care for women with a prior cesarean.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The continuous activation of certain immune sensors called Toll-like receptors (TLR7 and TLR9) and the production of pro-inflammatory signaling proteins, such as type-I interferons (IFN-I), drive the pathogenesis of many autoimmune conditions. Recent evidence has established that a poorly-characterized protein in immune cells, called SLC15A4, exerts control over these processes. The goal of this application is to develop inhibitors for and assess the therapeutic potential of SLC15A4 in order to create a new path for the treatment of autoimmune disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT This proposal aims to develop novel targeted therapeutics against blood cancer, with a focus on peripheral T cell lymphoma that affect thousands of patients annually in the United States. If successful, it will significantly advance our understanding of the progression and malignant transformation of blood cells, and provide new opportunities for developing therapeutic tools for the treatment of lymphoma and other types of tumors sharing the similar genetic defects in epigenetic and GTPase signaling pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The cDC1 subset is critical for immune responses to viruses and tumors, and proposals to expand this subset therapeutically by Flt3L administration rely on an untested presumption that such expanded populations can function normally. Our preliminary evidence indicates that FL3L expansion of cDC1 proceeds by a different genetic pathway than homeostatic cDC1 development. Thus, the goal of this application is to determine how cDC1 normally develop, how Flt3L treatment bypasses normal genetic requirements for cDC1 development, and whether Flt3L-induced cDC1 can operate in vivo in the same way as normal cDC1.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project will uncover new approaches to enhance the anti-cancer activity of immune cells, especially in the setting of aggressive malignancies that are refractory to current immune-based treatments. Upon completion, our project will provide new mechanistic understanding of how “stress signals” generated and delivered by tumors inhibit the protective function of our immune system. This knowledge should pave the way for developing novel forms of immunotherapy that more effectively control cancer progression and recurrence.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The seminal fluid proteins (Sfps) that accompany sperm into the female are important contributors to male fertility and are also molecular agents of sexual conflict. This proposal takes a combined functional and evolutionary approach to determine how Sfps work with the female and with sperm for optimal fertility, and to use them to probe sexual conflict molecularly. By exploiting the experimental advantages of the Drosophila model system to examine how Sfps function and evolve, we will obtain information that will be useful to diagnose certain forms of infertility, to design ways to control the mosquitoes that transmit serious human diseases and, potentially, to optimize conditions for assisted reproductive technologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The mechanisms behind impaired skeletal health with advancing age are still unclear, however defective energy metabolism is known to be associated with aging in multiple tissues. This proposal will investigate the role of energy metabolism in osteocytes, key regulatory bone cells, in response to mechanical loading and during aging. This work will enable us to identify novel strategies to maintain bone health during aging by targeting osteocyte energy metabolism.

PHR: Project Narrative MicroRNAs are essential regulators of gene expression, alterations in which have been shown to disrupt entire cellu- lar pathways, substantially contributing to a variety of human diseases. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Exposure to social disadvantage represents the most salient determinant of population health disparities in our nation. Our goal is to better understand the phenomenon of biological embedding of social disadvantage in the con- text of health and health disparities in obesity and metabolic outcomes. We hypothesize that the effects of social disadvantage may extend all the way down to the level of stem/progenitor cells – the cells that continually replenish our tissues and organ systems. In a study of Hispanic, non-Hispanic Black, and non-Hispanic White mother-child dyads, our project will test this hypothesis in stem cells obtained from child tissues (umbilical cord) at the time of birth. We will measure cellular features of child mesenchymal stem/progenitor cells (MSCs) and MSC-derived fat cells, along with newborn fat mass and glucose-insulin physiology. We expect our study findings to suggest avenues to better optimize long-term health and well-being.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance Statement The number of pediatric cancer survivors in the U.S is approaching 500,000. Because these survivors experience various complications and comorbidities related to their malignancy and treatment, there is a need for research to evaluate the influence of patient-specific demographic and genetic factors, premorbid and comorbid conditions, health behaviors, and aging on cancer treatment-related toxicity. The St. Jude Lifetime Cohort is providing new insights into the risks and underlying pathophysiology of adverse long-term effects, providing possible targets for intervention in this high-risk population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dysregulation of glutamate transporter subtype 1 (GLT-1) contributes to cocaine and opioid dependence and relapse. GLT-1 activators display efficacy in animal models of cocaine and opioid addiction, but they are limited primarily to β-lactam antibiotics that are not well tolerated by patients. By providing the first comprehensive in vivo study of GLT-1 activators that are structurally and mechanistically distinct from β-lactam antibiotics, we expect to provide an initial step in identifying non-β-lactam GLT-1 activators as potential treatments for drug addiction and related CNS diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Malaria remains one of the leading causes of death in children under five years of age in Sub-Saharan Africa, with the majority of these deaths attributable to Plasmodium falciparum infection. The recent global stall in the reduction of malaria deaths has made the development of an effective vaccine essential; however, a major challenge to developing an efficacious vaccine is the extensive diversity of Plasmodium falciparum antigens. Using the wealth of genomic resources currently available, together with targeted Plasmodium genome editing, we will fill a critical need in the malaria vaccine development field by bringing genetic diversity in candidate antigens to the forefront of vaccine candidate credentialing ultimately creating a systematic framework for evaluating new vaccine candidate antigens and combinations that will provide broadly neutralizing antibodies for inclusion in a globally effective vaccine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: This study begins to address a critical need for interventions that reduce both problem substance use (PSU) and HIV risk behavior among MSM in Latin America by adapting two evidence-based interventions, e-SBI and YMHP, for MSM in Argentina seeking HIV testing. Given that many MSM seek HIV testing in LGBT community agencies, these interventions have the potential to reach large numbers of MSM, help them reflect on their use of drugs and alcohol, and help link those with PSU to care. If proven efficacious in a future RCT, the implementation of these intervention in such agencies will help address a key contributor to HIV risk behavior and infection as well as reduce drug and alcohol use among MSM, who are disproportionately affected by HIV and substance use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Alkaloid biosynthetic studies NARRATIVE  Alkaloid biosyntheses are known to be a gold mine for novel/unprecedented transformations. In this proposal, besides in-depth mechanistic characterization of the novel, unprecedented transformations (e.g., endoperoxidation and oxidative C-S bond formation), we will also apply these mechanistic information to guide our genome-mining efforts.  Many of the compounds containing the functional groups (endoperoxide, epoxide, and thiols) have biological activities (e.g., anti-cancer, anti-infective, or having beneficial effects on many ageing associated diseases).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE I propose to determine whether the intermittent restriction and subsequent reintroduction of benzodiazepine coverage reduced the incidence of benzodiazepine-related harms among patients with indications for benzodiazepines use. A comprehensive evaluation of these restriction policies in a non-institutionalized population will inform the ongoing development of strategies to reduce the risk of benzodiazepine-related harms, including overdose and death.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Systemic sclerosis (SSc) is a disease with no known cause or cure. We reported that concordance for SSc in twins is lower than that reported for other rheumatic diseases. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Depression is a leading cause of disability worldwide and current treatments, such as psychotherapy and medication, are ineffective for many people, leading to a high global burden of depression. This project will investigate the efficacy of a 16-week Resistance Exercise Training (RET) program for treatment of Major Depressive Disorder via improving cerebrovascular mechanisms and using machine learning to inform future precision medicine approaches by modeling changes in depression outcomes, cerebrovascular function, and variation in adherence. If efficacy is confirmed, this highly translatable, accessible, low-cost treatment would add a novel behavioral treatment option for MDD while the machine learning modeling will independently help to improve treatment prescription and optimization for people with depression and other serious mental illnesses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  How the behaviors or experiences of one’s grandparents might affect our own health is not clear, but examples of the influence of transgenerational inheritance on metabolism, longevity, and even behavior have been documented in several model systems, and is surmised to exist in humans; furthermore, trans-kingdom signaling between bacteria and host cells might play a role in influencing behavior and transgenerational inheritance. We found that C. elegans can “read” the identity of bacteria through the bacteria’s own small RNAs, and subsequently use that information to influence behavior, avoiding the pathogen and passing this information on to four generations of progeny – and it may have co-opted a genomic “parasite,” a retrotransposon, to do so. We propose to use this system to identify the molecular regulators of the process, and to understand the logic of the system and its evolution.

PROJECT_TITLE: Cracking the Code of Transgenerational Inheritance of Behavior

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: HUGO W. MOSER RES INST KENNEDY KRIEGER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cerebral Adrenoleukodystrophy (CALD) is a neurologically devastating, inflammatory demyelinating disease of childhood that leads to a vegetative state or death in months to years. Treatments are most effective when initiated in the narrow window prior to the onset of neurological symptoms, however early identification of CALD is a significant challenge. In this project, we will study the transition from normal brain development to cerebral demyelination using advanced imaging techniques in order to widen the treatment window, provide lead-time for possible preventative strategies, and thereby help maximize neurological outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal is to improve the procedure of colonoscopy by improving a physician’s skill of probe insertion measured by the cecal intubation rate (CIR), improving a physician’s visualization thoroughness measured by colonoscopy adenoma detection rate (ADR), and reducing endoscope forces that can cause colon damage. This is achieved through the development of a Manikin Advanced Feedback Trainer (MAFT) that uses a sensorized manikin and offers guided optimization-based feedback to efficiently advance skills. The approach proposed adds broad knowledge about diverse colon anatomy geometries, optimal endoscope control strategies, and successful manikin sensorization training techniques.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative  Using single-cell RNA-sequencing to analyze the lungs of patients with pulmonary fibrosis, we have recently identified a novel distal basal cell population with profibrotic features in the lungs of patients with pulmonary fibrosis. Independent work in our group studying families with pulmonary fibrosis has identified mutations in an orphan receptor (GPR87) as a new PF risk gene; remarkably, and our preliminary data suggest GPR87 is predominantly expressed in these pathologic distal basal cells and may regulate their function. Utilizing innovative transgenic mouse, organoid and inducible pluripotent stem cell (iPSC)-based models, we will investigate the mechanisms through which GPR87 contributes to fibrotic susceptibility and adaptive versus pathologic lung epithelial repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative We have seen in the current SARS-CoV-2 pandemic, as for all major pathogen outbreaks in the last decade, how phylogenetic (i.e. evolutionary tree) methods are required to use viral genomic information to under- stand large-scale transmission patterns. However, current phylogenetic methods have two major limitations as a tool for viral control: ﬁrst, rigorous Bayesian probabilistic methods cannot scale to 1,000s of genomes, and second, models incorporating phylogenetic trees must be expressed in specialized phylogenetics pack- ages, making modern machine-learning approaches impossible. In this proposal, we develop variational ap- proaches to phylogenetics, which will allow fast inference and procedures to rapidly update inferences when new data arrives, as well as making phylogenetic trees a ﬁrst-class inferential object in major machine-learning packages. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Public Health Relevance: All life requires some form of nitrogen to function, and although the atmosphere is comprised of roughly 78% of dinitrogen (N2), it is biologically unavailable without reduction by nitrogenase enzymes, which convert unreactive N2 to a biologically-available form for uptake. The intimate details of this critical (and difficult) transformation are not understood, and although biological studies on the enzyme have demonstrated a critical role of cooperative interactions by nearby amino acid residues and a multi-metallic enzyme core, we do not know the intimate molecular details. This project aims to develop a molecular level understanding of these cooperative effects on substrate activation, which in addition to contributing important mechanistic details that govern nitrogenase function, may also translate into new catalyst development for organic and inorganic transformations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Periodontal disease (PD) is caused by unhealthy bacteria and plaque accumulation in the mouth leading to inflammation of periodontal tissues. The role of diet in PD progression is currently not well understood, yet is critical to better understanding disease progression and the development of new therapeutic approaches. This project proposes a novel approach to better understand how diet, particularly processed wheat grains, contributes to PD onset by altering bacteria, plaque accumulation, and periodontal inflammation in the mouth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Interactions between carbohydrates and proteins in biological systems play important roles in cellular proliferation, viral and bacterial pathogenesis, cell-cell recognition, fertilization, embryogenesis, neuronal development, and hormonal activities. Despite the importance in human physiology and pathophysiology, the study of carbohydrate-protein interactions remains challenging and highly specialized. In this proposal we describe the development of new tools that are needed to discover, study, and probe carbohydrate protein interactions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative LifeAfter90 is a newly launched cohort study of diverse individuals aged 90+ which has successfully enrolled and followed 908 research participants in 36 months. The continuation of LifeAFter90 will provide not only new information on dementia, and brain neuropathology but will also reveal early life contributions and risk factors for both cognitive `Super-Agers” and cognitive impairment. Renewal of LA90 will create an unprecedented scientific resource for studying Alzheimer's disease and cognitive outcomes in a diverse cohort of oldest-old individuals, a group representing the rapid diversification of this population.

This work is relevant to public health, because it will allow for the development of better influenza vaccines and more effective vaccination programs.

Primary objectives of the program include: for trainees to attain and demonstrate quantitative and systems analysis skills, to achieve diverse and equitable representation in the program, to facilitate the establishment of collaborative research networks, and to broadly disseminate innovative training and research tools.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: Ingestive decisions play a key role in a number of human conditions including obesity, diabetes, anorexia, hypertension, and coronary artery disease. The sense of taste is the most important factor in regulating these ingestive decisions, and therefore plays an important role in human health. The goal of this research is to uncover how taste neophobia learning is organized within central gustatory circuits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed research is relevant to public health because the malfunction of intra-flagellar transport (IFT) results in defects in primary cilium maintenance and abnormities in trafficking of signaling molecules that are associated with a variety of medical disorders, including developmental disorders, cancers and cystic diseases. The knowledge to be gained is essential for understanding the functional roles of IFT in structural assembly and maintenance of primary cilia and molecular trafficking in primary cilia. This knowledge will guide the development and evaluation of molecular therapies to ameliorate these primary cilium-related disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance Nearly half of the 3 million prostate cancer survivors in the U.S. were prescribed androgen deprivation therapy that increases their risk of becoming obese and frail. The proposed study determines whether a combination of a web-based lifestyle management program plus online supervised group resistance training can reduce obese frailty. We will also collect preliminary data on a set of implementation outcomes to guide future research testing the implementation of iLIVE into the clinical care pathway

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Narrative: Infectious diseases are responsible for reduced quality of human life, morbidity, and are taxing to the USA and global economy. To date, there are many infectious diseases that lack appropriate treatment options while current treatment regimens can often be less efficacious due to pathogen resistance. Training of pre-doctoral students at the interface of infectious diseases and drug discovery will have an impact on the number of new scientists harboring skills and determination to address critical gaps in treatment of infectious diseases.
PROJECT_TERMS: Communicable Diseases;drug discovery;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Drug Discovery in Infectious Disease Training
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Microbiology and Infectious Diseases B Research Study Section[MID-B]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Alcoholic hepatitis, the clinically most devastating presentation of alcoholic liver disease (ALD), is a significant global health problem, which has no effective therapeutics due to limited understanding of the mechanisms of disease progression, and liver transplantation remains the only curative option. The focus of this is the roles of sphingosine kinase 2 (SphK2)/sphingosine-1 phosphate (S1P)-mediated signaling pathways in alcohol-induced liver injury. Completion of this study will not only identify the potential cellular/molecular mechanisms involved in the initiation and progression of ALD but will also make a significant conceptual advance linking bile acids and SphK2 with alcoholic liver injury, which will create a fundamental base for developing novel therapies for ALD and a reduction of morbidity/mortality in patients with alcoholic hepatitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Parasitic diseases are responsible for millions of deaths in addition to severe and subtly morbidity and there are no effective vaccines or drug treatments to combat them. Understanding how parasites cause disease requires researchers and practitioners with high level of training. The Training in Tropical and Emerging Global Diseases program offers advanced training and professional development of talented predoctoral and postdoctoral trainees to prepare them for careers dedicated to fighting parasite pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Malaria is one of the major global health problems afflicting about 229 million people and causing over 400,000 deaths annually. Because of the emergence of drug resistance parasites, current therapies for malaria are rapidly losing their efficacy. The proposed research seeks to identify novel antimalarial lead compounds targeting parasite protein kinases effective against multidrug resistant malaria with therapeutic and prophylactic properties, thus contributing to the global malaria elimination campaign.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it contributes to laying the groundwork for the development of a new strategy to treat cancer by simultaneously utilizing DNA-targeted genotoxic therapy and the inhibition of critical proteins in a DNA damage repair pathway that is facilitated by homologous recombination (HR). HR in tumor cells is associated with accelerated resistance to chemo- and radiotherapy, and with recurrence of disease. The research proposed here aims to identify promising target molecules for inhibition in HR and, as such, is relevant to the NIH’s mission that pertains to increasing our understanding of the biological processes that will lead to advances in the treatment of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/REVELANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH This proposal aims to delineate the molecular mechanism underlying human testis aging through a combination of single-cell genomics, molecular and cell biology approaches. Recent data has demonstrated multiple degenerative changes in human reproductive tissues during aging, which can also be transmitted to the offspring and cause inherited disorders. Therefore, defining and understanding the molecular drivers of human testis aging has great implications for human reproductive health and wellness of the offspring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study will investigate milestones of oral microbiome development among Latinx infants who were born along the United States-Mexico border and have high risk for oral diseases. By contributing to new knowledge about the development of oral microbiome and modeling the association between pediatric microbial development and dental diseases, we may gain scientific insight to produce early prevention programs that can reduce dental disease risk and eventually prevent significant oral health disparities for this population. Understanding the dynamic changes of the oral microbiome may provide an innovative solution for personalized, predictive, and preventive pediatric dentistry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Deep learning shifts method development from hand-engineered models and pipelines to flexible models that can achieve state-of-the-art performance and learn complex patterns directly from the data. In this proposal we aim to leverage the potential of deep learning for the problem of SV discovery by developing a framework to call and genotype germline and somatic SVs, including complex variants, using data from different sequencing platforms. Improving SV detection will have a significant impact on our ability to characterize, diagnose, and treat a wide range of diseases driven by SVs, such as cancer and numerous neurological, autoimmune, and cardiovascular disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Small proteins, making up the majority of the proteome, are responsible for many devastating diseases, including cancer, cardiac arrhythmias and drug addiction. Due to their size, these proteins cannot be studied effectively by cryogenic electron microscopy (cryoEM), a technique allowing for proteins to be studied at native conditions more relevant to our understanding of function and disease causation. The proposed work is relevant to public health because we develop methods to break these size barriers and then study disease-associated proteins by cryoEM to aid in structure-guided drug design for potentially more effective therapeutics.

PROJECT_TITLE: Breaking barriers in CryoEM through computational protein design

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is the leading infectious disease cause of congenital viral infections in the newborn and has profound effects on the immune system. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Craving is one of the most clinically-important symptoms experienced by individuals in treatment, including those with opioid use disorders for whom several evidence-based treatments exist. Unfortunately, these treatments do not adequately address craving and reuse and relapse are the modal outcomes. If successful, this study will have uncovered a previously unknown biological indicator of how craving works to bias decisions toward drug use in addicted individuals. Studies can then use this indicator as a target of treatment, perhaps ultimately culminating in the implementation of interventions to reverse the specific decision biases induced by craving and thus improve patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Alzheimer's disease is a devastating and incurable neurodegenerative disorder projected to affect 13 million individuals in the US by 2050. Integrating results from human genetic studies with innovative model organism investigations, we will discover the mechanisms responsible for risk of Alzheimer's disease and related dementias. Improved functional understanding of Alzheimer's disease susceptibility, including disease amplifying and protective factors, holds enormous potential for therapeutic breakthroughs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Acute systemic inflammation, such as that seen after severe infections, leads to endothelial-mediated vascular dysfunction that is a costly burden to modern healthcare systems with a high morbidity and mortality. This research program aims to apply a multi-modal approach to elucidate the vascular mechanisms resulting from acute, systemic inflammation using integrated and complimentary themes involving animal studies, human populations and biochemical and molecular techniques. The overall goal is to better understand the effect of acute vasculopathy on critically ill patients and discover better ways to diagnose and treat them.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Reflection of the past brings awareness and comprehension to why inequities in oral health exist and continue to pose major public health threats, how public oral health policies have developed and been implemented, where innovations in oral health have occurred, what oral health care means to overall health, and who has been and can be responsible for shaping the trajectory of the dental profession. By translating these larger humanities-based themes into interactive, age-appropriate, and NGSS oriented lessons, P-12 learners will gain an understanding of how oral health care has progressed and impacted the world around them, as well as how they too can fit into the continuing story of dentistry and oral health. To accomplish this goal, the project will create accessible, freely available educational modules that combine the health sciences, humanities, and STEM to increase oral health literacy and awareness of pathways to the dental and dental research professions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We aim to train the next generation of scientists to understand, treat and prevent movement disorders, and to become rigorous and creative investigators. We will provide predoctoral trainees with both specialized research training in their chosen discipline and give them an appreciation for the broader issues related to motor control and movement disorder-related research, from molecular, systems, behavioral to computational. We have an experienced and dedicated team of researchers in a rich and collaborative academic environment.

PROJECT_TITLE: Neural, Computational, and Neuromechanical Approaches to Motor Control

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The delivery of drugs to sites of need, while sparing healthy tissue from often toxic side-effects, remains a challenge in drug delivery. Targeted carriers have been explored, often leveraging biological affinity, yet these localize only a small percent of an administered drug. We are developing a molecular-scale synthetic approach to target drugs to desired sites in the body through rapid formation of long-lived non-covalent affinity interactions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE No prophylactic or therapeutic regimen is known for any prion disease. We have developed novel vaccine strategies 6-8,16, a carefully-graded chronic wasting disease (CWD) challenge 9,10 and longitudinal monitoring system using ultrasensitive CWD detection methods in white-tailed deer 9,10,12,13, to permit vaccine assessment in the native host. In summary, we will determine the efficacy, safety and ability of prototype vaccines, alone or additive in combination to protect against prion infection.

ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Veterinarians are uniquely qualified to conduct biomedical research using animal models, but relatively few go into this field of work due to a lack of research training opportunities. This proposal aims to rectify this situation by enrolling veterinarians in a Ph.D. program that equips them with the fundamentals of conducting hypothesis- driven, cutting-edge biomedical research using state-of-the-art technologies and encourages their pursuit of careers in research in academia, industry and /or government.

PHR: Project Narrative  The “Scientific Communication Advances Research Excellence 2.0” program (SCOARE 2.0) is relevant to public health because it will contribute to building and sustaining a diverse and highly skilled biomedical and behavioral research workforce. The program will continue to provide innovative, evidence- based mentor training in the principles and practices of scientific communication (SciComm) skill development and broaden its impact through the addition of novel content and translation to a hybrid asynchronous delivery format. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / RELEVANCE  This project seeks to investigate the molecular function and evolution of long noncoding RNAs (lncRNAs) in mammalian gene regulation, in particular, X chromosome dosage compensation. Abnormalities in dosage compensation and dysregulation of lncRNAs have been linked to many human developmental disorders and diseases including cancer. Research findings from this proposal will provide essential knowledge for applying lncRNAs in health diagnostics and will contribute to new methods for targeted disease therapies and prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Spore-forming bacteria cause over a million infections each year, and spores are central to the infectious cycle of these pathogens and can resist antibiotics and sterilization. In this proposal we will determine the molecular mechanisms underlying spore germination. Our work will enable the development of treatments that either inappropriately induce germination, leaving cells vulnerable to standard antibacterial therapies, or block it, directly preventing disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Functional Analysis of the Clp Protease Systems in Chlamydial Growth and Differentiation Chlamydiae are important pathogens of humans and significant causes of morbidity, causing a range of illnesses including sexually transmitted diseases, trachoma, pneumonia, and other respiratory tract infections. The burden of these infections stems from their lack of symptoms, which can lead to chronic conditions such as infertility, adult-onset asthma, and, in some cases, possibly exacerbating heart disease. The work proposed here is to define the role of conserved and novel elements associated with protein degradation in chlamydiae, which in turn may lead to the design of novel therapeutics that would eliminate the broad effects of standard antimicrobial therapy on normal flora.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Neuronal Ceroid Lipofuscinoses comprise a group of inherited and fatal pediatric neurodegenerative disorders affecting approximately 6-8 infants per 100,000 live births, the CLN3 subtype is the most common. This application aims to continue hit-to-lead development of a library of multifunctional compounds that act to enhance the expression of the anti-apoptotic protein Bcl-2, reduce ceramide synthesis and activate autophagy, resulting in ability to rescue the pro-apoptotic and defective autophagy phenotypes of CLN3 patient induced pluripotent stem cell-derived neurons and rescue neurobehavioral deficits in a CLN3 mouse model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over the past several years, a number of new molecular technologies have been developed that can modify both the DNA and RNA within living cells, many of which have been adapted from naturally occurring systems or enzymes. This project aims to computationally mine natural diversity for enzymes that can programmably recognize RNA sequences, characterize these enzymes to understand how they work, and use them as the basis for the development of new molecular tools for making precise changes to RNA sequences and for marking specific cell types that express a targeted RNA transcript. These tools can be used by other researchers to study many aspects of human biology and disease as well as be applied in the future for therapeutic uses, which we aim to demonstrate the feasibility of in this work.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Hundreds of clinical studies against a wide spectrum of cancers have resulted in the approval of just three therapeutic cancer vaccines, including Provenge®, which extends survival among men with prostate cancer by 2 to 3 months without inducing actual cancer regression or objective responses. The proposed platform has the potential to transform the way immune protection against cancer is generated. By introducing into the personal T-cell repertoire engineered T-cell receptors (TCRs) that optimally bind the most prevalent vaccine epitope, robust T-cell immunity could be reliably induced in a diverse human population independent of each individual's preexisting TCR repertoire.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Treatment options for people with co-occurring opioid and stimulant use disorders are limited, partially because this group is inadequately represented in treatment efficacy evaluations. The proposed research uses a novel data-fusion approach to translate narrowly-focused clinical trial results to broader, representative populations with co-occurring opioid and stimulant use disorders. This study will demonstrate the effectiveness of treatments for real-world patients with these co-occurring substance use disorders; clinicians, researchers, policymakers, and other stakeholders may use results to select treatments that improve the health of people using more than one substance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Influenza A virus (IAV) is a serious respiratory pathogen, which poses an ongoing pandemic threat. Our research will focus on engineering new “universal" vaccines for influenza with the potential to elicit broad and cross-reactive immune responses against seasonal and pandemic viruses by (i) selecting highly conserved IAV immunogens and combining them within a single vaccine, (ii) increasing the immune recognition of these immunogens by incorporating molecular adjuvanting approaches, and (iii) finally by delivering optimized antigen expression cassettes using novel adenoviral vectored vaccines with low seroprevalence in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Individualized medicine in the future will need to know exactly what specific mechanisms are affected by each individual disease mutant. This project will develop that information from the computational assessments of the effects of any possible mutation by building upon the knowledge that will be mined from the large number of genome sequences, interpreted in terms of functional proteins. The results will impact the selection of drugs for individual patients, the design of more effective drugs developed by narrowing the focus to the specific parts of a targeted protein that will be identified as being responsible for adversely affecting mechanism. The project will provide quantitative predictors of the potential adverse effects of mutants on specific mechanisms and will organize relevant data and predictions into readily accessible databases, to provide important new information to the practitioners of individualized medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bacteria live everywhere as members of multispecies communities, and the activities in these microbiomes can have profound impacts on their hosts as well as the environment. This research focuses on discovering the chemical and genetic mechanisms bacteria use to interact with one another. Gaining a molecular understanding of these cell-cell interactions will provide us with a better understanding of microbial ecology as well as chemical tools to manipulate bacterial behavior in natural microbiomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research will develop and validate advanced multiparametric imaging technology which combines magnetic resonance imaging, cytometry and elastography (MR-ICE) to substantially advance noninvasive characterization of the spectrum histopathologic changes in patients with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease. Success of the proposed research will provide critically needed noninvasive technology for identifying patients who have a high risk of developing advanced disease in the nonalcoholic steatohepatitis spectrum, allowing early therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The system comprising the bacterium Escherichia coli and its virus, bacteriophage lambda, serves as a simple paradigm for the way gene regulation drives the choice between alternative cellular fates. The outcome of the proposed work will be a predictive, quantitative description of gene regulation and fate choice in the system, at the single-cell level. The conceptual and experimental tools developed in this work will further our understanding of how gene regulation drives cell-fate choices in higher systems, and ultimately, in the context of human health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  The Research Domain Criteria (RDoC) provides the basis for research into the brain system dysfunctions that are responsible for mental illness, but the existing RDoC framework has serious limitations that prevent it from being fully effective in driving research. We propose to use a combination of large-scale online behavioral testing and extensive MRI scanning of individuals performing a set of psychological tasks that are relevant to a set of mental processes (attention, working memory, and cognitive control) that are known to play a key role in mental illness. This approach will allow us to extend the RDoC framework to more precisely map from the mental processes involved in mental illness to brain circuits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Identifying ways to improve CD8 T cell responses to viral and infection and cancer is a goal of immediate importance. We recently identified that the cytokine, IL-27, promotes expansion and CD8 T cell responses during persistent viral infection. In the current proposal we will investigate the cellular sources of IL-27, how this cytokine sustains CD8 T cells survival and whether IL-27 signaling is essential for sustaining CD8 T cell responses to anti-PD-1/L1 therapy during persistent viral infection and cancer; the ultimate goal of these studies is to understand how IL-27 promotes optimal CD8 T cell responses in these disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People with HIV are living longer in Latin America with widespread access to antiretroviral therapy increasing risk of developing HIV-associated neurocognitive disorder (HAND), present in up to 50% of people with HIV worldwide. Emerging data, including our preliminary data, highlight that identifying HIV-associated neurocognitive disorders in Latin America is challenging given limited resources and specialists. I propose to evaluate a simple multi-modal platform for screening and predicting HAND in two large HIV clinics in Lima, Peru that can be utilized to assess the impact of HAND in Latin America.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The proposed research will develop new data modeling and analysis techniques to extract clinically useful information from brain activity measurements of patients with neurological injuries. These techniques will allow clinicians to make real-time predictions of patient outcomes and design earlier and more targeted treatments, using non-invasive technologies. Thus, the proposed research will improve the care of individual patients and enhance clinical efficiency, including in under-resourced healthcare settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative  Respiratory syncytial virus is a major health threat to infants, in particular when born prematurely, with underlying respiratory conditions or congenital heart disese, older adults, and the immunocompromised. A lack of effective vaccines and efficacious antiviral therapeutics creates an urgent clinical need for the development of novel therapeutics that improve RSV disease management and control virus spread. This project will advance two innovative RSV inhibitor classes towards formal preclinical development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: NARRATIVE The central diagnostic finding in Fuchs endothelial corneal dystrophy are progressive guttae—excrescences in the extracellular matrix of the corneal endothelium that contribute to vision loss and corneal endothelial cell loss. This project will investigate the extracellular matrix changes that occur when corneal endothelial cells are exposed to stress and will investigate how non-diseased corneal endothelial cells respond to extracellular matrix prepared from stressed cells. Extracellular matrix changes may be some of the first changes that occur in the pathophysiology of Fuchs endothelial corneal dystrophy and these studies will help identify potential pathways to target for future therapeutics.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The current project will establish the significance of the calcium-handling protein phospholamban in the thalamic reticular nucleus, a brain region implicated in the pathophysiology of various neurodevelopmental disorders. The proposed research is highly relevant to the mission of the NIH and public health; gaining insights into the intricate calcium-cycling processes that operate in the thalamic reticular circuitry may lead to the development of novel pharmacotherapeutic approaches to help manage these debilitating and costly brain disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project seeks to overcome a widely held but inaccurate assumption that has long plagued the study of the stuttering condition: that a surface view of stuttering severity can (a) identify adults who stutter at risk for broader impact and (b) accurately specify speech neurophysiology in adults who stutter. Both of these assumptions will be directly challenged by consideration of sub-group differences in cognitive-affective reactions measured via validated nationally representative surveys and by measuring speech neurophysiology in situ in realistic face-to- face communicative environments using functional near-infrared spectroscopy. The identification of adults who stutter at-risk for broader impact and the specification of speech neurophysiology in real-world communication will directly support improvements in the assessment and treatment of the disorder, further specify pathophysiology of stuttering, and reduce the burden of living with the condition in the roughly three million individuals in the United States who stutter.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative With the rapid increase in medicinal cannabis use, there is an urgent need to identify patients who are at-risk for cannabis use disorder, which can occur as an unintended adverse effect of using medicinal cannabis. Importantly, not all patients who use medicinal cannabis develop addiction or a pathological pattern of cannabis use (cannabis use disorder). This longitudinal study will collect new data on cannabis use in relation to health at micro (daily) and macro (follow-up over 2-years) time scales to understand the roles of tolerance and withdrawal (symptoms often experienced when taking medication as recommended) in likelihood of addiction among medicinal cannabis patients, and will identify risk factors for cannabis use disorder as a possible iatrogenic effect of using medicinal cannabis to inform clinical practice guidelines.
