IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Pain is the principal reason for seeking medical attention. It respects no boundaries, is not restricted to any one disease or medical discipline, is distributed across the life span and experienced by all irrespective of status (economic, educational, etc.) or gender. Many tissue insults lead to chronic pain states which are poorly managed because the mechanisms underlying pain are incompletely understood. Thus, there is a compelling need to enhance and broaden the training of the next generation of pain researchers.
PROJECT_TERMS: Clinical;Pain;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Training in Mechanisms and Clinical Presentation of Pain

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Black Americans experience significant mental health consequences due to race-related stress; yet, little is known about the psychological mechanisms through which race-related stress leads to negative outcomes and whether such mechanisms can be altered using brief, culturally-informed mindfulness interventions. To address this, we aim to investigate (a) if attention bias to threat – a novel, understudied transdiagnostic factor that reflects when one’s attention is disproportionately allocated to threatening stimuli – is such a mechanism in the race- related stress-mental health link, (b) if a brief, culturally-responsive mindfulness intervention can reduce attention bias to threat, and (c) if racial identity, a key individual difference factor, exacerbates race-related stress’s effects and amplifies the benefits of a culturally-informed intervention. To carry out this project, rigorous experimental designs and innovative eye-tracking methods in a Black community sample will be used, and findings from this project can inform the development of culturally anchored etiological and treatment models for this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The Kansas IDeA Network of Biomedical Research Excellence (K-INBRE) is a network of Universities in Kansas and Oklahoma that augments the research infrastructure, training, research productivity, and career development of biomedical researchers and undergraduate students. The K-INBRE offers diverse programs and funding mechanisms to support researcher pipelines and careers, build research infrastructure, and enhance the competitiveness of Kansas biomedical researchers. The K-INBRE’s strength is its long-standing collaborative network and success in pipeline development for students, trainees, and faculty in biomedical research. K-INBRE operates through three Cores with foci in faculty and trainee mentoring, data science, and administration and execution of this longstanding Kansas IDeA program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will evaluate and refine an artificial intelligence computer program (an “algorithm”) that can quickly read thousands of CT scans to look for calcium deposits in heart arteries to better predict heart attacks, strokes, and death. The study will also hold focus groups to identify the best way for patients and their doctors to use the information from the algorithm to initiate treatment for heart disease prevention. If the algorithm works as expected, it could be used to automatically screen millions of patients from diverse backgrounds who are unaware of their risk for heart disease and guide them toward lifesaving treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Parent Project Narrative Emotional experience changes in advanced adulthood, where emotional deficits may predate neuropsychiatric disorders. The brain and autonomic nervous system cohesively interact to support social-emotional well-being. Cutting-edge analytical techniques can now reveal the dynamic properties of these systems. I propose to determine how autonomic and functional brain network dynamics shape human emotions in older adults and to assess how these neural systems are impacted by loneliness.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (Parent) The proposed study will provide essential information regarding which intervention targets and strategies are most likely to improve receipt of preventive services and ultimately reduce morbidity among children with SCA. We will use quantitative methods to identify critical targets within the healthcare delivery system, as well as key subgroups of the population, that can be intervened upon to improve the receipt of preventive services, and qualitative methods to identify barriers and facilitators to receipt of these services. We will integrate the findings from the quantitative analysis with the results from the qualitative analysis to fill the gap in understanding specific targets within the healthcare system, key population subgroups, and feasible strategies for interventions to maximize the receipt of preventive services among children with sickle cell anemia.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Opportunities to optimize the receipt of preventive services among children with sickle cell anemia: A Mixed Methods Approach

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research will investigate the chemosensory and behavioral mechanisms in mice associated with the detection and perception of threatening predatory chemosignals. Chemosensation plays an important role in human well-being, including detecting dangers, food preferences, alcohol consumption, maternal bonding, and lifespan. Investigating how chemosensation contributes to social behavior can help us understand the human brain better and provide important insights that can improve the well-being of humans with chemosensation dysfunction and neurodegenerative disorders.

PHR: Relevance to Public Health  Defects in calcium signaling can lead to a variety of diseases that include cancer, Alzheimer’s diseases, and cardiovascular diseases. Proper calcium signaling is also critical for the pathogenicity of many micro-organisms. This project will increase our understanding of calcium signaling, provide new insights for disease mechanisms, and identify novel targets for the development of anti-fungal drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The overarching goal of the Brigham and Women’s Hospital/Harvard Medical School Roybal Center for Therapeutic Optimization using Behavioral Science is to continue to develop principle-driven interventions to enhance the evidence-based use of prescription medications. The structure and activities of the proposed Center will be based upon 4 key principles: (1) a multi-disciplinary approach; (2) the testing of principle-driven interventions in real-world settings; (3) the explicit testing of mechanisms of action, and (4) the use of novel analytic methods and technological approaches to gain a deeper understanding of behavioral mechanisms and to personalize interventions. The principle-driven interventions developed by our Center will readily translate to improvements in healthy aging and will also advance our fundamental understanding of how health behaviors can be effectively sustained.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – OVERALL Congenital cytomegalovirus (cCMV) is the leading global infectious cause of birth defects, hearing loss, and long-term neurologic deficits in infants exposed during gestation. Despite being considered a top priority for several decades, development of an effective CMV vaccine has been limited due to a gap in understanding of protective immune responses and virologic determinants of congenital CMV transmission. This Program will identify new antigen targets and immunization strategies for CMV vaccines to prevent and reduce cCMV infection, guiding design and clinical trial testing of next generation HCMV vaccines to prevent congenital CMV transmission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Opioid use increases the levels of phosphorylated tau protein in the brain, which is a classical marker of tauopa- thy neurodegenerative diseases, yet opioid use is not known to produce classical tau-related neurodegeneration pathology. Therefore, it is not clear if opioid-induced changes in tau are a byproduct of opioid use that has no independent effect on neurobehavioral function or if these changes in tau contribute to the effect of opioids on neural function and opioid consumption-related behaviors. This high-risk, high-reward project tests the hypothe- sis that opioids increase tau expression, phosphorylation, and aggregation in the prefrontal cortex leading to synaptic dysfunction and elevated oxycodone consumption.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project seeks to develop a fundamental understanding of interactions of β-peptides with membranes, to understand folding of β-barrel proteins, and to enable design of membrane proteins that can be assembled from modular elements. In the long term, this would enable us to design proteins with modified functionalities that can be added from the outside and assemble in the cell membrane. Those functions can improve uptake of drugs, antibiotics or nutrients (metabolites) at the cellular level, with vast applications to human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The objective of the proposed research is relevant to public health because S-adenosylmethionine (AdoMet) synthetase genes and AdoMet have been implicated in multiple cancer types, but the mechanism of action is not well understood because both increases and decreases in expression are associated with cancers. Our group has conducted studies on the AdoMet synthetase genes, SAM1 and SAM2, in S. cerevisiae and determined the opposite nature of impacts of deletion of these paralogous genes on genome stability and other cellular pathways. In addition to advancing the field towards a more complete mechanistic understanding of regulation of AdoMet and a detailed characterization of the impacts of mutations; including effects on the methyl cycle and the individual steps in genome stability changes, this multi-disciplinary project meets the stated objectives of the AREA program by offering undergraduate students hands-on training in classical genetics and modern molecular techniques and strengthens the research environment at Northern Kentucky University.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The goal of our proposed Roybal Center is to speed up the pace and increase the impact of scientific discoveries about how to change health behaviors to prevent premature aging. To do this, we focus on three innovative strategies: design thinking to incorporate the experiences of older adults; online platforms that help us conduct large-scale studies easily; and dynamic adaptation, which allows us quickly learn how different interventions work for different populations. With these strategies, we will design and conduct studies ranging from small pilots to ensure our interventions can work up to larger-scale studies with companies and health care organizations that show how interventions do work in real-world settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Hemophilia A is caused by the disruption of the gene encoding blood coagulation factor VIII and is the most common form of hemophilia, affecting 1 in 5,000 males worldwide. The most significant complication in the management of hemophilia A is the development of an inhibitory immune response to therapeutically infused factor VIII. Studying the blood coagulation mechanism of, and immune response to, factor VIII with a combination of structural and biochemical techniques can lead to improved therapies for hemophilia A patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed research focuses on using infrared (IR) spectroscopy with vibrational reporters (nitriles and azides) to probe local structure and dynamics in two proteins (adenylate kinase [AK] and superfolder green fluorescent protein) and in RNA hairpins. Mutations in AK are associated with hemolytic anemia, reticular dysgenesis, and ciliary dyskinesia. RNA structure is complex and the information gained from this research has the potential to benefit future advances in RNA vaccines, CRISPR, and RNA interference therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Bacterial cells in the environment communicate through the language of molecular cues. Here, we propose to study how molecules derived from the bacterial cell wall regulate bacterial growth decisions using the paradigm of bacterial dormancy in a prototypic uropathogenic strain of Escherichia coli. This research will identify the pharmacophore of the cell wall signal, or cue, elucidate genes that enable the bacterial response to the signal, and identify bacterial protein targets that engage the signal to further understand the underlying mechanism of bacterial crosstalk. The work in this proposal will expose 6 to 10 undergraduate students to biomedically relevant research with significant impact in synthetic chemistry and bacterial genetics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This study investigates how the redox state (and its alteration via environmental and genetic factors) during optic tectum (OT) development, the homolog to the mammalian superior colliculus (SC), affects OT neurogenesis and specification and modifies subsequent OT-driven behaviors. Accumulating evidence has implicated the SC in neurodevelopmental disorders, such as autism spectrum disorder (ASD), and in neurodegenerative disorders, such as Lewy body dementia, Parkinson disease, progressive supranuclear palsy etc. Very few studies have investigated the effects of redox state in OT circuitry, therefore, our study would fill an important gap in the current understanding. Additionally, since the SC is associated with ASD, and the environmental factor used here, valproic acid, is also correlated with higher ASD incidence, this study might shed light into the molecular and cellular underpinnings of ASD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: One’s diet and other factors influence the innate population of gut bacteria (the “microbiota”), which in turn helps shape physiology and health. Specific metabolites that are made by the microbiota are called xenometabolites, which can play communication and signaling roles in the host. Identifying the entire catalog of these molecules, understanding their trafficking and storage, and determining their specific roles is an emerging field of study. This proposal will characterize how unique microbe-derived fats are generated and will explore how these xenolipids regulate physiological systems important to physiology and metabolism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative (Overall) The goal of the Arizona State University Roybal Center for Older Adults Living Alone with Cognitive Decline (ASU Roybal) is to develop infrastructure, facilitate the design and conduct of 12 clinical trials, and sustain the Center’s long-term impact. The interventions will be driven by mechanisms of behavior change and apply digital technologies to delay Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias. These interventions will empower this population and improve their quality of life. It will test innovative technology-enabled interventions in a growing but overlooked population—older adults living alone with cognitive decline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (Overall): Dementia impacts both the person who carries the diagnoses and their care-partners. However, most interventions do not account for the interrelation among the dyad members when conducting behavioral research, with negative consequences for both the affected person and their care-partner. The MGH CONFIDE-ADRD will provide a research infrastructure with a novel experiential learning and team science approach to enhance dementia dyadic behavioral research to improve health and prevent negative individual and dyadic health outcomes.

PHR: Project Narrative Many human diseases are caused by aberrant lipid composition and rarely do we understand the mechanisms leading to the disruption of normal physiology. The C. elegans proteins being studied are homologous to human proteins that function in lipid metabolism. The proposed work will provide insights into how alterations in lipid biosynthesis and degradation can disrupt cellular physiology, which will provide fundamental knowledge that could lead to the treatment of disease.

PHR: RI-INBRE Narrative RI-INBRE is a network comprised of all nine universities and colleges in Rhode Island. RI-INBRE support of biomedical research in RI has significantly improved faculty-driven research and student training. This has helped position RI to substantially contribute to biomedical research in the region and the nation. Continued support of RI-INBRE is necessary to realize the full potential of this biomedical capacity building. Additional investment in the robust biomedical research framework in RI will maintain this upward trajectory, sustain the return on investments, and enhance the state's appeal as a destination for innovative research and biomedical investment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it defines the selectivity and activity determinants of bacterial sortases, a therapeutic target for antibiotic development against Gram-positive bacteria (e.g., Staphylococcus aureus) and a widely utilized tool in protein engineering. Within these applications, the majority of sortase-mediated ligation efforts utilize a single, highly specific sortase enzyme (from S. aureus), whereas observations for the broader protein family suggest a spectrum of target specificity. A greater understanding of the mechanistic basis of bacterial sortase selectivity and activity can dramatically expand next-generation protein engineering efforts; therefore, the proposed research is directly in line with the mission of the National Institute of General Medical Sciences to “support basic research that… lays the foundation for advances in disease treatment.”

PHR: Project Narrative Elder mistreatment (EM) is a major public health concern, with a limited evidence-base for behavioral interventions to reduce and prevent EM and its consequences. PHR: Project Narrative This project will enhance the capacity of the Minnesota Department of Health to promote occupational health and safety through surveillance of a core set of occupational health indicators and dissemination of the findings to appropriate stakeholders for use in setting priorities for education and prevention activities. The project will expand the use of industry and occupation information in established data collection efforts and will explore new sources of data in order to include previously underserved worker populations in surveillance of occupational health and safety.

PHR: Project Narrative Workers in Nebraska face risks to their health, safety, and well-being at their workplaces. State- based surveillance systems for occupational injuries and illnesses can provide critical data to assess the burden and trends of occupational morbidity and mortality in order to inform prevention efforts. The overall goal of the Nebraska Occupational Safety and Health Surveillance Program is to enhance public health surveillance in order to reduce the incidence of work-related injuries, illnesses, and exposures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over 50% of smokers attempting to quit will relapse to smoking within the first year. Personal social networks can have powerful influences on smoking behavior and the chances of relapsing. The proposed study will test Helpers Stay Quit, an innovative relapse prevention program that teaches newly-quit smokers how to reach out and help others in their personal network to quit, thereby creating a social environment more supportive of staying quit.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator (Last, First, Middle): Morris, Martha Clare and Aggarwal, Neelum Stroke survivors are debilitated by cognitive decline, depression and disability, and pharmacologic treatments are largely ineffective. This application proposes to conduct a Phase III randomized controlled trial designed to test the effects of a 3-year intervention of the MIND diet (Mediterranean-DASH Intervention for Neurodegenerative Delay) on cognitive decline, brain neurodegeneration, functional disability, and depression among 500 ischemic stroke patients, aged 60-80 years and without dementia who are discharged home. The project has great potential to contribute to the NIH mission of funding research that enhances health and reduces illness or disability. PHS 398/2590 (Rev. 06/09) Page Continuation Format Page

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: In 2016, 64,000 Americans died from accidental overdose of opioid drugs. The majority became addicted after being prescribed opioids for pain. The crisis is especially acute for veterans. Up to 25% of patients at VA outpatient clinics have received opioids for pain, and an estimated 8-12% have gone on to develop opioid use disorder. These statistics highlight a crisis that was created by a perfect storm of ill-advised pain treatment practices, healthcare expectations, and rampant availability of cheap high potency illicit opioids. To address the crisis, improved healthcare practices, better pain medications, and better addiction therapies are needed. Improved knowledge of the mechanisms underlying opioid addiction, craving, and relapse could help predict who may be at risk, and guide new therapeutic strategies for addiction that do not rely on alternative opioid medications. This proposal highlights a pathway that may contribute to addiction vulnerability, and could lead to new therapies that repurpose non-opioid medications already available for human use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: Project Narrative A critical challenge for all cardiovascular regenerative strategies is the need for neovascularization to support any newly generated cardiomyocytes. This project seeks to identify the role of O-GlcNAcylation in transdifferentiation and epigenetic plasticity, which will identify an epigenetic mechanism for cellular plasticity and a novel therapeutic target to enhance endogenous neovascularization for treatment of cardiovascular disease. The goals of these studies will uncover novel mechanisms of metabolic regulation of cell fate plasticity, which will lead to interventions for the treatment of ischemic syndromes, a goal consistent with the mission of the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute: to “understand normal biological function and resilience” in order to “develop and optimize novel diagnostic and therapeutic strategies to prevent, treat, and cure HLBS diseases.”

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Many prevalent neurodevelopmental disorders such as autism spectrum disorder, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, and Tourette syndrome share common characteristics including impulsivity and repetitive action patterns. These behaviors may originate through the dysregulation of action control mechanisms, however, the circuit alterations that give rise to these action control deficits are not well understood. This proposal aims to provide valuable insight into the neural pathology involved in these disorders, as well as elucidate the neural mechanisms involved in normal action control regulation.

PHR: The Translational and Molecular Sciences Training Program will provide a focus on translational research training for PhD graduate students. The program will consist of a mixture of didactic elements interwoven with meaningful clinical experiences that are individualized to synergize with research interests of each trainee. The objectives are to provide the necessary skills, training and experience for the next generation of biomedical scientists to integrate translational research elements into their research interests and prepare students for the diverse set of jobs anticipated in the translational research arena.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The underlying mechanisms driving the relationship between prolonged ST and higher CVD risk in youth is unclear, but recent studies have begun to examine ST as it relates to cardiac ANS function since cardiac ANS imbalance is linked to adverse CVD outcomes. However, very few studies have examined the relationship between ST and cardiac ANS function in youth, and studies that have do not examine associations within a day or within a person, and do not experimentally manipulate prolonged ST. Therefore, this study will leverage data collection opportunities from an NIH-funded randomized control trial (P.I. Dr. Britni Belcher; R01DK12333) that will allow for the relationship between ST and cardiac ANS function (via heart rate variability metrics) to be investigated observationally within-day under free-living conditions and experimentally, in which it will be determined how interruptions in prolonged ST may influence cardiac ANS function in youth with OW/OB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Chronic inflammation, and diseases that arise from chronic inflammation like atherosclerosis, benefit from vitamin D’s action on inflammatory suppression and active vitamin D (calcitriol, 1,25(OH)2D3) may be produced in nonrenal tissues in response to inflammation improving the disease condition. However, both the genomic mechanism for this regulation and clinical or animal evidence have remained elusive, therefore we seek to quantify the presence of calcitriol in nonrenal tissues in health and disease, investigate a mechanism for the inflammatory upregulation of the gene responsible for the enzymatic conversion to calcitriol, Cyp27b1, and define the biological benefits of local calcitriol production on atherosclerosis disease progression. Upon conclusion of these research studies, we will have defined a mechanism for Cyp27b1 regulation and vitamin D metabolite production in nonrenal tissues of the mouse in vivo, which will provide support for nonrenal calcitriol benefits and therefore may be clinically relevant in the design of human supplementation and studies aimed at disease onset prevention and/or amelioration of core symptoms during disease progression.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Although the regulation of mRNA degradation contributes to gene expression patterns and can be highly complex, the extent of its impact on developmental gene expression remains largely unexplored. In addition, defects in mRNA degradation machinery result in distinct and severe developmental defects in model organisms and have been linked to diseases such as osteosarcoma and neurodegenerative diseases in humans, though whether such machinery function in specific developmental processes must be characterized. Here I propose an innovative strategy using bulk and single-cell RNA-sequencing and live cell imaging/automated lineage tracing to address these gaps in knowledge and provide a more comprehensive understanding of gene regulation during development by focusing on post-transcriptional regulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is an extremely aggressive malignancy with a five-year survival of less than 5%. Genomic analyses of human samples suggest that PDAC can be classified into at least two major subtypes based on cancer cell autonomous properties. The proposed research will investigate the molecular regulators of PDAC subtype and provide fundamental knowledge required for the design of therapeutic strategies that target PDAC on the basis of subtype-specific vulnerabilities.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Up to half of older U.S. military Veterans report chronic pain-related disabilities. In addition, military populations are developing degenerative pain conditions at much higher rates and at younger ages than civilians. There is a higher prevalence of chronic pain and opioid use reported in Veterans compared to civilian populations. Accordingly, Veterans treated chronically with opioids for their chronic pain may be vulnerable to developing opioid addiction (i.e. opioid dependence) and/or using illicit opioids to self-medicate pain symptoms. This project will examine overlapping brain biochemical mechanisms of chronic pain and opioid dependence that may contribute to the worsening and potential interdependence of these two disorders, with the ultimate goal of developing better therapeutic strategies for these devastating conditions affecting VA populations. Additionally, with the growing number of female Veterans treated by the VA for chronic pain issues, it is necessary to investigate new treatment opportunities for the benefit of both male and female Veterans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Veterans who experience traumatic brain injury often have profound and debilitating sleep impairments impacting their mood, health, and overall well-being. The proposed experiments will determine how inflammatory molecular mechanisms in brain cells alter brain blood flow to affect sleep and brain wave dynamics. Findings from this proposal will aid in discovering novel therapeutic targets and approaches for sleep disturbances occurring in veterans with traumatic brain injury.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Chronic pain is common among Veterans with poly-trauma, traumatic nerve injury, and traumatic limb amputation. While opioids are currently used for chronic pain, they are not very effective and carry serious side effects including the risk of addiction and abuse. We, and others, have discovered that peripheral voltage- gated sodium channels (NaVs) play a central role in human pain disorders, which has led to the pursuit of inhibitors of these channels as treatments that would avert central side effects. Although NaV channel blockers exist, they are of limited utility due to non-specificity and significant CNS effects. The goal of this project is to identify new targets toward the development of more effective treatments for chronic pain through the study of trafficking and polarized distribution of NaV channels within sensory neurons. The outcomes are expected to facilitate development of safer, more effective, and non-addictive treatments for chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Cognitive deficits that occur with aging are a pervasive concern to older individuals and a growing public health issue and maintaining or improving cognition in older adults could have an important effect at the population level, potentially delaying the onset of Alzheimer’s disease and other dementias in millions of older adults. The goals of the proposed research are to first determine the minimal and/or optimal dose of a meditation-inspired digital intervention required for cognitive enhancement, and then to examine the impact of several potential moderators of treatment effects (i.e., cognitive decline, AD polygenic hazard score, cardiovascular risk, and race/ethnicity). This knowledge gained from his high-impact study with transform the field of cognitive interventions, paving the way for a precision medicine model for cognitive enhancing interventions that improve quality of life for older adults and individuals with cognitive deficits at risk of developing dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tuberculosis (TB) is the leading cause of death among people with HIV, with drug-resistant TB threatening decades of progress in TB and HIV control. Dr. Sarita Shah is a physician-scientist at Emory University whose research spans clinical, translational, and public health studies to reduce the burden of TB & HIV globally. This K24 award builds on her long-standing commitment to mentorship in patient-oriented TB & HIV research and will provide vital protected time to 1) expand her mentoring program for physicians and scientists who are pursuing these fields, and 2) enhance her knowledge of epidemiologic and genomic methods to aid in the understanding of drug-resistant TB transmission and prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed, “Strengthening Child Health Research Capacity in Resource Constrained Settings” (referred to as Researcher Resilience Training, RRT) will deliver and test state-of-the-art methods training and “hands-on” research experience to advanced doctoral students and early career investigators, specifically those of African descent, committed to addressing the serious threats to child behavioral health (CBH) as well as prevention and care disparities in poverty-impacted local and global contexts. This short course will prepare RRT Fellows to focus their research on serious overlapping outcomes for youth living in scarce-resource communities: 1) disruptive behavioral difficulties; 2) engagement in early sexual/drug risk behaviors; and 3) early acts of delinquency, including violent behavior. RRT will develop and support a pipeline of new CBH investigators who are prepared to advance scientific knowledge about system and community-level structural interventions that can address the disproportionate health burdens experienced by poverty-impacted youth of African descent via enhancing protective family, neighborhood, system supports; reducing disparities; and advancing racial and health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The Vanderbilt training program in Molecular and Genetic Epidemiology of Cancer is designed to build an elite class of epidemiologists to lead the new era of multidisciplinary collaborative research in cancer. The program, built upon an outstanding research and education training environment; excellent body of researchers and educators; multiple, ongoing, cutting-edge research projects; exceptional data/biospecimen and population resources; and the rich history of interdisciplinary training at Vanderbilt, delivers individualized didactic and research training to equip postdoctoral fellows from a variety of disciplines with the methodological tools, practical laboratory and survey-research knowledge, and hands-on research and grant writing experience necessary to launch independent careers in the molecular and genetic epidemiology of cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While clinical evidence demonstrates a unique “obese asthma” endotype that disproportionately affects women and is associated with poor health outcomes (treatment resistance, increased risk of morbidity/mortality), cellular alterations in the lungs that contribute to worsened lung dysfunction remain poorly understood. This application utilizes a novel model of obese asthma that more accurately mimics the human condition, and suggests that a unique cell population – mucosal associated invariant T (MAIT) cells – plays an important pathogenic role in obese asthma. Defining how MAIT cells influence asthma pathophysiology in obesity will not only spark innovative solutions for the treatment of asthma, but also contribute valuable knowledge to an underexplored cell type in the fields of immunology and metabolism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance to Public Health: Health-related policy is an effective, yet underutilized, strategy for health promotion. To protect the public from melanoma and keratinocyte carcinomas, government bodies have begun to enact legislation to restrict minor access to indoor tanning and minimize harm from indoor tanning devices. In order to contribute to the currently limited evidence base for future policy decision making and sustainability and to accelerate reductions in indoor tanning and sunburn, moving toward an indoor tanning “endgame”, this project will address policy characteristics associated with regulation compliance, cost-benefits of these policies, and barriers and facilitators of policy adoption. !

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Hearing loss and tinnitus are the most common service-related disabilities for veterans. These disabilities span decades, conflicts, geographic location, and job descriptions. For those patients who have hearing loss too severe to benefit from hearing aids, cochlear implants offer a chance to regain some hearing and even understand speech without reading lips. However, current electrode technology cannot approach natural hearing. We propose applying living scaffold technology to the central and peripheral auditory system to create an implantable hearing device that provides more natural hearing than is possible with current technology. Living electrodes will be created by growing spiral ganglion neurons on to constructs designed to be implanted in the cochlea or auditory nuclei in the brainstem. These studies promise to deliver a significant advance in the ability to restore hearing to veterans, and people around the world.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JAMES A. HALEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a leading cause of neurological complications including chronic memory deficits including dementia and tau pathology. Older TBI patients are at a higher risk for worsening of outcomes than their younger counterparts, despite the higher risk and worse outcomes, there are no targeted therapies for this susceptible population. This is compounded by data suggesting that older subjects may show less responsiveness to therapeutic interventions which may indicate that aged individuals will require specialized treatments that differ from young. In that regard, our lab has identified a novel cell free regenerative medicine therapeutic approach for TBI using exosomes (small vesicles secreted from cells) from human adipose derived stem cells, that have a therapeutic window up to at least 2 days after injury. This project will extend this promising finding and optimize this potential therapy for our elderly veterans’ population.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The opioid epidemic has enormous consequences on the health and well-being of Veterans, Veteran families, and Veteran communities. Opioid addiction is propelled by opioid-induced changes in brain circuits that control reward and aversion, and pharmacological or other neuromodulatory therapies that reverse opioid-induced changes are sorely needed. This proposal will systematically identify where and how the actions of opioids act on ventral pallidum and connected brain circuits to cause changes that underlie reward-seeking and punishment-avoidance behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Diet and the microbiome are important risk factors for the development of chronic diseases - cancers, inflammatory bowel diseases, obesity, and type 2 diabetes - and influential modulators of glucuronidation, an essential detoxification pathway. Metabolomics and metagenomics are top-down techniques, which facilitate the identification and quantification of metabolites in complex mixtures (blood, urine, and stool) and the distribution and frequency of microbial genes, respectively. The proposed research aims to integrate high-throughput -omics techniques and traditional molecular assays to define the glucuronidome under normal and disrupted conditions and identify the physiologic effects of shifting glucuronide pools on host inflammation, metabolism, and disease development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research examines the long-term effects of the COVID-19 pandemic on health care delivery, quality and equity for people living with multiple chronic conditions. In a unique national community health center practice “laboratory” caring for more than 2.6 million patients, time-series analyses will reveal the evolution of practice innovations such as telehealth, integrated mental health services, and patient outreach, and will discover their effect on patient care quality and equity. Comparative case studies sampled from the quantitative data will identify and characterize transportable practice innovations to advance equity of care for health disparity populations living with multiple chronic conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sepsis kills 11 million people every year and early identification and treatment are the only known ways to improve mortality. We currently focus on treating people once they get to the hospital or emergency department, which is often too late. This study will evaluate opportunities to identify and triage patients who may be at high-risk of sepsis before they get to the hospital.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: This proposal describes the development and implementation of theranostic PET imaging and radionuclide therapy agents targeting CD46, an exciting new therapeutic target which is highly expressed in multiple myeloma. We will optimize this strategy in preclinical models, developing co-treatment methods to maximize sensitivity. A pilot translational study of the PET imaging agent will be used to detect CD46 expression in patients with multiple myeloma, setting the stage for widespread clinical translation of these techniques.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Mammalian pacemakers located outside of the suprachiasmatic nucleus have not been studied in-depth. The goals of this project are to discover the neural circuitry and functional significance of these under-studied circadian pacemakers. Understanding how these enigmatic circadian pacemakers augment our current model of the circadian system will provide new ways to prevent, diagnose, and treat human disorders that are caused by, or lead to, circadian disruption.

PHR: One of the most significant impediments to the discovery of new medicinal agents is the inability to assemble complex molecules rapidly, efficiently, and with predictable outcomes. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rapid and accurate detection, identification, and characterization of invasive bloodstream infections is one of the most urgent unmet clinical needs today, where timely initiation of the appropriate antimicrobial is one of the key determinants of patient outcome. The current standard of care is too slow, is known to miss certain infections and cannot be used to track progression of the infection. In this program, HelixBind will leverage its RaPID platform and RaPID/BSI to develop the first diagnostic test capable of not only identifying these infections direct from blood, but also assessing the microbial load while monitoring progress towards clearance in response to the antimicrobial intervention. The information provided would enable the clinician to personalize the antimicrobial for optimal outcomes, ensure progress is being made towards recovery, while improving antimicrobial stewardship.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: CLEMENT J. ZABLOCKI VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: This project is of foremost relevance to Veterans and service members that have suffered from a concussion or traumatic brain injury (TBI), but has the potential to help people afflicted with heart disease as well. The heart and the brain do not function properly after TBI. In a healthy heart, there is a normal variation in the timing between beats, even at rest, which is controlled unconsciously by the brain. This variability in heart rate is altered by TBI and is associated with decreased quality of life, increased health care utilization, and premature death. The proposed studies will further our understanding of how TBI changes the brain processes controlling heart rate at rest and in response to stress with the goal of identifying new therapeutic targets or identify new tests (biomarkers) that provide accurate expectations of recovery from a trauma (prognostication), which could transform the way Veterans are evaluated for “return to service.” The long-term objective is to develop treatments that will improve medical outcomes for Veterans with TBI and heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative - Relevance to Public Health Statement:  Currently there are no effective drugs that prevent the death of nerve cells associated with age- dependent neurodegenerative conditions such as Alzheimer's disease. These diseases occur in the context of aging, yet most drug discovery projects use an approach that does not account for aging as a key aspect of the disease pathology. Since old age is the greatest risk factor for Alzheimer's disease, in this proposal we are using a highly innovative approach for drug discovery by identifying Alzheimer's disease drug candidates in screening assays that represent multiple, old age-associated toxicities that have not been explored by the pharmaceutical industry, leading to new drug candidates for old-age associated neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE PASC, or the post-acute sequalae of SARS-CoV-2 infection, will impact the individual health of millions of Americans over the next decade, yet few studies have examined the potential long-term effects of SARS-CoV- 2 on gastrointestinal outcomes (PASC-GI) such as Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS). This research aims to determine the burden the SARS-CoV-2 infection has for both incident and pre-existing IBS and other PASC-GI outcomes. Using a multi-omics approach this study will also investigate the underlying mechanistic pathways critical to ascertain, diagnose, and ultimately treat these disabling PASC-GI conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Corticostriatal circuits are involved in a large number of neurological and neuropsychiatric brain disorders that are also associated with impaired decision making and reduced cognitive flexibility. Impairments to decision making and reduced cognitive flexibility can cause severely debilitating negative impacts on life. An improved understanding of the connection between corticostriatal circuits and these impairments will be useful for developing new mental health treatments and avoiding side effects of treatments targeted to these brain circuits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC), characterized by poor prognostic outcomes, forms solid tumors with high interstitial fluid pressure (IFP) in the tumor microenvironment, where the high IFP compromises cancer immunotherapies by limiting T cell infiltration in the tumors. Given that lymphatic vessels are structurally and functionally impaired in TNBC tumors, which can increase tumor IFP and dampen anti-tumor immunity, this project will decipher the mechanisms of alterations of lymphatic structure and drainage in TNBC and examine new strategies to promote TNBC immunotherapies by normalizing tumor lymphatic function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Pioneer factors are mutated in various tissues and in immune cell pathways, thus underscoring their importance in development and disease. This project will investigate how pioneer factors mediate cellular reprogramming, specifically by probing the mechanism(s) behind their chromatin opening activity and learning how they recognize binding sites within closed chromatin. These studies will shed light on understanding the function of pioneer factor GATA3 in breast cancer cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Minorities with MS face increased disease severity in comparison to whites with MS, possibly due to the differences in the immune responses between the populations, making it important to understand the contribution of the immune response to disease severity in Minorities with MS. We have observed that plasmablasts are expanded in Minorities with MS in comparison to whites with MS. In this project, we will test whether these expanded plasmablasts make antibody that binds to neurons and makes disease worse using a mouse model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed studies seek to understand whether a small number of fetal cells transferred to the mother during pregnancy (fetal microchimerism) is associated with later-life cardiovascular disease (CVD) in women with a history of preeclampsia. In parallel, we will expand the usability of an advanced next-generation sequencing approach for improved microchimerism evaluation. This work will modernize the techniques for microchimerism studies while investigating a possible contributor to CVD in a unique cohort of women with the potential to identify novel diagnostics and therapeutic interventions to limit the burden of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Transcription factor (TF) networks in the heart, lungs and blood (H LB) ensure faithful development and maintenance of cellular homeostasis in these organ systems, with dysregulation of HLB-specific TFs leading to numerous disorders. Due to their central role in biology, methods to study how TFs bind to the genome are well developed, yet we lack a methodological framework for identifying genetic factors that regulate TFs at the protein level. This proposal aims to address this shortcoming by developing a novel framework for the discovery of genes that control HLB-specific TF protein abundances.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Astrocytes provide essential support for synapse development, plasticity, and signaling; yet little is known about the basic cellular and molecular mechanisms that govern this function. This proposal aims to investigate the lysosome as a critical signaling organelle at astrocyte-neuron synapses and define mechanisms of lysosome trafficking in astrocytes. Knowledge from this study will enlighten how astrocyte dysfunction may contribute to synaptic deficiencies in neurodevelopmental and neurodegenerative disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative One of the major ways that diabetes causes death in those it afflicts is by causing heart disease, while the mechanism by which diabetes drives heart disease remains largely unknown. Our recently attained data suggest a central role for gut microbiota. This proposal, which will build on this data, seeks to elucidate understanding of how diabetes causes heart disease and, moreover, develop approaches to prevent it.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Adult neurogenesis takes place in the SVZ of the lateral ventricles and the SGZ of the dentate gyrus in the hippocampus. While TGF-β signaling has been implicated in this process, the precise molecular mechanisms are not well known. This proposal will provide molecular insights for the regulatory role of TGF-β signaling in the addition of adult born neurons during different stages of adult neurogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed longitudinal research will result in the development of 3 models to predict risk of progression in ocular diseases with baseline biomechanical assessment. Progression models will include novel biomechanical parameters associated with asymmetry to predict progression in keratoconus, and scleral stiffness to predict the risk of developing diabetic retinopathy in diabetes. Biomechanical parameters will be added to the Ocular Hypertension Treatment Study risk model to augment prediction of conversion from ocular hypertension to glaucoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurodevelopmental disorders – including epilepsy, intellectual disability, autism spectrum disorder, and schizophrenia – have a significant and chronic impact on the quality of life of up to 1 in 6 children in the United States. Dravet Syndrome is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by treatment-resistant epilepsy, intellectual disability, and autism spectrum disorder, with a known causative genetic mutation and a well- validated clinically-relevant animal model, which allows for studies of disease mechanism and development of new treatments. This proposal uses electrical recording, neuroanatomy, and state of the art imaging techniques in an experimental model system to further our understanding of the pathophysiology of Dravet Syndrome with the goal of generating targets for novel therapies for neurodevelopmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: We will solve poorly defined mechanisms by which bacterial staphylocoagulase and streptokinase hijack the human hemostatic system, with critical involvement of host fibrin(ogen). Human prothrombin and plasminogen form active complexes with these bacterial proteins, and the complexes recognize fibrin(ogen) both as substrates and anchoring points. Knowledge of these mechanisms will allow development of new therapeutic antibodies that may protect patients with a fragile hemostatic system from adverse side effects of infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neuropsychiatric conditions that result from stress exposure, including anxiety and opioid use disorder, are often comorbid, debilitating to patients, and represent one of the highest public health spending burdens. This project is designed to investigate the neural mechanisms responsible for the initiation of anxiety and opioid use following stress by examining discrete stress-sensitive factors within the locus coeruleus to basolateral amygdala circuit. Specifically, by analyzing the contribution of locus coeruleus inflammation on basolateral amygdala norepinephrine activity and subsequent behavioral effects, these experiments will establish novel targets for the treatment of comorbid anxiety and opioid use disorders that result from stress exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Effective smoking cessation treatments that reach the target population of young adults are direly needed and smartphone interventions are a promising strategy. Few of the available smoking cessation apps are based on evidence or deliver intervention content tailored to participant-specific high-risk situations for smoking. The aim of this proposal is to test smartphone-delivered messages for smoking cessation and urge reduction among young adults that target specific high-risk situations for smoking and have the potential to curb smoking in this underserved age group.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE An established hallmark of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is the accumulation of liquid within alveoli that mechanically compromises their inflation and deflation, yet the key impacts on capillary hemodynamics and immune cell activity remain poorly understood. To address this issue, we have created the LungEx system, a novel technology that allows for mechanistic probing of lung respiratory-circulatory mechanics coupled with real- time imaging of lung dynamics at the single alveolar-capillary level. This proposal aims to use LungEx to establish causal links between lung mechanics and the underlying immunovascular dynamics and biology in ARDS-related lung injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project narrative Currently there are no clinically effective treatments to improve outcome after traumatic spinal cord injury (SCI). This proposal will examine the role of novel candidate mediators of secondary tissue damage following SCI. Hence, new therapeutic targets may be identified to enhance functional recovery after SCI.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: A large number of veterans are hospitalized and die from sepsis-induced acute kidney injury every year. Due to its poorly understood pathophysiological mechanisms, no effective therapy has been established to date. The proposed research is highly relevant to the VA's mission because the discovery of pathophysiological mechanisms involved in sepsis-induced kidney injury will lead to the development of rational therapeutic and preventative interventions.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Bipolar disorder (BD) is a common mental illness that affects 1-2% of the world’s population and ~100,000 veterans, causing mood symptoms, social/occupational disability and elevated rates of suicide. BD is associated with disruptions in daily (circadian) rhythms in sleep and activity. Lithium is an inexpensive, effective treatment for BD that protects neurons, and restores circadian rhythms. However, 30-50% of patients with BD fail respond adequately to lithium treatment. Lithium non-responsive patients often experience delays in receiving effective treatment and may require more expensive drugs. Our previous work indicates that circadian rhythm differences may help to identify lithium-responsive BD patients. Using newly-developed cell biology methods, we can now grow neurons from skin cells given by human donors. In this study, we use this approach to investigate circadian rhythm abnormalities in neurons from BD patients, and link circadian rhythm abnormalities with genetic factors previously tied to lithium-responsive BD.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Blast exposure caused by explosions is an exceedingly common event in the Iraq and Afghanistan Wars, and is a major source of trauma, often resulting in mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI). Very frequently, Veterans with mTBI also have comorbid posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD), depression, and/or addiction. While an estimated 400,000 Veterans have a history of blast mTBI, the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood, and treatment options have limited benefits. To fill these gaps, we propose to study a chemical messenger system (the dynorphin/kappa opioid receptor system) that plays a critical role in trauma-induced behavioral problems. We will test two different drugs to inhibit this system, one long-lasting and one short-lasting. We hope to determine mechanisms of chronic mTBI-related behavioral problems and to identify a potentially effective treatment to improve chronic blast mTBI-induced behavior problems related to PTSD, depression, and addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative:  Advanced glycation end products and serum protein infiltration is one of the leading mechanisms that cause structural valve degeneration of bioprosthetic heart valves. The proposed research aims to further elucidate the basis of this mechanism by examining the effects of pretreating bioprosthetic heart valve leaflet material with two model compounds: pyridoxamine, an AGE-inhibitor, and Poly-2-methyl-2-oxazoline, which we have shown to significantly reduce protein infiltration. This work will provide insight into novel strategies to potentially mitigate AGE and serum protein infiltration and enhance biocompatibility, thus circumventing a leading mechanism of SVD that has not been investigated before.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Gene therapy is a promising approach for treating neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer’s disease  (AD).  AD is closely associated with decreased neuronal signaling and loss of synapses. Interventional  strategies intended to remove Ab plaques have failed clinical trials.  Therefore, there is great demand for  neuroprotective strategies to preserve neuronal and cognitive function, independent of targeting Ab., to treat  male and female veterans with AD.  One potential alternative target is caveolin- 1 (Cav- 1), a membrane/lipid  raft (MLR) and scaffolding protein within the neuronal plasma membrane.  When delivered in vivo, neuron-  targeted Cav- 1 over- expression (using a synapsin promoter) increases hippocampal MLR- localized TrkB,  neuronal and synaptic plasticity, and improves memory in aged mice. This Merit application will be a major  advancement to further demonstrate and better understand Cav- 1- mediate neuroprotection and neuroplasticity  in AD mice and human neurons derived from iPSCs from early onset familial AD (EOFAD) patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) rs1421085 has one of the strongest associations with obesity in the entire human genome and is associated with iroquois homeobox protein 3 (IRX3) expression. The proposed research will investigate a brain circuit potentially mediating the association between rs1421085, IRX3, and obesity. This will provide critical knowledge concerning genetic disposition to obesity and aid in the development of therapeutics to reduce or reverse obesity.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Chemicals in the brain called neurotransmitters control virtually every aspect of brain function. Neurotransmitters do this by activating specific proteins, called neurotransmitter receptors. Neurotransmitter receptors allow us to talk, walk, make new memories, and even fall asleep. These same neurotransmitter receptors behave differently after brain injury and contribute to neurologic symptoms including depression and epileptic seizures. Because of the aging population and the current prolonged military conflicts, the number of veterans with epileptic seizures caused by stroke and traumatic brain injury is increasing. Improved understanding of how neurotransmitter receptors are affected in these diseases is vital to develop more effective therapies.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative  Vascular dementia (VaD) is a condition that arises from development of cerebrovascular disease leading to decreased flow to the brain that causes degeneration and inflammation of brain tissue. It is the second most common cause of dementia overall and an important clinical problem among veterans and the general public. To prevent or manage VaD, we need better understanding of its early development, identify factors that exacerbate the condition and develop new ways of treatment. The goal of this proposal is to investigate how the aging blood vessel, characterized by inflammation caused by agents such as medin (a protein that accumulates with aging) as well as cardiovascular risk factors (increased lipid and glucose), could lead to inflammation and degeneration of brain cells and test a novel treatment agent, monosialoganglioside nanoliposome, to protect brain cells against hypoxic injury. The proposal could impact our fundamental understanding of the genesis of VaD and identify new molecular targets and treatment interventions to prevent or control the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Contact PD/PI: LEE, ABRAHAM Acoustic microvortices instrumentation for dosage controlled, high efficiency cell engineering Narrative Nonviral transfection methods are alternatives to viral vectors that avoid the deleterious byproducts such as immune-mediated toxicity and oncogenic transgene concerns. In this application we propose to develop an acoustic-electric shear orbiting poration (AESOP) microfluidic instrument to achieve uniform dosage and high efficiency intracellular delivery of large-size exogenous cargos. We will benchmark AESOP by the technical requirements of engineering primary T cells and chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cells for developing universal CAR T cells for immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Problems with attention, concentration, and cognition are major features of many disorders that are prevalent in US veterans including sleep disorders, traumatic brain injury (TBI) and Alzheimer's disease (AD). We have identified a population of basal forebrain neurons that when stimulated in mice produce cortical activation, alertness, and enhance attention-dependent performance in a reaction time test, and in an associative learning test. The basic research proposed will test the ability of these neurons to rescue the attention and cognitive impairments produced by sleep loss. Veterans, especially those who suffer from TBI and PTSD have a very high incidence of sleep problems, with sleep apnea and chronic insomnia being the most common. Once sleep problems arise, they also exacerbate many of these health conditions. Future work will apply the therapeutic approach investigated here to mouse models of TBI and AD – disorders that are of great importance to US Veterans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) kills almost 90,0000 Americans every year, more than the death rate with cancers of the breast and prostate combined. While more than 20 million U.S. adults suffer from CKD, the rates are higher among Veterans. Moreover, Veterans with CKD also have much higher rates of other diseases such as diabetes, high blood pressure, and heart disease. Some forms of injury to the kidney can be temporary, referred to as acute kidney injury (AKI). However, recent research suggests that even AKI can cause CKD by itself. When AKI occurs in the setting of CKD, it can worsen CKD to complete kidney failure as has been shown in several studies in the Veteran population. CKD itself can impede the recovery from AKI. The specific mechanisms that lead to these poor outcomes are not well known. The main goal of this project is to identify the specific pathways that cause the interactions between AKI and CKD and lead to worsening of kidney disease. The results of these studies could lead to early interventions and medications to improve the health of the Veteran population.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS MED CTR SAN FRANCISCO
PHR: Tolerance to ischemia can be induced by various methods or drugs nowadays to minimize damage to organs that are deprived of blood supply. However, our ability in developing resistance to ischemia declines with age and metabolic diseases. The goal of this project is to determine the molecular mechanisms underlying the failed tolerance to stroke in type 2 diabetes. Data from our research suggest that this failure is closed linked to the modified immune response and chronic inflammation in subjects with type 2 diabetes. This proposed project will characterize these changes in order to find therapy to correct this condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Mitochondria are tiny bacterium-sized organelles, located in essentially every cell of the body, that play a critical and central role in producing approximately almost all of the energy in the body; if something goes wrong with the machinery running this "bioenergetic" factory, cells, and especially those with high energy demands, such as brain, heart, and muscle, begin to "run out of gas," and will eventually die. We have discovered that in cells from patients with defective mitochondrial energy production (i.e. mitochondrial disease), there is a "ripple effect" on the rest of the cell that is mediated by a disruption in the physical connections between mitochondria and endoplasmic reticulum (ER), an organelle that is required for numerous functions, including the distribution of proteins throughout the cell, lipid metabolism, calcium metabolism, and responses to stress. We propose here to study how reduced energy production in mitochondrial disease patients alters ER-mitochondrial connectivity and communication, with the ultimate goal of using this knowledge to "reverse" the connectivity defect as a way to treat these devastating and often fatal disorders.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative Tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) is a genetic disease caused by mutations in either the TSC1 (Hamartin) or TSC2 (Tuberin) gene and affects over two million people world-wide. Over 80% of patients with TSC develop renal disease, in the form of tumors and cysts, which can eventually lead to kidney failure. The factors that promote cyst generation and progression remain unknown. In this application, we report a novel mechanism for cyst formation and expansion which indicates that TSC cysts are driven by the creation of an imbalance in the population of cells lining the cyst. In this model, genotypically normal intercalated cells become the dominant cell type and the targeted principal cells gradually disappear. These results are new paradigms that will greatly advance our understanding of the pathophysiology of TSC renal disease and can be leveraged in the development of new therapeutic approaches for the treatment of this devastating disease.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative  Chronic kidney disease (CKD) affects 26–30 million U.S. adults including Veterans. Renal fibrosis is the inevitable consequence of almost every type of CKD regardless of underlying etiology. Unilateral ureteral obstruction (UUO) is a common and well-validated renal fibrosis experimental model. Big potassium (BK) channel is one of the two major potassium (K) channels responsible for renal K excretion. We have compelling preliminary evidence that shows for the first time that BKα plays a critical role in renal fibrosis. While BKα knockout mice were prone to developing more severe fibrosis after UUO, pre-treatment with the BK channel activator protected mice from developing renal fibrosis in wild-type UUO mice. Elucidation of the molecular mechanisms underlying the BK-mediated development of renal fibrosis will provide novel insights into whether BK channels can be utilized as a potential therapeutic target for treating CKD patients.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS MED CTR SAN FRANCISCO
PHR: Neurodegenerative diseases represent a major challenge in the health care for the civilian and Veterans populations. In particular, there are concerns that exposure to chemicals or injury during combat may increase the propensity of neurodegeneration in Veterans. ALS is a fatal neurodegenerative disease characterized by rapidly progressive loss of motor neurons in brain and spinal cord. By analyzing ALS mouse models and a large number of tissue samples from FALS and SALS patients, we show that misfolded proteins activate a highly conserved protein kinase, called HIPK2, which serves as a molecular switch to promote neuronal cell death, leading to hypothesize that HIPK2 is a feasible therapeutic target for ALS. To test this, we will (1) characterize HIPK2 interacting partner HSPA9 (Mortalin) and their roles in regulating neuronal survival in preclinical models of ALS, and (2) characterize the broader role of HIPK2 in astroglial pathology in ALS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Normal brain function depends on the orderly development of circuits in the cerebral cortex and on their intact function. Knowledge of the normal circuitry provides a foundation for understanding the causes of impaired brain function and developing corrective measures. Our studies of the normal circuitry involving inhibitory neurons in early visual cortical areas will provide greater insight into the causes and effects of central vision defects when these circuits are damaged by stroke or other neurological or developmental cause. Moreover, our studies of inhibitory neuron function will provide a foundation for understanding the consequences of their dysfunction in neurological and psychiatric disorders, such as seizure disorders (Zhang et al., 2009; Halabisky et al., 2010; Peng et al., 2013) and schizophrenia (Hashimoto et al., 2003; Volk et al., 2012), which have been associated with alterations in gene expression, abnormal function or anatomy of distinct types of inhibitory neurons, including PV and SOM neurons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: The goal of the proposed research is to identify the circuit-level mechanisms in the auditory cortex and anterior cingulate cortex that underlie auditory prediction and to test the way these mechanisms contribute to behavioral detection of regularity in sounds and its violation. This is achieved by using a combination of electrophysiological, optogenetic and behavioral approaches in the mouse system. Patients with hearing deficits, age-related hearing loss and communication deficits, exhibit disproportionate difficulty hearing when several sound sources are present. Identifying the function of specific neuronal circuits in the auditory pathway and their relation to predictive coding, which has been implicated in auditory source segregation, is a prerequisite for development of new and improvement of existing therapies for these large groups of patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although supervised exercise is first line therapy for people disabled by lower extremity peripheral artery disease (PAD), 45% of people with PAD do not meaningfully improve after exercise. This clinical trial of supervised exercise in PAD will test the hypothesis that changes in plasma nitrite levels during exercise activity mediate response to exercise and that people who do not respond to exercise fail to increase plasma nitrite levels during walking exercise activity. Results will be used to identify therapeutic targets for future interventions, to improve walking performance in people disabled by PAD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE About 1 in 20 individuals in the world could be affected by a rare disease. A good care starts with a good diagnostics. Unfortunately, people from Low and Middle-Income Countries (LMICs) do not have access to good diagnostics. The situation of rare diseases in those countries is globally unknown. Genomic medicine consists in using genomic information to make health decisions. The fact that little is known from some parts of the world prevents those parts of the world from having access to good genomic medicine. By helping rare diseases patients in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), we will also help patients in other regions of the world as well. The DRC is a genomically rich country, where experienced clinical geneticists trained oversee are now available and mobile internet has become available. We are a group of Congolese researchers who have come together to build a network that will generate good quality information and will improve the diagnosis in Congolese rare diseases patients, while also helping non-African patients across the world. We will also develop a model and tools applicable to other LMICs willing to embrace genomic medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Beta cell dysfunction and death are significant pathologies underlying the development of Type 2 diabetes. The goal of this application is to understand the acute and long-term effects of SARS-CoV2 infection on beta cell survival, metabolism, and function. These experiments will provide critical molecular mechanistic insight into the reported post-acute sequelae of hyperglycemia, diabetic ketoacidosis, and potentially lifelong diabetes that may afflict a significant number of patients who have recovered from COVID19.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative Diseases of the dopamine system such as substance use disorder, schizophrenia, Parkinson's disease, and other movement disorders including chorea and dystonia, have a tremendous personal and societal cost. The causes of the diseases are often unknown, but dopamine D2 receptors have been implicated in the pathophysiology or treatment of each of them. This work is expected to identify novel mechanisms by which dopamine D2 receptor mutations cause extrapyramidal motor system dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Microbiome research is expanding horizons across the cancer research continuum, and we are currently developing an understanding of how our microbiota may impact carcinogenesis, how microbiota may impact the efficacy of cancer treatment, how cancer treatment may impact the microbiota, and associations between the microbiome and cancer prognosis. Our team proposes to advance cancer microbiome research by improving access to cancer microbiome bioinformatics methods and data, developing a microbiome multi- omics bioinformatics platform driven by the needs of the cancer research community, and ensuring reproducibility of microbiome bioinformatics methods. This will be achieved in the context of the popular QIIME 2 microbiome bioinformatics platform and the Qiita public microbiome data repository and pooled analysis system, in collaboration with ITCR and NCI Cloud Resources project teams.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Smoking is a leading cause of premature death, causing more than half of all cancer deaths. However, tobacco treatment is often not provided and not highly effective in primary care. New evidence suggests that a precision treatment approach to motivate and guide treatment based on personal genetic and metabolic markers could improve treatment uptake and quit success. This study will test the impact of a multilevel precision treatment intervention on improving tobacco treatment and health outcomes in primary care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  The present collaborative studies will evaluate and optimize a novel prodrug-based delivery strategy for tumor-specific pharmacotherapy of neuroendocrine cancers. We will focus on the prodrug design as a tool for achieving high selectivity and potency of the anticancer therapy, while protecting normal tissues from exposure to toxic drug levels. The results of this project will facilitate the development, translation and clinical implementation of prodrugs targeted to tissue-specific cell uptake mechanisms as delivery systems for treating high-risk neuroblastoma and other aggressive solid tumors currently lacking effective treatment options.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A fundamental question in evolutionary biology is how the genetic basis of adaptation changes depending on the rate of environmental change. This study proposes to examine patterns of mutation fixation and mutational effects in viral populations that experienced a sudden or gradual increase in temperature, and to compare these patterns to expectations from existing theoretical models. The work is important for refining the theoretical models, and for identifying selective pressures and constraints that could be used to predict or control future viral evolution.
