IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: While the development of many new neural recording technologies has led to much excitement, it has created a huge gap between our ability to collect data and our ability to deeply understand it. More interpretable machine learning tools are necessary for understanding neural function in health and neurological disease, to one day develop curative interventions. The goal of this research is to develop interpretable machine learning models and apply them to understand how brain areas interact with each other and how they control muscle activity during a wide range of movements.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Children with mild bilateral hearing loss (MBHL) do not receive hearing aids as often as peers with greater degrees of hearing loss due to a lack of clinical tools to assess their listening difficulties. This research proposal would address this critical need by developing clinical novel clinical assessment and outcome measures for children with MBHL. The result will be improved communication, academic, and social outcomes for this underserved population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inflammation precedes neurodegeneration in glaucoma and may continue to drive it even in the presence of adequate pressure control yet no treatments exist to protect the retina from pressure-induced inflammation. To overcome this challenge, we propose to identify the glial mechanotransducers, define their role in the inflammation and neurodegeneration and mitigate their pathological roles through selective gene ablation. This work is hoped to pave the way for targeted interventions based on early diagnosis and treatment of pressure induced pathologies within the retina.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal will develop methods to quantify the interaction of radiation with the immune system, particularly the blood (i.e., circulating lymphocytes). We envision that future treatment planning in radiation oncology will treat lymphatic nodes and the blood as organs at risk and include them in the treatment optimization process so as to influence the level at which the radiation treatment impacts the immune system of the patient. Clinical trials can be properly designed only if the dose to circulating lymphocytes can be accurately quantified. Our tools will ultimately allow this for both pre-clinical and clinical research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although Alzheimer’s disease and Alzheimer’s disease-related dementias (AD/ADRD) affect a large and growing number of Americans, the social determinants of AD/ADRD are not well understood. The proposed research leverages data from the Health and Retirement Study, a nationally representative panel survey of older U.S. adults, to investigate the consequences of patterns and trends in education for sex/gender disparities in AD/ADRD. Results will clarify whether gender inequality in education contributes to women’s greater burden of AD/ADRD, with significant implications for social, economic, and health policy and practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While the resident microbiota has been extensively characterized in many parts of the human body, such as the gut, the ocular surface microbiome is relatively understudied. This is in part due to the unique challenges of characterizing a broad range of organisms in specimens that have low microbial biomass, such as those collected from the ocular surface. Here, we describe the systematic optimization of sample processing methods, validation of computational tools, and longitudinal characterization of the composition and viability of organisms comprising the healthy ocular surface microbiome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this research is to better understand the efferent auditory system’s role in speech-in-noise perception by: 1) improving methods used to study it and 2) evaluating its function in normal-hearing adults with and without speech-in-noise deficits. The outcomes of this research can be used to: 1) create clinical assessments and targeted treatments for individuals with severe difficulties understanding speech-in-noise and 2) create biologically-inspired noise reduction algorithms for hearing aids and cochlear implants that are based on neural processing strategies in the normal auditory system.

We will provide novel insight into the fundamental principles that link chromosome structure to genetic activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This work will bolster our understanding of epicardial-myocardial signaling and the role of the extracellular matrix in modulating cell behavior in the developing heart. The clinical relevance of this work lies in the application of epicardial cells to enhance the pump function of a perfusable, chambered, human cardiac tissue model that will be ideal to study the impact of cardiac disease and therapeutics on pressure-volume dynamics, stroke work, and ejection fraction. In the future, this living, human muscle pump generated in a dish might be used to restore cardiac function in patients with heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Opioid use disorder causes persistent epigenomic changes in brain reward regions that contribute to drug seeking behavior, but we currently do not have a way to access these epigenomically altered cells selectively. The proposed work develops a novel viral approach that leverages the unique epigenomic environment in animal models of opioid use disorder to gain selective access to and control of the cells that drive drug seeking behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The cones in the fovea face extremely high photon fluxes throughout our lives and it is not clear how they escape a complete depletion of the visual pigments in bright sun light. The experiments in this proposal will elucidate the contribution of recently discovered pigment regeneration pathways in the mouse neural retina to dark adaptation and maintenance of light sensitivity in the human macular cones. A long-term goal of these studies is to generate new knowledge about the function of the photoreceptors and their interactions with Müller glia and retinal pigment epithelium in the human macula in healthy eyes as well those affected by macular dystrophies such as Age- Related Macular Degeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE The proposed research will be focused on technology development for ultra-high sensitivity deep proteomic analysis of limited biological and clinical samples. Comprehensive proteome characterization of such samples at the level of digests, intact proteoforms, native non-covalent protein complexes, and protein interactions is presently an insurmountable challenge in bioanalytical research. The proposed technology offers an unprecedented opportunity for expanding our knowledge of molecular mechanisms of disease processes and identifying new paths toward the discovery of diagnostic and prognostic biomarkers using minuscule sample amounts. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: RELEVANCE (See instructions): Integration of different sensory modalities is a common cognitive capability and a foundation of  communication processes. Inability to properly process simultaneous channels of sensory inputs may lead  to symptoms expressed by patients of autism disorder spectrum (ASD). Better understanding of the  mechanisms and brain dynamics underlying multisensory integration will facilitate understanding  communication processes in healthy subjects as well as the underpinnings of communication disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Syphilis is a bacterial infection that can lead to devastating birth outcomes in pregnant women. The Syphilis in Pregnancy Study (SIPS) was designed to improve syphilis diagnostic testing in women and infants so fewer infections are missed. The study will also measure the immune response to syphilis in women and infants before and after penicillin treatment to identify markers of protection to help guide future vaccine studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The research program is relevant to public health because its overarching aim is to determine the developmental impact of mild to severe hearing loss on reading comprehension. More specifically, we will study how individual differences in early auditory access and oral language skills are associated with variability in growth trajectories for reading comprehension. This research program fulfills the mission of the NIH to improve health through research because it will provide evidence on the effect of auditory-linguistic experience on reading development and provide empirical support for clinical recommendations for intervention for children with permanent hearing loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Adolescents impacted by household incarceration and associated stressors are at increased risk for compromised school and mental and behavioral health outcomes. SHARE evaluates a primary prevention program for youth that embeds SEL competencies in novel artistic self- expression and community engagement activities to strengthen protective factors known to promote healthy adolescent development and resilience. SHARE will advance scientific understanding of adolescent risk and resilience processes and expand the evidence-base of effective prevention programming for vulnerable youth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Some patients who undergo interhospital transfer who do not experience a time sensitive emergency, such as trauma or heart attack, experience worse outcomes—particularly for rural patients who experience the highest levels of mortality and are the most likely to be transferred. Identifying the factors that contribute to worse outcomes is challenging due to a lack of integrated datasets that contain all of the data necessary to conduct in-depth analyses to identify which factors contribute to poorer outcomes. Our study will create a comprehensive data management platform that will use geographic information systems and other spatial analytics to combine patient electronic health record data, medical transport data, social determinants of health data, and other location data to identify significant factors that contribute to the transfer of rural patients and their associated clinical outcomes.

PHR: Project Narrative Although it has previously been established that there is a lack of racial and ethnic diversity in the oncology physician workforce, the impact of this lack of diversity on cancer care and outcomes for patients with cancer remains unknown. IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Most US service members are within the late adolescent period (18 –25 years-old), which is characterized by the immaturity of the prefrontal cortex. We propose to develop an animal model that can be used to test whether alcohol abuse during late adolescence can increase the vulnerability of US Veterans to a wide range of neurological and mental health conditions. Development and characterization of this model will put us in a position to test new mechanisms and interventions to ameliorate conditions observed in our Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: RELEVANCE (See instructions): Deterioration and loss of hearing has a major negative impact on quality of life for millions of Americans. Learning induced circuit changes interact with hearing loss at multiple levels from  learning induced changes ameliorating perception despite hearing loss through the effect of hearing loss in  children during times of substantial learning plasticity, to learning following use of devices such as cochlear  implants. Understanding how learning affects auditory representations is crucial in treating hearing loss and  ameliorating quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Overall Program Narrative This Center is focused on developing better, faster, more informative research tools and computational models that aid during response to and recovery from environmental emergencies. Climate change, human economic activity, and long-standing socioeconomic disparities together increase vulnerability to disasters that may involve exposure to hazardous chemicals. We bring together a team of scientists from biomedical, geosciences, data science and engineering disciplines to propose solutions for characterization and management of both existing and environmental emergency-created hazardous waste sites in both coastal and in-land regions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project 1 Narrative Measurements of hazardous substances in environmental samples have traditionally focused on a small subset of target compounds largely selected from toxicology studies. However, these small targeted studies create a huge gap in our understanding of the entire potential exposures, because thousands of new chemicals are introduced into commerce each year. In this proposal, we will employ untargeted analyses combining ion mobility spectrometry (IMS) structural assessments, mass spectrometry (MS) m/z measurements and computational capabilities for the comprehensive assessment of novel chemical features detected in complex environmental samples obtained before, during and after environmental emergencies. The untargeted measurements will then be used to populate new targeted list with thousands of hazardous substances of potential interest for their rapid characterization and quantitation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project 2 Narrative Children living near Superfund sites are at high risk for inhalation exposures to hazardous volatile organic compounds (VOCs), especially following environmental disasters. Since mechanisms underlying the role of VOCs in asthma pathogenesis are poorly understood, this project will develop an age-appropriate, population- based in vitro pediatric airway model to rapidly characterize respiratory risks and determine the role of extracellular vesicles in response to VOC exposure. Using a state-of-the-art mobile air sampling approach, we will also characterize ambient VOC mixtures in high-risk communities to support real-world toxicity testing and disaster research response.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) affects more than 35 million Americans and can progress to complete kidney failure, a condition in which patients must undergo kidney dialysis or transplantation for survival. Veterans are more likely to have CKD compared to the general population, and the prevalence of CKD among veterans is rising. When CKD is accompanied by the abnormal excretion of proteins in the urine (known as proteinuria or albuminuria), the risk of developing complete kidney failure is greatly increased. Treatments for this type of CKD are extremely limited and are intended to slow disease progression rather than cure the disease. This application tests the specific effects of a major cellular pathway (Nrf2) on proteinuric CKD in order to develop more effective treatments for this disease in the veteran population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project 3 NARRATIVE Exposures to environmental hazardous substances, including those that may be released in the event of natural and anthropogenic disasters, are known to impact pregnancy, leading to adverse pregnancy outcomes like preterm birth. Here, we propose to address our central hypothesis that a tissue chip model mimicking the complex multi-cellular feto-maternal interface can be used to evaluate the mechanistic pathophysiologic pathways related to preterm birth that may be perturbed by complex mixtures of environmental hazardous substances. We will also develop and utilize a higher throughput tissue chip model that can rapidly assess the potential hazard of environmental samples that may lead to preterm birth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glaucoma remains the second leading cause of blindness worldwide. We will investigate a three-pronged strategy to reduce intraocular pressure by reducing aqueous humor production and promoting outflow promotion through the trabecular meshwork and uveoscleral pathways. The new formulation based on this novel therapeutic intervention will be clinically impactful for improving glaucoma treatment and patient adherence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project 4 NARRATIVE Project 4 will determine what cell-based human model systems best predict potential toxicity, including the extent of inter-individual and inter-tissue variability, in people who may be exposed to hazardous substances as a result of a disaster. We will also create a framework for testing mixtures of chemicals for toxicity in these cell-based systems and for how best to understand at what dose these mixtures may be harmful. The outcome of this project will be a set of experimental tools and computational models that can be used rapidly during/after natural or man-made disasters.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Elevated plasma triglyceride levels are associated with an increased risk for atherosclerotic heart disease, and severe forms of hypertriglyceridemia often lead to life-threatning pancreatitis. We will pursue discoveries on basic mechanisms for triglyceride metabolism with advanced biochemical and imaging techniques (including NanoSIMS imaging); simultaneously, we will pursue our discovery of a new human metabolic disease syndrome (chylomicronemia from GPIHBP1 autoantibodies) and test whether plasma GPIHBP1 levels are a useful biomarker for metabolic or vascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project 5 NARRATIVE This project is developing broad-activing sorbent materials that can be used to minimize exposures to hazardous chamicals during and after environmental and man-made disasters. The outcomes of this project will be of direct use by first responders, frontline personnel, vulnerable community members, and others exposed to hazardous chemical substances during disasters and emergencies. Ultimately, the strategy of using multicomponent sorbents and novel barrier formulations will effectively decrease chemical exposures through ingestion, dermal contact and inhalation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Administrative & Research Translation Core NARRATIVE The Administrative & Research Translation Core is providing leadership and guidance to the Texas A&M University Superfund Research Center. It provides general Center malmanagement support, promotes cross- discipline interactions among all projects and cores, and facilitates research translation. The Core operates through regular Center-wide and project-specific meetings, tracks the productivity of the Center, develops future activities, and guides scientific innovation through a pilot project program. The Core also coordinates the Center’s disaster research response (DR2) activities, training, community engagement and outreach with input from two advisory committees.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Community Engagement Core NARRATIVE The residents of communities located along the Galveston Bay/Houston Ship Channel (GB/HSC) region have excess risk of exposure to acute pollution, emergency chemical spills and incidents, and high-impact natural disasters, such as hurricanes and flooding. Community engagement provides a link between the adaptive capacities of a community—the human, fiscal, political, and social resources that enable proactive behavior— and its responses and changes after disruptions, including natural disasters and environmental contamination events. An engaged community has greater resilience and is better able to anticipate future threats and prepare for and recover from adverse events.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diseases of the respiratory system and of critical illness constitute major public health problem in the US and worldwide. The objective of this Program is to prepare young scientists to pursue research careers addressing mechanisms and treatment of human disease, with a focus on respiratory disease and critical illness. We expect that trainees from this Program will identify disease mechanisms and develop and implement new effective treatments that will improve human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Research Experience and Training Coordination Core (RETCC) NARRATIVE The Center brings together a team of scientists from biomedical, geosciences, data science, and engineering disciplines to design comprehensive solutions for complex exposure- and health hazard-related risk assessment and reduction challenges. Given the diversity of the disciplines involved, the excellence of the investigators, and the tight integration of the fundamental and applied research, the Center will form an outstanding training environment for graduate students and postdoctoral fellows and will create ample opportunities for integration and professional development of our trainees. The Research and Experience Training Coordination Core promotes interdisciplinary learning via collaborative projects across multiple Projects/Cores; augments trainees’ existing graduate and postdoctoral programs with targeted skill-building workshops; provides opportunities for interactions with diverse audiences (scientific and layperson); and tracks and evaluates trainee development and success.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Home health is an ideal post-acute setting for people living with Alzheimer's Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD), yet, people with ADRD experience barriers to accessing needed health care services. Unprecedented changes in home health in 2020 due to pandemic disruption and implementation of a new reimbursement model pose a significant threat to home health access and quality for people with ADRD. This study examines the impact of these changes on home health access and quality of care for people with ADRD and will inform advocacy efforts, current home health practice, and future post-acute care health policy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Data Management and Analysis Core (DMAC) NARRATIVE The Data Management and Analysis Core of the Texas A&M Superfund Research Center serves as a hub for translating the raw experimental data produced by the Research Projects into useful knowledge to the community via data collection, integration, quality control, analysis, and model generation. The Core utilizes state-of-the-art methods in data science, optimization and machine learning, develops and applies novel dimensionality reduction techniques, and establishes a common data management and computational platform for collaboration within the Center and data dissemination to the Center stakeholders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Transcription, a process by which RNA polymerase (RNAP) converts the information stored in the DNA (or RNA) into an RNA message, is critical to the survival of all organisms. The speed with which RNAP makes RNA determines the three-dimensional shape into which RNA folds and consequently whether or not the RNA product can be used for downstream gene expression processes; however, our understanding of the interplay between RNAP kinetics and co-transcriptional RNA folding is lacking. In the proposed project, we will develop novel tools for capturing structural snapshots of RNA folding intermediates and apply them to study RNA folding and function in bacteria and human mitochondria, with ultimate insights into the underlying causes of mitochondrial diseases and applications in engineering microbes for synthetic biology, diagnostic, and therapeutic applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Risk and Geospatial Sciences Core (RGSC) NARRATIVE The Risk and Geospatial Sciences Core will support the Center in synthesizing, mapping, and visualizing relevant scientific data and conclusions for use by those involved in decisions related to risk management. These services will support the Center’s overall goal by helping to interpret and translate research project findings into information that can be used by varied stakeholders, from communities to federal and state decision-makers, to assess the human health impact of contaminant exposures after an environmental emergency, and enhance the planning, emergency response, as well as long-term recovery and remediation efforts related to environmental disasters.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Disaster Research Response (DR2) Core NARRATIVE The Texas A&M University Superfund Research Center is engaged in a number of disaster research response (DR2) activities and deployed personnel to a number of disasters to collect samples and respond to concerns from community partners, non-governmental organizations, and local and state agencies. Activities included sampling of water, sediment, and soils in response to Hurricane Harvey (2017), Hurricane Florence (2018), and the large-scale industrial fire at the Intercontinental Terminals Company (ITC) facility (2019). Therefore, this new DR2 Core will support the Center, and the rigor and reproducibility of its DR2 activities, by ensuring the Center’s ability to respond to disasters through creation of a centralized resource to support DR2 infrastructure, methods, supplies, and training.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While immune checkpoint inhibitors targeting the PD-1/PD-L1 axis have shown unprecedented and durable clinical responses in a variety cancers, resistance to therapy remains a problem for the majority of patients. This project seeks to understand the fundamental mechanisms linking cancer cell mutations that confer resistance to immunotherapy with immunosuppressive myeloid cells infiltrating these tumors. This work will define a new paradigm of personalized immunotherapy to tailor treatment to an individual patient based on their tumor’s mutations and infiltrating myeloid cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pleiotropy (the phenomenon where a genetic region or locus confers risk to two or more traits) is widely observed among complex human traits and diseases, including seemingly unrelated traits. While the scientific significance of studying pleiotropy is well-understood, statistical methods for identifying variant-level shared genetic basis of traits in genome-wide association studies (GWAS) are still lacking, especially for family-based studies and studies with partial/complete sample overlap. In this R21 application, we propose to develop novel, powerful and genome-wide scalable methods, along with open-source, user-friendly software, to statistically investigate questions of pleiotropy between complex diseases/traits with or without sample overlap and across the entire allele frequency spectrum using existing aggregate-level genotype-phenotype association results (or GWAS summary statistics) under both population- and family-based study designs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Therapeutic irradiation is commonly used to treat both primary and metastatic brain tumors and can cause a number of late effects including progressive cognitive dysfunction. There is no treatment currently available that can even partially reverse cognitive changes observed after radiation injury and our data demonstrates. Our proposed studies will identify immune related factors as potentially critical contributors to the susceptibility of the radiation-induced loss of cognitive function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project narrative This proposal expands upon extensive preliminary data to achieve a comprehensive assessment of brain somatic mosaicism, in healthy and diseased brain. This genetic variation may play a role in normal development and may shape individual susceptibility and resilience to neuropsychiatric disorders. We will provide the first comprehensive estimate of the number and frequency of genomic variation in cells of the human brain and will test hypotheses about mechanisms responsible for their creation as well as their significance for brain development.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Essential tremor is a common neurological disorder that is often disabling, interfering with daily tasks, and forcing early retirement. Many Veterans with tremor also have anxiety and depression. Current therapies are unsatisfactory. Our initial goals are to confirm our findings that cannabidiol suppresses tremor in the harmaline mouse model of essential tremor, and that a specific enzyme inhibitor that raises the brain level of a natural endocannabinoid also suppresses tremor. Our pilot data indicate that these agents work by activating a specific serotonin receptor subtype. We will seek to confirm out pilot findings that drugs that selectively activate these serotonin receptors suppress tremor and, also study how well they are tolerated and whether their effectiveness wears off. This work will facilitate the development of new therapies for disabling tremor in Veterans that are expected to be potent yet well tolerated. Moreover, based on published data, these treatments are expected to be effective for co-morbid depression and anxiety.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Liver cancer, also known as hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), is the fastest growing cause of cancer-related deaths among Americans. HCC occurs in people with liver disease, and fatty liver disease related to metabolic dysfunction (e.g., diabetes, obesity), also called MAFLD, has become the most common liver disease in the world. Our research aims address important gaps in our understanding of how to prevent HCC among people with MAFLD by investigating the role of chemoprevention, surveillance, and risk scores in 3 highly synergistic scientific projects that are supported by 2 shared cores for data and samples collection and analysis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Two of the more serious clinical syndromes that afflict newborn children are severe neonatal hyperbilirubinemia (SNH), which can develop both in preterm and term newborns and lead to severe CNS toxicity, and necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC), which is mainly restricted to preterm newborns. We will argue and present new findings that the development of SNH and the events leading to protection against NEC are regulated through similar mechanisms, leading us to suggest that the onset of SNH, which displays potent antioxidant properties, is not a random event in preterm newborns but may have evolved as a protective event to combat inflammatory diseases. Using novel animal models that express the human UGT1 locus and the UGT1A1 gene and develop SNH during the neonatal period, experiments are outlined to examine the interrelationships in the mechanisms that control the onset of SNH and NEC with the intention of exploiting these findings to identify potential therapeutic targets to treat NEC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Primary liver cancer also known as Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is the fastest growing cause of cancer- related deaths in the United States. This research aims to fill gaps in our understanding of the pros and cons of two HCC prevention strategies -- surveillance and chemoprevention -- in individuals with metabolic dysfunction (e.g., diabetes, obesity) associated HCC. We propose to develop the first publicly available on-line tool, HCC Simulator, for providers and their patients that will give real-time information (including graphic report print- outs) on the risk of developing HCC and effective prevention plan, all based on individual patient’s risk factors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROGRAM NARRATIVE Health services research indicates those with dementia utilize healthcare differently than controls, and initial studies suggest mild cognitive impairment may also be related to altered patterns of healthcare utilization. Better understanding use of health services in older adults across the spectrum of cognitive impairment is essential to: (i) future resource planning and allocation, (ii) development of cost management strategie s; and (iii) identification of areas where healthcare patterns might eventually be improved, especially in early disease, when changes may be easier to implement. We propose to examine differences in healthcare utilization, in use of dementia drugs, and in end-of-life care, across those with no cognitive impairment, mild cognitive impairment, and dementia, using a unique linkage of Medicare claims data with rigorous cognitive data from several cohorts of cognitive aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Vestibular migraine (VM) is among the leading causes of dizziness and spatial disorientation with an unknown pathophysiology. Here we apply a rigorous framework to (i) determine sensory contributions to spatial disorientation in VM patients, (ii) find the link between these measures and clinical sign and symptoms in VM patients, and 3) examine the role of neural networks that contribute to spatial disori- entation in VM pathophysiology. These are crucial steps towards devising effective treatment strategies for the debilitating symptoms in VM patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of our Program Project is to conduct several research studies to better understand and reduce the risk of developing the most common type of liver cancer, hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), among individuals with metabolic dysfunction (e.g., diabetes, obesity). The proposed studies require rigorous implementation of well-designed protocols for patient enrollment and biospecimen and data collection, optimal and complete follow-up of patients with cirrhosis to determine if they develop HCC, and rigorous statistical analyses. Our proposed Data and Analysis Core will provide expertise and support in data management, coordination, statistics and information technology that are crucial for the success of all projects and the overall Program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pediatric pulmonary hypertension is a life-threatening disease of the lung vasculature that can result in right heart failure and death, but the population of survivors is increasing due to pharmacologic advances. Survivors report low quality of life related to symptoms of exercise intolerance, and adult literature supports exercise training as an adjunct to pharmacologic therapy. The proposed training program and research studies aim to increase understanding of barriers to exercise in pediatric pulmonary hypertension survivors in order to pilot a home-based exercise program which may lead to new therapeutic approaches and improved quality of life.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative NeoChip combines real-time PCR, digital High Resolution Melting (dHRM) of DNA and RNA, and machine learning to create unique “fingerprints" for microbes and antimicrobial resistance, allowing for faster and more precise detection of pathogen(s) causing neonatal infection. This project will build out NeoChip’s melt curve database to include clinically relevant strains of cytomegalovirus and herpes simplex virus infections, while concordantly assembling updated epidemiologic timelines and prevalence of perinatal CMV and HSV transmission. Our goals are to validate NeoChip for the rapid and specific diagnosis of congenital CMV and neonatal HSV infection on multiple tissue matrices and translate the NeoChip platform for incorporation into standard universal newborn screening for the diagnosis of congenital cytomegalovirus on dried blood spot samples.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Brain microstructure changes occur during adolescent development, and the trajectory of these changes can be affected by the onset of mental disorders such as bipolar disorder. Understanding the neurobiology of this process requires longitudinal diffusion MRI datasets and diffusion models that have the specificity to distinguish between the different types of changes that occur during adolescent development. In this project, we will develop an open source software framework for analyzing developmental trajectories of brain microstructure based on advanced diffusion models applied to longitudinal datasets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The transition to adult HIV care is often accompanied by reduced medication adherence, retention in treatment, and HIV viral load suppression; however, little is known about which interventions might be most effective in supporting adolescents undergoing this care transition. We will estimate the short- and long-term efficacy of a community-based differentiated care intervention to support adolescents during their transition to adult HIV care; estimate the cost and cost-effectiveness in terms of cost per additional successful transition achieved; and provide data on implementation considerations essential for uptake, sustainability, and successful adoption by the public sector.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nutritional behaviors and eating habits are affected gradually in Alzheimer’s disease making it hard to identify abnormal behaviors in the early stages. This research and training program will apply a novel strategy using a digital research system in real-world homes to characterize dietary behavior in healthy older adults, mild cognitive impairment and early Alzheimer’s disease. Once such strategies have been developed, they can be used to identify early changes in health, cognitive function and activity that could be predictive of memory loss and dementia, and provide an initial step towards the long-term goal of finding effective prevention and treatment strategies for Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Moderate or severe traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a substantial health problem that in addition to often-devastating acute effects, can trigger chronic and evolving neuropathologies that may underlie long-term functional decline. Here we propose to further understanding of how TBI can induce chronic and progressive degeneration of the brain's white matter. We will achieve this by examining human tissue samples in parallel with translational models of TBI to explore degeneration, including at the individual cell level and across brain networks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Ozone is a ubiquitous urban air pollutant that causes significant adverse health effects in healthy and susceptible individuals, including children and the elderly. Our studies are focused on elucidating inflammatory mechanisms contributing to ozone toxicity in humans and experimental animals. This is key to development of new strategies to reduce lung injury and disease arising from exposure to ozone, as well as other agents that cause inflammatory lung damage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Narrative Most cancer types are not responsive to checkpoint blockade immunotherapy and the majority of patients with cancers known to be responsive do not benefit from it. This research proposal will use state-of the-art technologies of imaging, world-renowned expertise in cancer vaccine design and production, single cell RNA sequencing, immunoprofiling, and multiplex immunofluorescence to show that by harnessing the lymphatics, immune responses can be personalized. The implications for this research extend beyond cancer to autoimmune and infectious diseases that benefit by immunomodulatory interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Determination of chromatin protein dynamics in CD8 T cells  CD8 T cells are driven by T cell antigen receptor (TCR) and co-receptor signaling via transcriptional regulation of gene expression to confer antiviral and antitumor immune response. Here we propose to unbiasedly determine the protein factors dynamically associated with active gene enhancers and promoters in CD8 T cells upon TCR and co-receptor stimulation, potentially leading to the identification of novel modulators of CD8 T cell antitumor activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We do not know enough about how efficiently the spike proteins from diverse SARS-like beta coronaviruses need to bind with the ACE2 host cell receptor proteins encoded by different animals to successfully jump across host species and spark pandemic zoonotic spillovers. Using cutting-edge synthetic biology paired with multiplex infection assays, we will perform a series of large-scale genetic studies to reveal how differences in ACE2 protein sequence and cell surface expression levels interact with coronavirus spike protein sequences from various bat coronaviruses to understand how often each virus infects those cells. This molecular and genetic information will reveal which animals can serve as hidden reservoirs for potentially zoonotic SARS-like coronaviruses deserving heightened surveillance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE “Understanding cancer and comorbidities among American Indian and Alaska Native people” is a two-year study which will use SEER-Medicare data to provide foundational data on the prevalence of comorbidities among AIAN people with cancer, and the impact that those comorbidities have on receipt of timely and guideline-concordant cancer care, and cancer survival. An exploratory aim will use Indian Health Service data to replicate analyses in a more geographically and demographically representative population, and determine whether IHS data are feasible to support population-based health services research to understand cancer care delivery among AIAN people. These data will provide critical information to understand causes of AIAN cancer disparities that can be used to drive future healthcare-based structural and programmatic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to demonstrate the effects of craniofacial reconstruction using an advanced biomaterial that has shown great promise in treating voice and speech disorders. Defining the long-term three-dimensional conformation changes and implant microenvironment of biomaterials within the posterior pharyngeal wall will help demonstrate the feasibility and durability of this approach in a preclinical model. This preliminary study will have broad implications for a potential clinical use in reconstructing the velopharyngeal mechanism. Achieving these goals will allow for additional preclinical modeling and development of precision medicine use cases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project is expected to determine the role of neuroendocrine dysfunction in primary hypertension, a dangerous clinical condition that afflicts 75 million people in the United States and may lead to stroke, heart disease, and renal failure. The proposed studies will greatly improve the understanding of the cellular and molecular mechanisms of the most common form of hypertension, primary hypertension, and should provide important information for developing new treatments to reduce high blood pressure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative A United States Preventive Services Task Force recommendation suggests that pregnant people at risk for depression be proactively engaged in behavioral health services. We will build an interpretable and acceptable algorithm for perinatal risk prediction that also addresses inequities in diagnosis and care provision. We will test the feasibility and acceptability of a scalable digital cognitive behavioral therapy tool for a diverse group of pregnant people identified as at risk for depression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Lyme borreliosis, caused by the spirochete Borrelia burgdorferi, remains the most common vector-borne disease in the United States with an estimated 300,000 cases each year. The proposed research will address how the bacterium secretes surface lipoproteins and generates its interface with the host. This may lead to the identification of new targets for prevention or treatment.

PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator (Iñiguez, Sergio, Diaz): NARRATIVE Affective disorders are highly prevalent in the juvenile population. The dearth of preclinical models designed to evaluate the neurobiology of depression, in vulnerable populations specifically, limits our ability to uncover its pathophysiology. Thus, the goal of this proposal is to validate the vicarious defeat stress model for the examination of stress-induced illnesses in understudied populations, specifically adolescents and females. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The rising incidence in colorectal cancer (CRC) diagnosed under age 50 has resulted in updated guidelines from the American Cancer Society (ACS) advising average-risk screening begin at age 45, rather than 50. However, the etiology of early-onset CRC and contributors for this rise remain unclear. Our investigations into the role of mid-adulthood and early-life obesity, sedentary behaviors, and poor diet associated with risk of early-onset advanced adenoma as well as biomarker discoveries of both early-onset advanced adenoma/CRC will advance the understanding of the etiology of early-onset CRC and shed light on prevention. Our estimation of the explained portion of the rising incidence as well as the improvement of the simulations used to support the 2018 ACS screening guideline by incorporating meta-analyzed early-onset CRC specific risk factors/estimates will be a significant step forward toward optimal screening in younger adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative:  1.6 million people suffer from opioid use disorder (OUD); opioid use has a high relapse rate, and is especially susceptible to overdose deaths, with >60% of deaths attributed to fentanyl. The transition from recreational/prescription to persistent opioid use and enhanced susceptibility to relapse is, in part, driven by enhanced endogenous opioid signaling in the brain, the maladaptive co-opting of existing reward-seeking strategies, and aberrant activity in the striatum, a brain region important for reward seeking. Therefore, the goal of this proposal is to refine and elucidate how enhanced opioid signaling alters neural circuit activity in the striatum during opioid-seeking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Study Narrative The proposed study moves an evidence-based culturally adapted treatment for addictions tested under controlled conditions in Project CAMI (Culturally Adapted Motivational Interviewing), to the real-world. Project Aims are to increase access to CAMI in a primary care setting to heavy drinking Latinxs and to evaluate CAMI's feasibility, acceptability, and effectiveness when delivered by clinical staff within this treatment delivery system. Our study is a first to test how to integrate culturally-adapted addiction treatments into primary care practice and will answer essential questions on implementing evidence-based care for Latinxs that can improve health disparities related to substance use while deepening understanding of how stressors (that are immigrant-specific or not) contribute to heavy drinking and drug use; findings may translate to the broader community to focus on population health for all primary care patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to establish an academic-industrial partnership between Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center and General Electric Healthcare to develop and disseminate advances in dynamic contrast-enhanced (DCE) MRI for use in cancer patients. The new developments, which include radial imaging, compressed sensing, and deep learning, will deliver rapid motion-resistant DCE-MRI with high spatial and temporal resolution for more accurate and reproducible quantification of MRI-derived metrics. The new technology to be disseminated as a prototype on GE scanners will promote the use of quantitative DCE-MRI biomarkers in clinical practice, a long-desired goal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fibrolamellar carcinoma, a life-threatening variant of liver cancer affecting adolescents and young adults, is characterized by a fusion event resulting in a novel chimeric protein that joins the N-terminal domain of DNAJ with the catalytic subunit of protein kinase A (PKAc). We aim to identify and validate druggable signaling networks that regulate the growth of DNAJ-PKAc fusion-expressing FLC cells. The knowledge gained from this study will accelerate the development of a novel therapeutic option for targeting childhood liver cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Babson Life Sciences Entrepreneurial Product Development Immersion for New Technologies and Solutions (Babson L-SPRINT) Program Biomedical entrepreneurship and health-related entrepreneurship at large is recognized as central to improving health outcomes, economic development, and societal well-being. Yet commercialization and technology-based start-ups can be challenging in an academic environment due to varying reward structures, organizational structures, organizational cultures and a lack of entrepreneurial education to bridge the gap between basic science and commercialization. The Babson L-SPRINT program will develop, recruit participants for, and deliver a specialized entrepreneurial education curriculum highlighting Babson’s signature Entrepreneurial Thought & Action® offering coupled with customized health and biomedical entrepreneurship content on addressing market segmentation and uncertainty, commercializing emerging technologies, scaling for growth, and interactive biomedical community building experiences.

PHR: Project Narrative Genome editing technologies are poised to revolutionize the practice of modern medicine for the treatment of genetic diseases. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative Human norovirus is the leading cause of viral gastroenteritis globally causing up to 200,000 deaths each year; however, it is unknown how norovirus establishes infection and causes disease. We recently discovered that murine norovirus, a model for human norovirus, infects rare intestinal cell called tuft cells which are critical for combating worm infection. In this project, we will identify how norovirus kills tuft cells, whether infection impairs tuft cell function, and how infection of tuft cells enables norovirus to evade the immune response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Immunotherapies have become crucial treatment options for a variety of cancer types and several novel targets are currently being explored to evaluate their anti-tumor capacity. Crucially however, most of these targets suffer from on-target, off-cell effects, as other immune cell types can express high levels of these molecules or induce widespread toxicity in non-malignant organs, severely limiting viable treatment options. The proposed study will elucidate the anti-tumor effects of TFR cells, a novel cellular immunotherapy target, and test ways to target them more specifically to induce long-lasting anti-tumor responses without causing irAEs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Obesity and diabetes are very common metabolic disorders linked to brain dysfunction. Glucagon-like peptide- 1 (GLP-1) analogs reduce food intake in humans, and this is an FDA-approved drug for treating type 2 diabetes that is also approved for weight loss in treating obesity; however, their mechanism for suppression of food intake is unclear. Addressing the central control of GLP-1 on feeding behavior will not only help us understand the functions of neuropeptides in the brain but will also inform the pharmacotherapy of obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The vestibular system plays a key role in our ability to move and interact with the world, by supporting balance, posture, and the stabilization of vision during movements of the head and body. This project will provide insights about the computations neural circuits perform on vestibular signals to guide movements, and how those computations are tuned by learning. The results will build a foundation to guide the development of new approaches for treating balance disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Multiple myeloma studies have revealed molecular subtypes with therapeutic and prognostic implications, but these fail to identify almost half of patients with poor outcomes, such as the proliferation myeloma subtype which is not defined by specific genetic alterations. This suggests an epigenetic regulation of proliferation gene expression, which will be investigated using computational analyses of somatic genetic alterations, tumor DNA methylation and gene expression in primary samples from the CoMMpass trial. Results will be integrated with patient outcomes to prioritize pathways for functional testing and follow-up mechanistic and translational studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because neuromodulator systems are targets of most pharmaceutical treatments for psychiatric disorders, neurodegenerative disorders, and almost all drugs of abuse. Understanding the spatial, temporal, and context-dependent features of neuromodulator signaling is essential to explain neuromodulator function. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to NIH's mission to reduce illness and disability because it will, in the long term, help design better therapies that target specific features of neuromodulator signaling for neurological and psychiatric disorders.

PHR: This project will identify common ways that M. tuberculosis bacteria avoids being killed by drugs that would normally work against them. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING

PHR: Project Narrative  Paid caregivers (e.g. personal care aides, home health aides, and other direct care workers) provide essential care that allows persons with dementia (PWD) to remain living at home, yet little is known about the lived experience of PWD receiving paid care. This project seeks to better understand factors that determine the roles that paid caregivers play in the home-based care of PWD. This will improve the care for PWD in the community by supporting the meaningful integration of paid caregivers in the person-centered dementia care team and guiding health policy to maximize the positive impact of paid caregivers on the lives of PWD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Nutrient metals such as zinc (Zn) are essential for life but can only be obtained through dietary intake, indicating the need for careful Zn maintenance. This proposal will focus on identifying mechanisms used by Acinetobacter baumannii to overcome Zn deficiency that is encountered by pathogenic bacteria during infection. Successful completion of this project will identify the function of clients of the A. baumannii metallochaperone, ZigA, in combating Zn deficiency and will ascribe a role for ZigA clients during the pathogenesis of pneumonia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There continues to be a need to engage students in cancer prevention and control research early in their academic training to inspire cancer prevention and control careers and renew the pool of scientists and clinicians in the field. The overall goal of this program entitled, “Student Transformative Experiences to Progress Undergraduate and Graduate Professionals” (STEP-UP) for cancer prevention is to provide undergraduate and Masters' degree seeking students with an intensive, hands-on summer research experience in cancer prevention and control. This research training experience includes the conduct of a mentored research project, didactic instruction, and career development guided by highly experienced multidisciplinary leadership and mentoring teams with peer reviewed research funding, to assure a quality program that will build and sustain the cancer prevention and control workforce of the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most prevalent neurodegenerative disease and most common form of dementia throughout the world. One of the causative disease driving proteins of AD is the accumulation of tau tangles in the brain. The goal of this project is to determine how cytoskeletal remodeling genes influences the brain’s native protein clearance pathways to lower tau accumulation as a potential therapeutic target to treat disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Preterm infants are at high risk of brain injury and there is increasing awareness of a link between neurological injury associated with prematurity and later-to-emerge psychopathology associated with self-regulatory deficits including Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder and clinical levels of internalizing and externalizing behaviors. Based on our research and findings of other independent investigations, we have isolated parental responsiveness as a modifiable environmental factor that may normalize trajectories of neurological development with strong implications for improving short- and long-term mental health outcomes for children born preterm. Utilizing a scalable parenting intervention, conducted over the internet, the proposed research will address a paucity of data in this area by providing a benchmark for identifying if parental responsiveness is a modifiable psychosocial factor that improves neurodevelopmental outcomes and brain connectivity in children born preterm, thus directly advancing the NICHD’s mission to ensure the health, productivity, independence, and well-being of all people through optimal rehabilitation.

PHR: Project Narrative The membrane-interacting domains of class I viral fusion proteins, such as HIV-1 Env, appear to play much greater roles in its stability, function and antigenicity than what has been appreciated previously. This proposal aims to determine atomic structures of these domains in a physiologically relevant environment, to assess their functional roles in viral infection and to facilitate development of intervention strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Anaplasma, tick-borne pathogenic bacteria that cause disease in a wide range of animals including humans and livestock, lead an obligate intracellular lifestyle, cycling between the cells of their tick and vertebrate hosts. Switching between these hosts involves extensive reprogramming of Anaplasma gene expression to facilitate adaptation to these distinct intracellular niches. Here we investigate how a regulatory protein recognizes DNA targets to orchestrate the transcriptional remodeling underpinning adaptation of Anaplasma to the tick host, and how disruption of this protein compromises bacterial survival inside tick cells.

PHR: Project Narrative Worldwide, more than 600,000 newborns die from infections each year. India has one of the highest burdens of newborn deaths due to bacterial infections, which are commonly resistant to antibiotics. In this study, I will identify risk factors for newborn bloodstream infections, develop a method for predicting antibiotic-resistant infections, and create an infection prevention survey to reduce risk of infections in hospitalized babies in Indian Neonatal Intensive Care Units.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Overactive bladder (OAB) affects one in nine adults in the United States and is a source of great suffering for patients and huge costs to the healthcare system estimated at $70 billion per year. Current treatments are either based on low adherence drugs, recurring botulinum toxin injections, or neurostimulators, that either require exhaustive sessions, or costly invasive implantation. This proposal seeks to demonstrate preclinical safety and efficacy and to complete development of a game-changing therapeutic intervention based on recent understandings of bladder pathophysiology. The new minimally invasive, radiofrequency mucosal partitioning Uzap therapy is expected to provide an effective, single session, non-drug, non-implant solution for OAB and result in significant relief to patients as well as substantial cost savings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  The impending health epidemic of age-related macular degeneration (AMD) creates an urgent need to develop treatments that prevent AMD or stop its progression. Because the pathogenesis of AMD is multifactorial, ways need to be developed to make informed decisions about the most efficacious intervention for individual patients or patient subgroups. The studies in this application will test the hypothesis that mitochondrial dysfunction is a key step in AMD pathology for individuals harboring the AMD high risk SNP (rs1061170; amino acid change Y402H) for complement factor H (CFH), the most prevalent AMD patient population and the one with the greatest risk for developing advanced disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Statement / Narrative The Duke University Superfund Research Center (DUSRC) will study the impacts of multiple contaminant exposures in humans and ecological models of neurodevelopmental health, elucidate neurotoxic mechanisms that occur from these co-exposures, and develop novel remediation and treatment strategies that target the highest risk contaminants without increasing the risk of other contaminants. Our work will provide key data and information needed to improve public health guidance and environmental clean-up goals to effectively mitigate the negative health consequences of co-exposure to hazardous chemicals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Perinatal exposure to lead is known to adversely impact neurodevelopment; however, children are exposed to lead in combination with many other hazardous chemicals that may interact to negatively impact neurodevelopment. This project will examine the role of prenatal co-exposure to metals and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) to assess their interactive effect on neurodevelopment in children. Additionally, we will use a novel isotopic approach to identify the primary sources of lead exposure in an impacted community and recommend the best mitigation strategies to reduce exposure and health risks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Takotsubo Syndrome is a condition characterized by regional cardiac dysfunction, which was originally considered innocuous. These thoughts were revised because of observations showing similar mortality in patients with Takotsubo Syndrome to other acute coronary syndromes. Our proposal is directed at understanding regional differences in the control of myocardial blood flow and cardiac metabolism underlying Takotsubo Syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Exposure of the developing nervous system to environmental contaminants can have life-long effects, as illustrated by a few well-known examples such as lead. The degree to which combined exposures to multiple chemicals can adversely impact neurodevelopment is very poorly understood, although people are invariably exposed to mixtures, not single compounds. We will test the developmental neurotoxicity of combined exposures to common and important pollutants in order to provide information and a new cost- and time- efficient tool that could be used with real-life complex mixtures to test whether current regulatory actions at Superfund sites are adequate for protecting against adverse impacts on the developing nervous system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Enzymes are essential for the metabolic processes that occur throughout nature, but we still have an incomplete understanding of the full repertoire of enzyme families that can participate within metabolism. Recently, we have found that carbonic anhydrase (CAH) family enzymes with key active site mutations have neofunctionalized to act in the biosynthesis of neuroactive molecules in plants, and strikingly, similar mutations can be found in the evolutionarily-conserved carbonic anhydrase related proteins (CARPs) that are important for neurological function in humans. Our research will provide fundamental insight on the catalytic mechanisms and metabolic capabilities of neofunctionalized CAH enzymes, with an emphasis on a) CAHs that participate in the biosynthesis of medicinal compounds in plants, and b) CARPs that are critical for neurobiology in humans and other animals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Exposure chemical contaminants in aquatic ecosystems can have significant ecologically relevant fitness consequences such as mitochondrial dysfunction linked to adverse behavioral and bioenergetic outcomes. These effects may be exacerbated when exposed to multiple abiotic stressors such as changes in temperature and oxygen levels, but remain poorly understood. We will determine physiological fitness outcomes of chemical exposure in a multi-stressor environment in the context of evolved pollution resistance to better inform ecological risk assessment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) are contaminants of great concern commonly encountered at Superfund sites. In this project, we will develop innovative precision bioremediation approaches that promote PAH degradation and minimize co-contaminant mobilization. A fundamental feature of our project will be the engineering of microcapsule delivery vehicles that facilitate targeted delivery and optimized activity of microbes carrying out key remediation functions, ultimately reducing the potential for human and environmental exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anxiety disorders are the most common class of psychopathology among youth, with nearly a quarter of adolescents meeting 12-month diagnostic criteria. The primary aim of this project is to use user-centered design methods to engage at-risk adolescents, providers, and community partnerships into the design and evaluation of a technology-enabled prevention service for anxiety. Accomplishment of the training goals and proposed research project will provide the skills and tools necessary for development of an R01 proposal aimed at testing the efficacy of the technology-enabled prevention service for anxiety among youth within community settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Defective human mismatch repair (MMR) genes cause the common cancer susceptibility Lynch syndrome aka hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (LS/HNPCC), as well as 10-40% of various sporadic cancers. This proposal will utilize novel single molecule imaging techniques to quantitatively examine the mechanisms of human MMR in vitro and in vivo. Understanding the detailed MMR sequences responsible for faithful repair, DNA damage sensing, immune activation and cancer should significantly advance predictive genetic diagnostics for LS/HNPCC patients and therapeutic strategies for tumors driven by MMR defects.

PHR: Project Narrative The Administrative and Research Translation Core (ARTC) of the Duke University Superfund Research Center (DUSRC) provides holistic support to the Center’s five research projects and four cores. Through efficient central planning and coordination, fiscal oversight, stakeholder and partnership engagement, effective communication and trainee support, the ARTC will enable an integrated and efficient systems approach to research, and successful research translation. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Assessment of health impacts related to human or ecological exposure to pollutant chemicals relies critically on our ability to measure these chemical species at relevant levels in biological and environmental samples. Superfund contaminants such as hydrophobic organic contaminants (e.g. polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons) and metals (e.g. lead, cadmium) must be measured with high sensitivity and selectivity. The Analytical Chemistry Core seeks to provide these capabilities, along with training and expert consulting services in analytical chemistry practice, to researchers probing developmental impacts of Superfund-relevant chemicals after environmentally- relevant exposures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adenovirus is the most common cause of human eye infection, and yet, at present there is no effective therapy. We will study three novel interfaces during viral infection of corneal epithelial and stroma cells with the potential to increase understanding of viral pathogenesis. Studies on intracellular viral trafficking and virion assembly may lead to novel approaches to antiviral therapies, while our examination of how corneal epithelial cell-derived proinflammatory mediators contribute to corneal inflammation is directly translatable to the keratitis caused by adenovirus infection in the human cornea.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Environmental health science problems posed by chemical exposure are complex; addressing these problems successfully requires expertise from diverse scientific fields. Likewise, communicating science is challenging for many scientists, and historically much environmental health science work has been done in the absence of interaction with affected communities. The Research Experience and Training Coordination Core of the Duke University Superfund Research Center is dedicated to training future environmental health researchers from many backgrounds in a cross-disciplinary fashion that enables them to carry out and communicate integrated, problem-oriented research, in partnership with affected communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Supporting the aim articulated in NIEHS’s 2018-2023 strategic plan to “recognize and seek to address the disparate health impacts of environmental hazards on disadvantaged and diverse communities,” and the focus of the Duke University Superfund Research Center (DUSRC) to investigate neurodevelopmental health impacts of early-life co-exposures to polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) and metals, the Community Engagement Core (CEC) will engage with low socioeconomic status communities of color in Durham and Navassa, North Carolina, experiencing disproportionate exposure due to geographic proximity to hazardous sites and expected exacerbated health risks from exposures due to social determinants of health1–10. The CEC’s holistic, three-tiered approach to prevention and intervention is based on the environmental health literacy framework11–14, with a focus on generating awareness of, and promoting self-efficacy to reduce exposure to chemical contaminants by facilitating bidirectional communication between affected communities and Center researchers and trainees, other SRPs and local, state and federal agencies. Co-produced in collaboration with our extensive network of community-based and community-serving organizations in the two geographic areas, the CEC aims to generate solutions to reduce early life exposure to PAHs and metals at the individual, community, and policy levels through the following approaches: 1) promote individual awareness and self-efficacy to reduce exposure among pregnant women and children in Durham, NC, through report-back and bidirectional communication mechanisms; 2) foster community level awareness of and the capacity to investigate and reduce exposures through co-developed Environmental Health Academies; and 3) build the capacity of affected communities to assess and utilize environmental health data to promote more effective and inclusive policies aimed at reducing exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The National Magnetic Resonance Facility at Madison (NMRFAM) research resource provides access to state- of-the-art solution and solid-state NMR technology to the biomedical research community, enabling facility users to leverage the power and diversity of NMR methods to study the structure, dynamics, function and interactions of large and small biomolecules. NMRFAM will continue to provide reliable and timely access to NMR instrumentation with excellent staff support for all phases of the NMR experience, in order to engage actively in experiment design well aligned with user objectives, to obtain the highest quality data possible and to commit to interpreting results to solve highly significant biomedical research problems that are best addressed by NMR.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative / Lay Language Description Diarrheal disease accounts for an immense global public health burden, primarily among young children in low- resource settings. This project will test blood samples collected from young children enrolled in randomized trials in Kenya and Bangladesh for antibody response to diarrhea-causing pathogens so that we can study the effects of improved water, sanitation, handwashing, and nutrition on pathogen transmission, and determine whether serology can be used to identify communities with the highest burden of diarrhea-causing pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Three-dimensional ultrasound imaging is an important clinical tool for disease diagnosis as well as providing guidance for interventional and surgical procedures. At present, existing three-dimensional ultrasound imaging technologies are not widely accessible, difficult to use, and do not provide sufficient imaging functionality to meet the clinical needs. To fill the gap, we propose to develop a new three-dimensional ultrasound imaging solution that is accessible, functional, user-friendly, low-cost, and compatible with most existing ultrasound imaging systems in the clinic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Cardiometabolic diseases (CMD), including obesity, dyslipidemia, type 2 diabetes, and hypertension, disproportionately impact Hispanic and Latino people and are the leading cause of disease burden in the world. Despite decades of genetic research, little is understood about how gene expression measures impact and are impacted by CMD. Therefore, we propose to study the relationship of gene expression measures genome-wide in two key metabolic tissues (whole blood and abdominal subcutaneous adipose tissue) with CMD and its progression in Hispanic and Latino people to garner a better understanding of the relationship between gene expression and CMD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE) African American (AA) women have a higher risk of being diagnosed with aggressive breast cancer and have the highest mortality rate among all racial groups in U.S. women. We will systematically elucidate the role of long noncoding RNAs (lncRNAs), a novel class of regulatory molecules, in breast cancer prognosis in AA women. This work is new and is anticipated to advance our understanding of molecular mechanisms contributing to the aggressive tumor biology and poor cancer prognosis observed in AA women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This proposed project is relevant to public health because it will evaluate the impact of the largest outpatient value-based payment program in the U.S. on patient access to evidence-based treatment for depression and anxiety disorders in the primary care setting, potentially improving the quality of primary care for the large number of Medicare beneficiaries with these conditions. The project is relevant to the National Institute on Mental Health's mission to use real-world medical claims, survey, and clinician data to identify, evaluate, and validate national innovative primary care payment and service delivery models on their impact on access to care, evidence-based treatment rates, health outcomes, and costs of care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: 99% of the mitochondrial proteome is encoded by nuclear genes and require the coordinated efforts of dedicated mitochondrial protein import machinery for the proper import, sorting, and folding of these cytosolically-translated proteins. Although it is well-understood that these processes are so critical for sustaining the numerous mitochondrial functions that are necessary for maintaining normal human physiology, modern medicine's ability to combat human disorders such as neurodegeneration and cancer are hampered by our limited structural understanding these protein import machineries. My proposed research under this award will utilize targeted biochemical strategies and groundbreaking technological developments in electron cryomicroscopy to pioneer studies of these critically important protein import complexes, providing insights into how their dysfunction leads to alterations in the protein content of the mitochondria and progression of the disease state.
