PROJECT_TITLE: Towards an Atomistic Understanding of Mitochondrial Protein Biogenesis

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Successful treatments for atherosclerotic heart disease reduce the “bad” cholesterol in the bloodstream, but further therapies are needed, underscoring the public health relevance of this proposal. These challenges will be addressed by 1) understanding how a recently uncovered gene decreases the body's ability to clear “bad” cholesterol, and 2) establishing whether the beneficial effects of inhibiting this gene extend beyond a cell culture dish and into a whole organism. Since the results will determine whether this gene could be a future drug target, as well as how a drug would have to work against it, this proposal is directly relevant to the NIH mission of promoting fundamental discoveries and innovative research designs as a basis for improving human health.

PHR: Corticospinal circuits are essential for skilled movement. In humans, interruption of motor circuits caused by spinal cord injury, stroke, or other disorders results in severe deficits in most fine motor skills. Therefore, understanding the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying corticospinal circuits will provide important information for developing new therapeutic avenues for addressing diseases and injuries related to motor circuits in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT ALBANY
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed study will evaluate if and how multiple weather factors and/or natural disasters jointly affect the most fatal diseases in the aging population, including cardiovascular disease, respiratory diseases, Alzheimer’s (and other forms of dementia), unintentional injuries, and renal disease, and if the exposures to these weather extremes and related health impacts are different by different socioeconomic status (SES) among older adults. This may be the first study to utilize the comprehensive meteorological data collected by Mesonet, the remote sensing data, and over 300 environmental variables to create daily high-resolution gridded weather data (1km*1km or finer), and to assess nationwide COVID-19 infection/death after weather extremes. The health risk predictive models based on multiple SES, social, environmental, and community risk factors using data science methods, the vulnerability and resilience index/map, and culturally appropriate communication materials will help guide state and/or federal environmental and health agencies to plan interventions and adaptation programs, specifically for the aging population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative How cells respond to the environment is a fundamental process required for normal development, and homeostasis and that is altered in disease. Our proposed studies aim to understand the role of the post-transcriptional RNA modification m6A as a critical component of the repertoire of tools that cells use to adapt to extracellular cues and the mechanisms involved in this regulation. The success of the research proposed here will not only expand our understanding of basic tools that cells use to respond to their environment but will have the potential to identify novel pathways and therapeutic targets implicated in disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The CBPH attempts to clarify the cellular, molecular and biological pathways through which social, economic, and psychological and experiences impact health with aging and create differential health. This is accomplished through the development of valid and reliable biological measurement appropriate for population studies, the integration of networks of experts on novel biological processes into the demographic research community, and the support of cutting edge research. Such knowledge is essential to improve our ability to improve health and reduce health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Human airway smooth muscle (HASM) represents the pivotal cell regulating bronchomotor tone. However, our incomplete understanding of type 2 (T2) inflammation-regulated excitation-contraction (E-C) coupling in HASM shortening has, for the past 60 years, hindered the development of new HASM bronchodilators in the treatment of obstructive lung disease. We assert that studying the molecular mechanisms of excitation-contraction (E-C) coupling that differentiate HASM shortening in asthma- and non-asthma-derived cells/tissues will uncover novel mechanical endotypes of airflow obstruction (inflammation-dependent and -independent) and identify improved bronchodilators that are less susceptible to tolerance and less affected by immune inflammatory responses in asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The protective effect of education against Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) is found to be smaller for racial/ethnic minority groups than non-Hispanic White individuals. To identify sociodemographic factors that mediate or modify the education-ADRD risk relationship and ultimately reduce racial/ethnic disparities in ADRD, the proposed research will conduct novel multigenerational and multilevel mediation analyses to assess the effects of education across multiple generations in a family and the effects of structural inequality and racism on ADRD risk among racial/ethnic groups. The proposed study is relevant to public health because the results will help identify socioeconomic mediators and modifiers to reduce disparities in ADRD. This study will also contribute multidomain contextual data to a nationally presentative longitudinal study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Diet Interventions, by Race, Evaluated as Complementary Treatments for Pain (DIRECTPain) Project Narrative Racial disparities in knee osteoarthritis (OA) pain may be reduced through adoption of a demonstrated pain- reducing, low-carbohydrate diet (LCD). The overall aim of this study is to examine the efficacy of the LCD to reduce evoked pain and to determine the contribution of race to these effects, with an emphasis on psychosocial variables. We believe that the reduction in evoked and self-reported knee OA pain will be modulated by race, wherein Non-Hispanic Black individuals will experience greater benefit from the LCD, providing an alternative to opioids for pain relief and reducing racial disparities in knee OA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Major biomedical advances for prevention and treatment, which have enabled substantial progress towards the goal of ending the HIV epidemic, will not reach their full potential without rigorous behavioral and social science research to optimize uptake, adherence, and effective and equitable implementation and scale-up. Ending the epidemic requires significant commitment of resources and effort, including further biomedical and behavioral research, and a continual infusion of an adequately trained workforce. By providing postdoctoral research training opportunities in HIV-related behavioral and social sciences, our Program will contribute to the development of the next generation of outstanding behavioral sciences HIV researchers, capable of addressing the challenges and opportunities that the evolving HIV pandemic poses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Transcription of RNAs that do not encode protein, but nonetheless function in critical roles during cell division, is linked to age-related diseases including cancers. The proposed research aims to discover novel mechanisms in genomic stability by the RNA interference pathway, mediated by pericentromeric noncoding RNA in mouse stem cells. The results will inform fundamental understanding of new mechanisms of gene regulation and genomic stability critical to human development and disease, and potentially useful to develop new disease therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Rates of sexually transmitted infections with Neisseria gonorrhoeae are rising in the US and increasing gonococcal antibiotic resistance presents a major public health threat. Inadequate understanding of the natural history of infection is a substantial impediment to the development of public health interventions against gonorrhea, particularly vaccines. This study proposes a novel longitudinal study of N. gonorrhoeae natural history in a high-risk cohort to identify the bacterial and host determinants of infection outcome using the distinct, yet integrated, strategies of pathogen and natural microbial community genomics and immunology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Drug resistance and disease relapse is common in patients with high-risk acute myeloid leukemia (AML). Almost 40-50 % patients die due to disease relapse. Here we provide molecular insights into the pathways exploited by AML cell to survive during drug treatment, which results in treatment resistance, and demonstrate that blocking these pathways leads to a cure. While the project focuses on AML, the findings should be readily translatable to pother treatment resistant cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: HUGO W. MOSER RES INST KENNEDY KRIEGER
PHR: Project Narrative Acute flaccid myelitis is an emerging infectious disorder caused primarily by Enterovirus D68 that resembles polio and is affecting increasing numbers of children in the Unites States and worldwide. It is poorly understood and therefore has few effective treatment options. To better define the pathophysiology of acute flaccid myelitis and evaluate therapeutic targets, I will study the infection of motor neurons by Enterovirus D68 to evaluate the role of disrupted nucleocytoplasmic transport in motor neuron toxicity, define early events in motor neuron pathology, and determine the role of host genetics in disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECTIVE NARRATIVE Significant breakthroughs in cancer diagnosis and treatment are limited by the shortage of scientists and clinicians with the necessary training to bridge the gap between basic science discovery in the lab and clinical advancement for the patient. The Emory Training Program in Cancer Biology will provide enhanced mentored training to postdoctoral fellows to acquire the depth of knowledge and critical skills in cancer biology research combined with the practical exposure and understanding of clinical concepts to initiate an impactful independent research program to make transformative discoveries to improve quality of care for patients with cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The phosphatidylinositol-5-phosphate 4-kinases (PI5P4Ks) are lipid kinases that have evolved to mediate cellular responses to stress yet how they are regulated is not understood. We have discovered that the core kinases of the Hippo pathway, MST1 and MST2 are direct negative regulators of PI5P4K activity, as well as the lipid substrate of the PI5P4Ks, PI-5-P interacts with the Hippo adaptor protein MOB1 which in turn effects the activity of the Hippo downstream effector YAP. The overall goal of this R01 proposal is to obtain a comprehensive understanding of Hippo-PI5P4K communication under physiological conditions and elucidate the oncogenic roles of the Hippo-PI5P4K axis for breast cancer development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to develop a real-time precision opto-control (RPOC) technology for selective control of all biomolecules of interest in live cells using lasers. We will prototype a high-speed ‘smart’ RPOC platform that manipulates biomolecules based on optical logic signals and demonstrate the capability of this platform by designing photoswitchable compounds for controlling enzyme activities at sub-micron precision. Then, we will build a multi-color portable RPOC system for broader applications outside an optical laboratory.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The efficient preparation of small molecule therapeutics is contingent upon the availability and diversity of chemical tools. Moreover, the synthesis of pharmaceutically relevant chiral molecules presents an even greater synthetic challenge if isomerically pure compound is necessary in order to minimize potential off-target biological effects. The goals of this proposal aim to develop new chemical tools for the highly selective upgrading of hydrocarbon feedstocks to value-added chemical building blocks, further abridging synthetic sequences and improving access to drug-like molecules.

PHR: The proposed research is relevant to the missions of the NIH and NINDS because it determines mechanisms involved in the initiation and progression of Parkinson's disease. This work will identify molecular factors in the vermiform appendix that are abnormal in Parkinson's disease cases to further our understanding of gastrointestinal contributions to Parkinson's disease. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because providing a means of continuous hemodialysis is important for clinical outcomes by enabling more flexible hemodialysis prescriptions. The project will develop a robust, ultrathin, sheet-membrane hemodialyzer suitable for continuous hemodialysis using a two-filter system that will be tested on the benchtop and in a small animal model. The silicon nitride-based dialyzer will be scalable to clinical use and supports the “Advancing American Kidney Health initiative”.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Little is known about the core ocular microbiome constituents in a healthy population. This project will characterize the ocular microbiome at the species level and their interactions with the immune system using well-established whole-metagenome sequencing, and metatranscriptomics methods optimized for low-biomass clinical samples. The outcomes of this study will add to our understanding of the core microbial constituents in anterior segment and their role in immune interactions to maintain homeostasis.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fungal infections are common, increasing in frequency and severity, and cause considerable morbidity and mortality. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The development of engineered, patient-specific kidney tissue would meet an urgent clinical need for ~110,00 patients awaiting renal replacement therapy and also serve as a model platform to expedite biomedical research. While significant progress has been made towards this goal, engineered kidney tissue still lacks a collecting duct network and ureter. This proposal will result in the development of an engineered collecting duct network with a single drainage outlet that would enable filtrate removal from engineered kidney tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative A polygenic score detects 20% of the population with more than double the average risk of heart attacks caused by coronary plaque, and those are flying under the radar in current clinical practice. This project will return a high polygenic score result to 300 participants of a hospital biobank, study how their cardiovascular health and blood biomarkers contribute to their coronary plaque imaged using a dedicated coronary CT scan, and finally conduct a clinical trial on half of them to determine whether and how colchicine combined with statin changes their coronary plaque over a one-year period.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative The proposed research focuses on developing and testing a web-based platform, called Jom-TestPlus, that will incorporate HIV self-testing (HIVST) with real-time e-counseling (eHIVST) with online-to-offline (O2O) linkage to HIV prevention and treatment services while simultaneously co-addressing chemsex-related needs for men who have sex with men (MSM) in Malaysia. This model represents a potentially impactful strategy for reaching marginalized populations, like MSM, and allows immediate engagement in the post-test linkage process to prevention or treatment services.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Psychosis: A Convergent Neuroscience Perspective is a training grant aiming to provide basic and clinical neuroscientists with the skills and knowledge necessary to establish an interdisciplinary research career that can contribute to understanding the neurobiology of psychosis spectrum disorders. This renewal application capitalizes on the depth of resources, facilities and faculty dedicated to research and training in translational neuroscience at the University of Pennsylvania. The program forges cross-fertilization of clinical and basic neuroscientists, with diverse expertise that is critical for probing neural mechanisms pertinent to psychosis and advancing novel treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because no effective therapeutic intervention currently exists beyond, physical, occupational and speech therapy for the hundreds of thousands of individuals who live with motor and cognitive disabilities following traumatic brain injury. The goal of the research is to develop a deep brain stimulation system that will facilitate post-injury recovery of motor and cognitive function sufficient to improve daily function and vocational reentry. The project is relevant to the mission of the National Institutes of Neurological Disorders and Stroke as we are seeking to reduce the burden of traumatic brain injury on individuals, their families, and society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE AML is a growing public health problem in the United States: over 20,000 new cases of AML will be diagnosed in 2019, and sadly, greater than 11,000 deaths will occur. Although routine use of dose-intense chemotherapy regimens improves outcomes for patients with AML, the majority of patients die of disease and suffer significant toxicities with therapy. As such, the development of more effective, molecularly-targeted therapies is of urgent clinical importance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Latinx children and adolescents experience rates of anxiety and related internalizing disorders at a higher rate than other ethnic groups, but we know little about risk and protective factors for the emergence of symptoms in Latinx children. This K01 will examine the role of neural, dyadic, and cultural markers of emotional processing and regulation in the development of anxiety symptoms in young Latinx children from toddlerhood to preschool. A greater understanding of the individual, dyadic, and cultural factors contributing to an increased risk for anxiety in Latinx children could have a substantial impact on our ability to identify which Latinx children are at the highest risk of starting trajectories towards clinical levels of anxiety and could help generate culturally- tailored interventions to modify developmental trajectories away from increased symptoms in these children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE AML is the 2nd most common type of leukemia diagnosed and has a 5-year survival rate of only 27%. Unlike other non-solid tumors (e.g. CML), few significant improvements in AML survival have been achieved over the past 40 years, despite a large number of clinical trials using both conventional and targeted therapies. Of interest, the Bcl-2 inhibitor Venetoclax recently demonstrated improved clinical outcomes with conventional therapeutics, i.e., cytarabine (AraC) or hypomethylating agents. We posit that non-toxic liposomal-based therapeutics designed to deliver the pro-apoptotic bioactive lipid C6-ceramide will augment the efficacy of standard of care therapeutics and have a substantive clinical impact for the treatment of AML.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Race-ethnic disparities in acute leukemia clinical trial enrollment limit the generalizability of study findings and equitable access to high-quality care, while acute leukemia’s unique care patterns limit the utility of existing interventions to reduce them. I propose to combine community engagement with data science methods to develop a multilevel intervention targeting key trial enrollment barriers through three complementary pilot studies: a review system to preemptively modify trial design elements associated with enrollment disparities, an enrollment diversity performance feedback interface for physicians, and a peer-based support application for patients. Together, these interventions promise to create low-cost and scalable methods for diversifying cancer clinical trial enrollment as I prepare for an independent research career focused on ensuring equity in cancer care delivery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study focuses on the role of acid ceramidase in leukemic cell survival. Primary goals are to complete preclinical studies with novel acid ceramidase inhibitors and to identify clinical, biochemical, and genetic features that predict sensitivity to these agents. Knowledge gained from this work will be utilized to design improved AML treatments that exploit a novel target in specific patient populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute myelogenous leukemia (AML), for which there have been few treatment advances in 40 years, is the most common type of acute leukemia in adults. The goal of this work is to develop new, innovative, effective lipid-based therapies for treatment of AML.

PHR: HIV remains a deadly pathogen that threatens human's life and the absence of efficient cure poses a major problem for public health. Despite the success of antiretroviral therapy (ART), the emergence of drug resistant strains and the genetic diversity of HIV necessitates the development of even more potent and diverse ART. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute myelogenous leukemia (AML) is the most common acute form of leukemia affecting adults, and it lacks long-term efficacious therapies. Core A serves a vital role in hypothesis testing and generation for the projects by seeking to understand alterations in (glyco)sphingolipid metabolism in AML by providing standardized measurements of the sphingolipid pathways and ADME/PK analytical services to facilitate sphingolipid-based therapy development. The outcome of these studies will help define new therapeutic strategies for AML.

PHR: The Medical Science Training Program (MSTP) at the Medical College of Wisconsin (MCW) provides integrated basic science and medical training as the educational foundation for future academic physician scientists. The mission of MCW-MSTP is to prepare students for careers as physician-scientists, which allows students to conduct hypothesis-driven research and to practice evidence-based medicine as an MD-PhD. MCW-MSTP welcomes all applicants, including students of diversity, students with disabilities, and students from socio-economically disadvantaged backgrounds.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Biostatistics and data management support are critical for the success of the Program Project, which involves human subjects, animal models, and approximately 30 different hAML cell lines. The Biostatistics Core provides easy and guaranteed access for investigators and also allows the biostatisticians to specialize in the Project areas regarding content knowledge and appropriate statistical methodology. The dedicated and experienced personnel in the Core provide the resources and support available to all investigators in the Program Project, and the Core serves as the interface to the larger resources in biostatistics in the Department of Public Health Sciences (DPHS) of the School of Medicine at the University of Virginia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To accelerate the pace of diabetes research, there is a pressing need to train computational scientists the biological basis of diabetes and related metabolic disorders. The University of Utah Computational Approaches to Diabetes and Metabolism Research Training Program trains both predoctoral and postdoctoral trainees in the computational and mathematical sciences and in the biological basis of diabetes and obesity. These bioinformatics scientist trainees will gain the expertise and leadership skills to apply computational methods to complex biological questions that will ultimately impact the prevention, treatment, and outcomes of people with diabetes and related metabolic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transposable elements are prevalent selfish DNA sequences present in many organisms, and they constitute about 45% of the human genome. Their activity and abundance are related to their ability to cause inherited diseases and cancers, including breast cancer, colon cancer, and leukemia. The proposed research will identify factors that influence the abundance of transposable elements and determine their consequences on host function and fitness, with strong implications for human health and disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Glial cells, the primary immune responders in the brain, respond swiftly to neurodegeneration, and abnormal innate immune responses are coupled to the progression of devastating neurological conditions, as well as poor recovery from acute traumatic events. This proposal is relevant to public health because it will provide critically needed insight into the molecular and cellular signaling pathways that govern glial responses to neural injury. These discoveries will advance our understanding of neuron-glia communication in the brain, provide a springboard for the development of treatments to reduce the burden of neurological disorders and, thus, will be highly relevant to the NIH mission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Nematodes are successful and devastating parasites of humans, capable of modulating host biology in numerous ways including suppressing the immune system. The goal of my lab is to understand modulation of host biology by nematode parasites, and to characterize the host signaling pathways they target to achieve this modulation. This research project contributes to our understanding of lipid signaling in innate immunity and how nematode proteins affect host immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic pain, a common and distressing complication of advanced cancer, is commonly treated with analgesics with minimal access to comprehensive biopsychosocial pain management approaches. Aligning with NCI’s mission to advance scientific knowledge to help patients live longer, healthier lives, this K08 proposal seeks to improve cancer patients’ pain self-management by adapting and integrating cognitive behavioral therapy for pain into an existing mHealth intervention designed to optimize pharmacologic management (e.g. daily pain/opioid monitoring and tailored advice) for patients with advanced cancer. This integrated psychological and pharmacologic mHealth intervention has strong potential to improve cancer pain outcomes and to readily disseminate pain management support and alleviate pain for a wide range of patients with advanced cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women who develop gestational diabetes during pregnancy are two times more likely to develop cardiovascular disease and 7 times more likely to develop type 2 diabetes in the decade after pregnancy, but the reason why this occurs is unclear and there are currently no specific treatment strategies to prevent this disease progression. This project addresses this public health issue in three ways: examining if woman with a history of gestational diabetes have reduced micro-vessel responses to insulin (aim 1), delineating if oxidative stress is the cause of this reduced function and where this oxidative stress is coming from (aim 2), and examining if metformin treatment after pregnancy is able to specifically reverse this micro-vessel dysfunction (aim 3). Answering these questions will increase our understanding of what causes elevated disease risk after gestational diabetes and lay the foundation for trials of mechanism-specific treatment and prevention strategies in these women with high lifetime cardiovascular and metabolic disease risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE Postpartum depression is a significant public health concern, as at least 1 in 7 individuals will experience postpartum depression and alarming related health disparities exist, both in rates of postpartum depression and in availability of efficacious treatment. This project has clear relevance, affecting this significant mental health problem by determining whether an established preventive intervention (group interpersonal psychotherapy) delivered virtually shows the same benefits for preventing postpartum depression as it does in person. Recommendations based on this study will support sustainability and scalability of the intervention to other healthcare settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Atrial fibrillation (AF) is the most common abnormal heart rhythm, affecting >3 million Americans and may lead to bothersome symptoms including palpitations, congestive heart failure and stroke. Our proposal seeks to determine whether chronic premature atrial contractions (PACs) cause adverse atrial electrical and structural remodeling and contribute to the development of AF over time. If our hypothesis is correct, it could lead to a novel upstream preventive therapy for AF, improving quality of life, reducing morbidity and mortality and reducing healthcare costs for many Americans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Opioid use disorder (OUD) is a complex multi-symptomatic disorder whereby traits non-linearly interact on an individual basis across the OUD phases influencing vulnerability and resiliency. Using a novel rat model capturing this behavioral heterogeneity present in human OUD, cell- and pathway- specific adaptions underlying OUD propensity will be characterized. Work from this proposal will contribute to disentangling the neurobiological and behavioral complexities associated with OUD vulnerability, yielding valuable insight into the compensatory mechanisms in place to promote resiliency.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed junior level clinical immersion course will provide training and preparation of undergraduate engineering students through virtual reality clinical immersion experiences to be able to identify and evaluate real world healthcare problems in today’s evolving healthcare infrastructure. Through both online and in class learning modules, students will be able to work in multidisciplinary teams to develop a proposed innovative medical solution that can improve current practices of healthcare that were observed through virtual reality immersion. Using this scalable approach, large institutions and those institutions who do not have access to medical centers will be able to improve the next generation of biomedical engineering education by allowing students who would otherwise be unable to enter a clinic an understanding of current medical practices and how to identify and use technologies to improve the current field of healthcare.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The aim of this research proposal is to gain mechanistic understanding of the relationships among genomic variation, phenotype, and disease. The proposed research will combine data from DNA-DNA proximity ligation assays and multiple genome alignments to extract coevolutionary information about DNA elements and to infer the network of functional interactions among them. The PI has already made important contributions to the field of 3D genomics employing similar approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This application requests support for the five-year continuation of our NIMH-funded institutional training grant, “A Training Program to Address HIV-related Health Disparities in MSM” seated within a leading School of Public Health, a research environment rich in HIV prevention research, LGBT health research, theoretical and empirical approaches to explaining risk among MSM, and HIV global health and bio-behavioral research, all creating an ideal environment to rain the next generation of HIV prevention scientists who will address the epidemic among MSM. This training program has been designed with the goal of providing trainees with the necessary skill sets to not only launch their careers, but also to make a substantial difference in the fight against HIV/AIDS among MSM. Continuation of a T32 training program within an extraordinarily rich environment will continue a mechanism to mentor the next generation of HIV prevention scientists who will be uniquely poised to find ways to end the epidemic among MSM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The aging process directly leads to a multitude of diseases that affect nearly all systems of the body, including blood system. We have discovered a candidate rejuvenation signaling pathway and we intend to test whether enhancing this signaling axis can restore the functional capacity of an aging blood system. These studies will lay the foundation for the development of therapeutic strategies to rejuvenate the aged blood stem cell and to reduce the morbidity and mortality associated with myelosuppression used to treat a wide range of age-related hematopoietic disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative The current proposal is an innovative research plan to determine, for the first time, whether administration of antioxidant (NACA) or alternative biofuel (ALC) known to maintain mitochondrial bioenergetics and promote functional neuroprotection after contusion spinal cord injury (SCI), in combination with novel intrathecal injection of isolated muscle mitochondria embedded in a thermo-gelling, erodible hydrogel system to protect mitochondrial viability fosters greater neuroprotective efficacy. The use of an injectable hydrogel will permit the development of a local environment which can aide in maintaining mitochondrial health through optimization of the hydrogel niche. The knowledge gained from the proposed experiments will provide direct insight into the use of hydrogel systems for organelle delivery in vivo, and the potential of this novel combinatorial therapeutic intervention(s) to maintain cellular bioenergetics while reducing oxidative stress following SCI to promote tissue sparing and functional recovery.

PHR: Metastatic breast cancer is a deadly disease with no effective cure to date. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Family and unpaid caregivers are at the forefront of managing Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD) but are not well-supported in health care delivery. The actions of poorly informed and supported caregivers negatively affect persons living with ADRD and caregivers themselves. The challenges of ADRD caregiving may be alleviated with tailored services and supports. However, evidence-based models have typically been developed outside real-world care settings; few explicitly engage family at the point of care or are poised for widespread diffusion. The spread of consumer health information technology affords new opportunities to support ADRD caregivers within health care delivery. The patient portal allows patients to view test results and sections of their electronic medical record, perform health management tasks (e.g. scheduling visits, paying bills, filling prescriptions), access educational materials, and communicate with clinicians using secure messaging. Many care delivery organizations allow patients to share access to their patient portal account by registering a “care partner” to have their own identity credentials (login/password). Through shared access, patients may select whether and who electronically interacts with clinicians on their behalf, thus, respecting patient preferences while supporting care partners with timely information about patient health and treatments, and a mechanism to electronically navigate health system demands. Emerging evidence suggests that engaging care partners through shared access to the patient portal improves patient and family communication and confidence in their ability to manage care. Shared access may be particularly relevant in ADRD care due to the long and progressive course of the disease and heavy reliance on caregivers. Little is now known about electronic information sharing preferences and practices of persons with ADRD and their caregivers, or the feasibility of deploying novel interventions through consumer health information technologies to better support ADRD care and management. This application responds to RFA-AG-21-007 by building a program of health services research to address Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias Implementation Milestone 13.I to support research on technology-based dementia assessment, care, and management. The applicant is an established investigator who is trained in health services research and gerontology, has deep expertise in the study of family caregiving, and a robust research portfolio that bridges population-based social science and applied behavioral interventions that are embedded in real world care delivery contexts. The program assembles a multidisciplinary team of new and existing mentees at varied career stages to increase evidence regarding the role and use of consumer health information technology in ADRD care and management, and novel technology-supported strategies that hold promise for ADRD assessment, care, and management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Physical exercise exerts beneficial effects against type 2 diabetes (T2D), but the mechanisms by which exercise induces systemic metabolic benefits are unclear. We recently discovered that activation of autophagy, a lysosomal degradation pathway, in non-contractile tissues during exercise, via exercise-stimulated muscle-secreted fibronectin (Fn1) and downstream pathways, may play an important role in the regulation of exercise-induced insulin sensitization. In this proposal, we will demonstrate the role and mechanism of autophagy activation in non-contractile tissues in driving exercise-induced metabolic benefits against T2D.

PHR: Narrative This application is aimed at development and preliminary testing of a text messaging intervention that will reduce the risk of a major depressive episode and worsening depressive symptoms in perinatal individuals. The system would screen pregnant individuals, send tailored text messages with links to enhanced content, and would include a peer chat function. This accessible text platform would leverage both the ease of use inherent in text messages and the power of enhanced content drawn evidence from based behavioral interventions (Interpersonal Therapy and Cognitive Behavioral Therapy).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Current approaches to prevention and treatment of depression and anxiety among pregnant and postpartum individuals often operate within larger health systems that 1) lack mental health providers, and 2) are not trustworthy for birthing people, especially those who are from communities that have been marginalized. Scalable interventions that focus on improving perinatal mental health care for communities that have been marginalized are needed. We will develop and test an approach to linking the health system and the community to improve the reach and impact mental health care for pregnant and postpartum individuals with a particular focus on communities that have been marginalized.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement VEXAS syndrome is a newly discovered, deadly autoinflammatory disease and currently has no cure. This proposal will test the therapeutic potential of auranofin for this deadly disease, based on our new finding that auranofin can correct the functional defect of the VEXAS syndrome-causing protein UBA1. Auranofin is a clinical drug currently used to treat rheumatoid arthritis, and therefore, this proposed study may pave the way for repurposing of auranofin as the first drug for treating VEXAS syndrome

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tumor associated macrophages (TAMs) are highly suppressive in the tumor microenvironment (TME) and contribute to chemo- and immuno-therapy resistance. Our lab has made the discovery that a commonly used cancer therapy, PARP inhibitors (PARPi), induce lipogenic metabolism in TAMs rendering them even more suppressive, in which they inhibit T-cell function and activation, and limit therapeutic responses; importantly, however, in the absence of TAMs, PARPi promotes metabolically superior T-cell antitumor traits. Our proposal will formally determine how lipogenic TAM and T-cell metabolism is regulated during PARPi therapy, which is likely to provide opportunities for the development of novel treatment strategies that hold the power to overcome the immune-suppressive TME and improve PARPi therapy success in a number of cancer types.

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research aims to translate findings from basic science to create outcome measures and lay the groundwork for a potential clinical trial in Kabuki syndrome providing a novel treatment option to a clinical entity (intellectual disability) that has few therapeutic options. In addition to creating outcome measures and providing information for Kabuki syndrome that may be applicable to other rare diseases as well, understanding more about the cellular mechanisms resulting in impaired cognition in KS may provide a window into the mechanisms underlying normal cognition and memory and learning, and pathologic states – specifically intellectual disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study is highly significant because it targets a disproportionately affected group, Latinx men who have sex with men, and tests a culturally adapted, flexible intervention, Connecting Latinos en Parejas, developed specifically for Latinx male couples. The project is innovative in that it includes Latinx couples regardless of HIV status and expands prevention alternatives offered in other couples-based interventions by incorporating biomedical prevention methods such as pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP), promoting engagement in care, adherence to treatment regimens and viral suppression (TasP) and encouraging routine HIV testing if appropriate given the couple’s serostatus. Our intervention targets multiple points in the HIV Prevention and Care Continuum and is responsive to the Ending the HIV Epidemic Initiative and National HIV/AIDS Strategy (2022-2025).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Bacteria in biofilms, not individual or free swimming (ie planktonic), contaminate food, can spread bacteria when surfaces are cleaned, and are responsible for 80% of all hospital acquired infections, about 1.6 million infections and 80,000 deaths, at an annual cost of $16.8 to $27.2 billion dollars in the US. Biofilm development and reaction to antibiotics are dependent on the geometry being studied, nutrient, and liquid flow conditions and there are currently no relations able to translate between one set of conditions and another. This project seeks to create platforms and mathematical relations that will increase the ability of researchers, clinicians and manufacturers, translate from fundamental studies on biofilms with finite time scales and materials to infections and surfaces.

PROJECT_TITLE: Developing platforms for studying the impact of external stresses on multispecies biofilms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE Opioid addiction is a major public health crisis in the United States, and treatment of opioid addiction is hindered by high rates of relapse after abstinence. We here study the changes to medial orbitofrontal cortex in mice and rats in response to oxycodone withdrawal and relapse by integrating connectivity, gene expression, and genome accessibility measurements at the level of single cells and identify conserved core changes by comparing across species and behaviors. Our work contributes to the basic understanding of the connectomic and epigenomic changes in opioid addiction and aims to identify conserved changes for treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative There is a critical need to develop digitally delivered behavioral interventions for adolescents with chronic pain to drastically increase the reach of evidence-based interventions around the country and worldwide. This proposal seeks to systematically develop and evaluate the feasibility and preliminary effectiveness of a digital exposure treatment for adolescents with chronic musculoskeletal pain, utilizing a sequential replicated and randomized single-case experimental design (SCED) and incorporating innovative technology for remote biomechanical and daily physical activity assessment. Agile research methods will allow for a rapid, iterative development and evaluation of the intervention which will be further evaluated in a pilot trial utilizing SCED, providing the opportunity to rapidly and pragmatically evaluate treatment effectiveness in small cohort— ultimately yielding a clinically useful, evidence-based digital solution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Relevance statement A multitude of human diseases result from defects in genome maintenance and are characterized by profound neurodevelopmental abnormalities and neurodegeneration, even brain tumors, illustrating the importance of DNA repair for brain health. Therefore, understanding how DNA repair pathways function in the brain is critical for the development of treatments for these and other diseases. This grant application proposes a research plan to answer gaps in our knowledge concerning a specific cell type in the brain called glia, and how genome damage in these cells contribute to disease processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Overall – Project Narrative The Wake Forest Alzheimer’s Disease Research Center (ADRC) was founded only 4 years ago but has made remarkable progress toward its mission to promote research focused on strategies for preventing and treating Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and related disorders. We have a special focus on understanding how common medical conditions such as prediabetes, diabetes and hypertension influence the risk of AD, and how risk is influenced by health disparities of underrepresented groups. We will make important contributions that include critical research resources and highly trained investigators to the national ADRC network to address these questions and work together toward our common goal of developing effective methods to prevent, treat, and cure AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) is a common liver disease, and macrophages, which are cells of the im- mune system, play a pivotal role in disease progression. The proposed project will contribute to our under- standing of macrophage function and NASH progression to highlight the clinical utility of targeting these cells in NASH. Ultimately, our studies may lead to new therapeutic options that will improve patient health and quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Skeletal muscle insulin resistance accounts for ~90% of the reduction in insulin-stimulated glucose clearance in type 2 diabetic individuals. Alteration in lipid metabolism has been implicated for the pathogenesis of muscle insulin resistance, but the exact identify of the lipid-mediated mechanism that suppresses muscle insulin action in humans remains inconclusive. In this proposal, the role of lyso-phospholipids on skeletal muscle insulin sensitivity will be investigated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A large number of diseases are now recognized as `conformational diseases', caused by protein misfolding and subsequent aggregation. One example is hepatic fibrinogen storage disease (HFSD), where the underlying cause is the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) retention and aggregation of fibrinogen mutants, leading to liver damage, hypofibrinogenemia, and excessive bleeding. Serendipitously, we have uncovered an important role of ER-associated degradation (ERAD) in the biogenesis and quality control of both wildtype fibrinogen and disease-causing mutants of fibrinogen.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: The proposed research is relevant to public health because antibiotic resistant infections caused by Klebsiella aerogenes, Klebsiella oxytoca, Klebsiella pneumoniae, and P. aeruginosa were responsible for approximately $2 billion in attributable healthcare costs and over 12,000 deaths in 2017 alone. Nearly half of all patients who develop severe pneumonia caused by pathogens like these will experience antibiotic treatment failure and up to 30% will not survive. This proposal will advance the NIH mission to protect and improve patient health by addressing the urgent for new and innovative treatment approaches including Precision Dosing for patients infected by these pathogens.

ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding changes in brain dynamics and behavior of a subject recovering from unconsciousness is critically relevant to public health and patient quality of life, particularly in brain injury and recovery from anesthesia. This proposal will determine functional neuronal connectivity maps underlying awakening in healthy and injured brains and metrics that predict and track levels of arousal and awareness by combining cortical activity and motor behavior parameters. Successful completion of this proposal will identify more precise biomarkers that improve our ability to measure forebrain arousal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative In this multicenter proposal, we plan to test and validate a novel approach to hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC, the fastest growing cause of cancer death in the United States) in cirrhotic patients at risk, based on an abbreviated magnetic resonance imaging (AMRI) protocol using a liver specific MRI contrast agent (gadoxetic acid) with acquisition time <15 min, which potentially provides better detection rates of HCC, compared to the recommended ultrasound method with/without serum alpha-feto protein (AFP). We also plan to test the added value of liquid biopsy (circulating tumor DNA) measured in the blood, alone and in combination with AMRI and ultrasound for HCC screening. Additionally, we will assess the cost-effectiveness of the AMRI approach in comparison with ultrasound. Finally, we will explore the value of a dynamic AMRI protocol in comparison with ultrasound. If validated, this may benefit a large population of patients with chronic liver disease in the United States, with potential decrease in HCC-related mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative: The urothelial cells that line the bladder are tightly bound to one another by a multi-component, belt-like structure called the apical junctional complex. How this complex promotes adhesion in the face of large changes in bladder volume are unknown, but we hypothesize that it depends on the expansion and contraction of the junctional complex in response bladder filling and voiding. We further propose that the junctional complex senses tension and when bladder pressure become pathologically high (e.g., in response to benign prostatic hypertrophy) the components of the junctional complex stimulate the urothelial cells to proliferate and express abnormal amounts of regulatory proteins that contribute to further bladder dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: In the United States, there remains a critical need for well-trained investigators in dental, oral and craniofacial research. This training grant application supports Training in Craniofacial and Oral Health Research (T-COHR), an integrated program based in the College of Dental Medicine at the Medical University of South Carolina (MUSC) to help train the next generation of clinician scientists and scientists engaged in dental, oral and craniofacial research. Research training will be in the areas of oral infection and inflammation, oral cancer, bioengineering/biomechanics of the oral complex, and oral/craniofacial complex growth and regeneration.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because progress to ensure that all HIV-exposed infants are tested and treated as necessary has lagged and, without substantial improvements, will prevent the global community from reaching the UNAIDS 90-90-90 targets to end the AIDS epidemic by 2030. There is an urgent need for novel approaches to prompt early infant HIV testing, such as engaging social networks since they have been shown to be important in affecting other health behaviors, though not yet rigorously assessed within the context of infant HIV testing. This proposed research is directly relevant to NIH's HIV/AIDS research priorities to develop, test, and implement strategies to improve HIV testing by laying the foundations for implementing a social network intervention to ensure prompt testing and treatment for the 150,000 newly infected infants each year.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We seek to construct biocompatible chemical tools that can interrogate the dynamic molecular events of living systems across space and time. By embedding highly eﬃcient reactions within 2D/3D nucleic acid scaﬀolds, we will build toolkits with the speed and sensitivity to capture the deep complexity of living cells and tissues. With architectures that can translate chemical events into new sequence information, we aim to erase boundaries between in vivo chemistry and nucleic acid biotechnologies, transforming (bio)molecular tracking and sensing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Thousands of people in the United States each year suffer permanent voice loss because their voice boxes (larynges) are damaged from cancer, trauma, or nerve injury, as, in these cases, we currently have no options for restoration of normal laryngeal function. In this application, we explore novel methods for restoring function of the voice box (larynx) using adult-derived muscle and fat stem cells in a large animal model. We believe our findings will completely transform current paradigms for voice restoration in patients who have suffered severe laryngeal injuries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative  The ability to predict the sensory consequences of our actions is critical for learning and maintaining many complex behaviors, including speech, as well as for normal hearing in everyday life. This proposal will investigate the neural circuitry necessary for learning to predict the anticipate and suppress the excepted acoustic consequences of our actions. This research will provide critical insights into brain mechanisms important for normal hearing and will form the basis for understanding how the brain processes phantom sounds in disorders including tinnitus and schizophrenia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project will generate new knowledge of the magnitude and mediators of inequities at each phase of the transplant selection process and how institutional racism embedded in center-level processes and individual clinician biases may influence inequities. The results will elucidate the influence of institutional racism in transplant systems and processes on racial equity in access to transplant. In the future, Our toolkit will represent the first intervention developed to overcome bias and mitigate inequities at each step in the transplant selection process. In the future, we hope implement our toolkit at multiple transplant centers to test its ability to mitigate institutionally biased practices which contribute to organ transplant inequities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative (Public Health Relevance) This project will develop explainable and stable machine learning solutions for psychiatric brain stimulation. The pro- posed approach aims to discover how targeted stimulation drives changes in network dynamics and connectivity at a large scale and across multiple brain areas. As such, it will result in the design of AI-guided neuro-stimulation that can modulate and improve higher cognitive function, such as working memory, attention, and executive control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Plasmodium falciparum malaria remains a major public health problem globally, and new approaches to malaria control and prevention are urgently needed. In this proposal we will comprehensively determine the function of two newly-discovered human red blood cell host factors for malaria, testing the hypothesis that they facilitate parasite invasion through distinct yet synergistic pathways that are critical for the parasite’s life cycle. This project will advance our fundamental understanding of red blood cell-parasite interactions, and lay the groundwork for the development of host-directed therapies for malaria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: It is estimated that 69 million people suffer a traumatic brain injury (TBI) on an annual basis and many of these individuals will go on to develop post-traumatic headache (PTH) that can lead to persistent post-traumatic headache (PPTH). Such headaches are extremely difficult to treat, and new, effective non-opioid medications are urgently needed. Our studies are aimed to increase understanding of PTH and transition to PPTH in order to improve therapies for patients.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal describes a new NCI-supported postdoctoral Biobehavioral Oncology Training (BBOT) Program with a cross cutting theme of cancer disparities. This transdisciplinary training program in the biobehavioral aspects of cancer prevention, control and treatment response addresses 1) the biology of stress and disparities and 2) social determinants of health, behavior, and outcomes. Through outstanding mentorship, research, and training experiences, the goal of the BBOT Program is to prepare the next generation of biobehavioral oncology researchers for successful research careers devoted to ameliorating disparities in cancer health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Spousal bereavement increases the risk for developing Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD). The proposed study aims to examine psychological, immunological, and neurobiological mechanisms that contribute to elevated ADRD risk. By examining biobehavioral pathways by which spousal bereavement confers risk for poor cognitive function and cortical thinning in signature AD regions, this study will (a) enhance scientific understanding of how psychological stress impacts cognitive function and structural brain integrity (b) help identify at-risk widow(er)s years before ADRD onset, and (c) inform the development of individualized interventions targeted at delaying or preventing ADRD onset.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: 8. Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will greatly improve the performance of MRI scanners to image metabolic alterations in primary brain tumors. The new imaging methods will be used to guide intra-operatively surgical resection of brain tumors and monitor treatment response. This will enable precision oncology with targeted therapy tailored to the individual patient. Hence, this research is relevant to NCI’s mission to advance diagnosis and treatment of cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative The U.S. has set a goal to end the HIV epidemic by the year 2030, which can be achieved but only if targeted approaches are implemented with at-risk populations to address known barriers of engagement along the HIV prevention and care continua. The proposed research will inform efforts to reduce HIV/STI risk and transmission, reduce HIV/AIDS disease progression, reduce drug use and mental health co-morbidities, and improve the health and quality of life of HIV+ among at-risk youth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is the fourth leading cause of death in the United States and results in nearly 700,000 hospitalizations and over $70 billion in direct medical costs annually. Although COPD is a heterogeneous disorder affecting organ systems beyond the lungs, treatment approaches remain largely similar for most patients and have not advanced significantly over the past two decades. An improved understanding of the metabolic profiles associated with specific COPD features has the potential to open up new treatment pathways for patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nicotine use and misuse from smoking combustible tobacco reflects a major health problem with an estimated annual economic cost around $400 billion; some of the vulnerabilities and health consequences are greater in women. The potential individual and societal benefits that would come from a better understanding of factors contributing to chronic tobacco use are enormous. This benefit drives the long-term goal of our research program to understand how nicotine accrues additional reinforcing value through conditioning processes, identify factors that exacerbate or blunt the enhanced nicotine use caused by this conditioning history, and determine the role of sex as a biological variable.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will evaluate dysregulation of the alternative pathway (AP) of complement in patients with CKD. We will measure biomarkers and functional assays of the AP in participants of NEPHRON-D and SPRINT and evaluate if biomarkers of AP activation predict adverse outcomes in CKD. Additionally, we will evaluate genetic variants of the AP of complement as a potential contributing mechanism to AP dysregulation in CKD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Coronary artery disease is a major cause of death around the globe, yet there are currently no strategies to regenerate diseased coronary arteries. We hypothesize that studying how the developing embryo builds coronary arteries from the ground up could reveal ways of rebuilding them in diseased hearts. We identified candidate developmental pathways during the previous funding period, and propose here to study whether and how these pathways stimulate coronary regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS THE STATE UNIV OF NJ NEWARK
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescence is an important period in social and cognitive development, and social isolation during this developmental stage has long-lasting impacts on physical and mental health. Value-based decision making, or how we make decisions about the costs and benefits of alternative options, is a crucial aspect of daily life. This project will uncover how adolescent social isolation alters these complex decision-making behaviors in adulthood, as well as the underlying neural circuitry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have made the striking discovery that deletion of a key stress response gene, Atf6, in β-cells of a type 1 diabetes (T1D) preclinical model confers protection against T1D by inducing a previously not recognized multi- pronged pro-survival adaptative mechanism. We will investigate the regulation of β-cell-immune cell dialogue as well as the molecular mechanisms of diabetes protection in β-cell-specific Atf6-deficient mice and test the translatability of our work in stressed human islets. Our work will provide valuable insight on the molecular mechanisms of adaptive and maladaptive stress responses in β-cells during T1D progression and thus holds the potential to reveal new therapeutic strategies or targets for T1D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The outreach goal of the proposed research project is to develop a new combination of targeted drug delivery and immunotherapy for the treatment of advanced pancreatic cancer. Our innovative designs of tumor penetrating and immune modulating theranostic nanoparticles, coupled with a novel nanoparticle PD-L1 inhibitor (Nano-iPD-L1), enable efficient delivery of chemotherapy drugs and immunotherapy agents into stroma-rich pancreatic cancer tissues to destroy drug resistant tumor cells, modulate an immunosuppressive microenvironment into a pro-immune environment, and generate strong immune responses. Results of this translational research project have the potential for the development of a targeted and image-guided cancer therapy that significantly enhances therapeutic efficacy, and activates tumor specific immune response, and improves survival of pancreatic cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Treatment of urinary tract infections (UTI) is a major medical economic burden, and certain populations including diabetic women are at an increased risk of infection and severe complications. This proposal will investigate how dysfunctional metabolism in diabetes alters critical host antimicrobial defenses, bacterial virulence, and the vaginal microbiota, which frequently is a reservoir for uropathogens. These studies seek to understand the molecular mechanisms diminishing host defenses during metabolic disease to inform new therapeutic targets that can treat or prevent UTI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE: Although antimalarial drugs are critical for reducing disease incidence and transmission, resistance has emerged against every modern antimalarial drug within twelve years of clinical introduction, including to the current first-line artemisinin combination therapies (ACTs). This proposed study will apply two separate approaches to identify new drug targets for which parasite resistance would be unlikely to arise, opening new avenues for the development of long-lasting resistance-resistant antimalarial therapies. One approach will focus on identifying collateral sensitivities in parasites resistant to a wide range of drugs, while the second will identify host serum metabolites critical for asexual replication and production of transmission-competent Plasmodium falciparum parasites.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative/Public Health Relevance: Interdisciplinary, co-operative research to advance knowledge in the demography and economics of aging requires an adaptive scientific infrastructure. The Population Aging Studies Center at the University of Pennsylvania is an intellectual platform at the crucial juncture of the behav- ioral, social, and health sciences. The accounting and analytic frameworks of PARC, anchored in demography and health economics, provides insights to help meet the research and evidence needs to promote successful and equitable aging for individuals, and to inform effective health policy responses in aging societies, in the U.S. as well as globally.

The Population Aging Studies Center at the University of Pennsylvania, along with this Core A, provides an intellectual platform at the crucial juncture of the behavioral, social, and health sciences. The accounting and analytic frameworks of PARC, anchored in demography and health economics, provides insights to help meet the research and evidence needs to promote successful and equitable aging for individuals, and to inform effective health policy responses in aging societies, in the U.S. as well as globally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Eliminating racial and ethnic disparities in costly acute care utilization among Persons With Dementia (PWD) is a national priority. By studying these patients' communities and primary care practices where they receive care from nurse practitioners in a large national study, we will produce evidence to help design future systems and community interventions to ensure optimal care for minority elderly PWD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative/Public Health Relevance (Core D): Interdisciplinary, co-operative research to advance data- driven analysis in the demography and economics of aging requires significant investments in data and data security. The Population Aging Studies Center at the University of Pennsylvania, along with this Core D, provides the platform for dramatically increasing the availability and access to novel data and data linkages at the crucial juncture of the behavioral, social, and health sciences. At the same time, to speed the knowledge-transfer from social science to policy or stakeholders, Core D makes strategic investments in dissemination, expanding the skill sets of our associates as well as leveraging successful dissemination infrastructure to further PARC’s goal of informing effective health policy responses in aging societies, in the U.S. as well as globally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative 37.9 million people worldwide currently living with HIV/AIDS rely on costly lifelong cART treatment to suppress HIV replication and are at risk of non-AIDS comorbidities as they age. Thus, there is a pressing need to develop new strategies that induce long-term remission of HIV without the need for cART. This study will test a novel strategy that harnesses the transcriptional and epigenetic programs of stem-like CD8 T cells to enhance the efficacy of immunotherapies targeting the HIV reservoir and will lay the foundation for future therapies that achieve a cure for HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it develops a novel and innovative approach to cancer surgery. The main goal is to improve tumor and margin identification, thereby increasing the safety and completeness of surgery for neuroblastoma, to ultimately improve outcomes for the most common extracranial solid tumor in children. Importantly, successful completion of this work should invigorate further research in intraoperative molecular tracer development for other adult and pediatric cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer immunotherapy is curing some patients who previously had extremely poor prognosis, but many patients do not respond. A critical step for immune activation is for the correct T-cells to encounter cognate tumor antigen in tumor-draining lymph nodes. We propose to analyze this process using mathematical modeling and animal experiments to determine how these encounters between antigen and T-cells are impaired in cancer. We will use our analysis to identify strategies for enhancing immune activation in non-responding patients to improve effectiveness of immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ST. JOSEPH'S HOSPITAL AND MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative Based upon our novel findings that: 1) circulating exosomes released from lung transplant recipients (LTxRs) diagnosed with BOS induces epithelial mesenchymal transition of airway epithelial cells in an LKB1 dependent manner; and 2) our observed significant down regulation of LKB1 in the biopsies from LTxRs with BOS and inverse correlation with PDGFRβ. We will define the mechanism by which tumor suppressor, LKB1, participates in the development of chronic lung allograft dysfunction by determining signals leading to PDGFRβ upregulation and mechanisms leading to down regulation of LKB1. Studies proposed will employ both clinical samples from LTxRs and human airway epithelial cell culture models towards these goals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Pseudomonas aeruginosa (PA) keratitis is one of the most rapidly developing and destructive diseases of the cornea and a global cause of visual impairment and blindness. Emergence of antibiotic-resistant bacterial strains poses additional challenges for effective management of the disease and development of alternative treatment is in urgent need. This study will uncover the molecular mechanisms underlying the roles of the miR- 183/96/182 cluster (miR-183C) in PA keratitis and the protective effect of anti-miR-183C against the disease through miR-183C's regulation of corneal sensory nerve function and neuroimmune interaction in both mouse and human.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Because both high-level noise exposure and aging may lead to cochlear deafferentation, this type of “hidden” peripheral auditory damage has the potential to affect a large number of people and have a significant influence on public health. The proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH's mission that pertains to acquiring new knowledge to diagnose disability because it will form the basis for a clinical test battery for diagnosis of cochlear deafferentation and will clarify the perceptual impacts of this type of auditory dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic cancer the third deadliest cancer in the US. The KRAS oncogene is mutated in 95% of pancreatic cancers and anti-KRAS therapies are anticipated to make a significant impact on improving patient survival. I propose to develop therapies that block key ERK regulated proteins, which are critical for KRAS to drive metastatic pancreatic cancer growth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ovarian cancers have co-evolved with the patient’s immune system and build a complex tumor-immune microenvironment. As anti-PD1 immunotherapy has generally shown poor efficacy against ovarian cancers, there is a dire clinical need to complement checkpoint inhibition with treatments that stimulate infiltration or proliferation of tumor-specific TC’s. We propose an integrated experimental–mathematical oncology approach to decipher how to best harness immune sparing and immune stimulation of fractionated photoimmunotherapy to personalize treatments for advanced or recurrent epithelial ovarian cancer patients with presently dismal survival rates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project maps out the developmental trajectories of spatial hearing abilities in complex reverberant environments for school-age children with normal hearing. Findings of this work will provide intervention benchmarks to guide the fitting of bilateral hearing devices (e.g., cochlear implants and hearing aids) for children with hearing loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Parkinson’s disease (PD) is a prevalent neurodegenerative disease characterized by a hypokinetic movement disorder with symptoms of tremor, rigidity, and bradykinesia. The most common treatment for PD consists of dopamine replacement therapy utilizing either the dopamine precursor levodopa (L-DOPA) or dopamine receptor agonists. These therapies become unsatisfactory as the disease progresses due to a variety of short- term and long-term side effects that occur with dose escalation, including levodopa-induced dyskinesias (LID); therefore, there is an urgent need to develop non-dopaminergic therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative: Commensal fungi have emerged as an important player in the regulation of lung immunity and diseases, yet the mechanism(s) of the gut mycobiota (fungal community) directing gut-lung immune crosstalk has not been elucidated so far. Here, we propose to investigate the role of antifungal T cell response to gut fungi in airway inflammation that affects estimated millions of Americans. Understanding the role of gut mycobiota on the outcome of pulmonary disease and dissecting the mechanism(s) behind mycobiota-mediated lung immune regulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: This application is focused on understanding how severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV- 2), the causal agent of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), enters cells. Using unbiased genetic and optical tracking approaches we will interrogate the host factors that are used during entry and where the virus gains access to the cell. We will define where and how therapeutics that are in late stage clinical development including monoclonal antibodies, soluble receptor decoys, and small molecule inhibitors interrupt viral entry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: 8. Project Narrative The need for well-trained cancer biologists is more acute than ever with the growing impact of cancer on life and health. In this renewal application for our long-standing interdisciplinary Cancer Cell Biology Training Program for predoctoral students at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, we propose our vision for the training of cancer biologists who will be well prepared to contribute rigorously and effectively to the changing landscape of cancer biology, whether their future paths are in academic or non-academic careers.
