IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Pharmacies are nationally emerging as frontline public health practicing spaces due to their ubiquity, accessibility to medication and screening, and rapid scalability. Moreover, independent pharmacies are often located in under-resourced areas where corporate chains are typically absent, are ideal for public health interventions to reduce disparities (as previously evidenced), are more flexible, and can therefore be rapidly scaled up. Based on two decades of disparities-focused pharmacy-based intervention research, our team will investigate in-pharmacy delivery of opioid use disorder services (i.e., low-threshold access to telemedicine-based buprenorphine treatment initiation, naloxone dispensation/overdose prevention counseling) and HIV services access (i.e., HIV testing/ counseling, PrEP/PEP dispensation, HIV treatment re/initiation) among persons who use opioids.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The stress from cultural mismatch negatively disrupts overall wellness including health (self- reported mental/physical distress) and academics and may be directly linked to biological and clinical markers of health. Thus, there is a dire need to understand fundamental knowledge and mechanisms underlying cultural mismatch to inform interventions, programs and policies that can ensure health and educational equity for all. Cultural mismatch likely influences health in a variety of contexts or groups; thus, results from this work can aid in enhancing the health of society as a whole.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative We will study the impact of high and chronic pesticide exposures in a rural environment on the gut microbiome of Parkinson’s disease (PD) patients, their household members and healthy community controls and its contributions to progression of PD. This research will be highly efficient due to our access to an existing cohort of PD patients and unaffected community controls - who live in a heavily agriculturally pesticide exposed area of California – and a network of rural health care providers. Our research may discovery novel etiological pathways for pesticide action through the microbiome, propose interventions to prevent PD progression, and change public policy and pesticide regulations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The reprogramming of differentiated cells to induced pluripotent stem cells represents a remarkable reconfiguration of gene regulatory programs and provides the unprecedented ability to generate any type of human cell in unlimited amounts for therapeutic purposes and drug screening. The goal of this project is to identify the general principle regarding transcription factors remodeling cellular networks that define human cell identities. The results of this project will further reveal how human genetic variation affects the establishment and maintenance of the induced stem cell state.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative High-risk Acute Myeloid Leukemia and Myelodysplastic Syndrome are aggressive hematologic cancers associated with a very poor prognosis, with less than 20% of patients surviving beyond 1 year. Venetoclax, a BCL-2 inhibitor is one of the most exciting drugs in AML therapy. In this project we designed a Phase II clinical trial combining venetoclax with an optimized 10-day decitabine regimen in unfavorable risk categories of AML and MDS, with goals to improve outcomes of these patients by accelerating molecular responses and to further characterize molecular determinants of response and resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While many studies have performed analyses to define the ocular surface microbiome composition, there remain gaps in knowledge in regard to microbiome stability, the influence of factors like age, sex, and geographic location on microbiome make-up, and whether bacteria at the ocular surface are true ocular surface colonizers. This proposal is designed to increase resolution and confidence in determining bacteria that are true colonizers of the eye by revealing bacteria that are present at the ocular surface longitudinally and testing whether those bacteria stimulate human immune cells and/or can be introduced to and re-isolated from the ocular surface of mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In complex diseases like cancer, a single-adjuvant vaccine may not be fully effective to mitigate the myriad immunosuppressive effects of a heterogeneous aggressive tumor microenvironment such as that of triple- negative breast cancer. Co-delivery of multiple adjuvants in a rationally designed “super adjuvant” formulation can harness multiple pattern recognition receptor pathways simultaneously to drive a proinflammatory synergistic cytokine response that has both breadth and depth. Here we propose to design a tumor-targeted “super adjuvant” immunomodulatory nanoparticle platform for in situ cancer vaccination that coencapsulates 3 synergistic innate agonists of the STING, TLR4, and TLR9 pathways to promote Type I interferon-mediated anti-tumor immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: SAN FRANCISCO DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To help end the HIV epidemic, we will develop a new surveillance approach that will obtain early warning signs of outbreaks among people who inject drugs (PWID) in San Francisco and Alameda counties, California. A cohort of 600 PWID will be recruited from the community using outreach and peer referral. Each month, PWID will report on their experiences by smart phone or in-person interviews, including risk and preventive behaviors, use of services, and other events significant to the HIV and drug use epidemics in the US.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: This project will determine whether the newly discovered optic nerve laminar region- Neural progenitor cells (ONLR-NPCs) directly protect retinal ganglion cells (RGCs) from axonal ischemic stress, whether their loss increases RGC stress, and whether they partially effect their neuroprotective action through secreted extracellular vesicles. We will use a mouse transgenic model enabling selective ONLR-NPC depletion, the rodent model of non-arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (rNAION) in both mice and rats, and cell culture techniques, evaluating the effects of ONLR-NPC loss on RGC stress and loss, and determining whether direct administration of ONLR-NPC extracellular vesicles improve outcomes and begin identifying their components. Our findings will identify the factors that contribute to RGC stress and disease resistance and generate new, improved approaches to treatment of optic nerve diseases.

PHR: The project will advance the understanding of fundamental regulatory mechanisms that control embryonic development in a relatively simple invertebrate model system with favorable experimental advantages. Therefore, this project will facilitate the identification of therapeutic strategies relevant to modern medicine, particularly in the field of regenerative medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inhibitory receptors, like PD1, CTLA4 and LAG3, are overexpressed in chronic viral infections and cancer, preventing disease clearance, and are thus now major immunotherapeutic targets in the treatment of cancer. However, we still have a very limited understanding of how LAG3, the most recent inhibitory receptor to be targeted in the clinic, works. A greater understanding of the LAG3 mechanism of action may lead to the development of optimal antagonists for the treatment of chronic viral infections and cancer, and agonists for the treatment of autoimmune and inflammatory diseases.

PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator (Last, First, Middle): Durham, Paul, Louis NARRATIVE We have shown that dietary supplementation of a polyphenol-enriched grape seed extract inhibits expression of proteins implicated in chronic pain and enhances descending pain modulation pathways activated by opioids and cannabinoids. Our goal is to better understand the cellular and molecular changes within the nervous system mediated by grape seed extract to further validate its use as a safe and effective nutraceutical in a complementary and integrated therapeutic approach for chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: LOUISIANA STATE UNIV A&M COL BATON ROUGE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research investigates protein phase separation, a fundamental process underlying the formation of biomolecular condensates that are crucial for cellular functions and associated with age-related disorders. The study employs a model protein and polymer system as surrogates for proteins and nucleic acids, both are common precursors for biomolecular condensates. By examining the effects of a wide range of crowding agents commonly used to simulate the crowded environment within living cells, this study aims at elucidating the effects of crowding on the conformation and intermolecular interactions of protein and polymer molecules, and to establish connections between the molecular-level information and the bulk phase behavior of proteins. Collectively, our research will provide a comprehensive, molecular-level understanding of protein phase behavior in cell-like environments, thereby advancing the fields of biophysics and cellular biology, and opening new avenues for therapeutic development in diseases related to abnormal protein phase separation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Parkinson’s disease (PD) is a prevalent neurodegenerative disease characterized by a hypokinetic movement disorder with symptoms of tremor, rigidity, and bradykinesia. The most common treatment for PD consists of dopamine replacement therapy utilizing either the dopamine precursor levodopa (L-DOPA) or dopamine receptor agonists. These therapies become unsatisfactory as the disease progresses due to a variety of short- term and long-term side effects that occur with dose escalation, including levodopa-induced dyskinesias (LID); therefore, there is an urgent need to develop non-dopaminergic therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Public Health Relevance. The proposed Center addresses the need to strengthen the capacity of informal caregivers of persons living with Alzheimer’s and similar illnesses to provide guidance and care to those individuals and, therefore, enable them to live in the community and not in institutional settings for as long as possible. Addressing the need to promote caregiving mastery in heterogeneous caregiving contexts is central to the quality of life of those living with these illnesses and may contribute to restraining the growth in health care expenditure associated with them. The Center will support the design, development, implementation, and stage-advancement of mechanism-based behavioral intervention clinical trials, especially stage I and II trials, proposed by researchers across the country and aimed at specific caregiving contexts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Although peritoneal metastasis is one of the most lethal forms of colorectal cancer progression, with few treatment options available to affected patients, little is known about the origins and the biology of the disease. With a strong inter-disciplinary team consisting of clinicians, geneticists and computational biologists, we propose to investigate the paths by which peritoneal metastases are seeded, what their genetic characteristics are, and how their microenvironment correlates with disease progression. Results from this study will provide a much-needed rational basis for the development of new surgical and medical treatment approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Overall Narrative Our proposed UIC Midwest Roybal Center for Health Promotion and Translation seeks to turn the findings of behavioral research interventions into real-world ways of improving the physical and brain health and quality of life of older adults at risk of Alzheimer’s Disease and Alzheimer’s Disease Related Dementias (AD/ADRD). Our renewal Center will continue to design interventions for older racial/ethnic minority adults while expanding our focus to reach those at risk of AD/ADRD using interventions that address brain health. This renewal application has four focus areas: 1) develop and test interventions to increase physical activity among older adults at risk of ADRD; 2) design interventions to maintain or improve brain health and mobility; 3) use technology to improve intervention delivery and quality; and 4) target mechanisms of behavior change to foster lasting lifestyle change.

PHR: Behavioral Intervention Development (BID) Core Narrative Our proposed UIC Midwest Roybal Center for Health Promotion and Translation seeks to turn the findings of behavioral research interventions into real-world ways of improving the physical and brain health and quality of life of older adults at risk of Alzheimer's Disease and Alzheimer's Disease Related Dementias (AD/ADRD). Our BID Core will enable us to achieve that goal by identifying talented investigators and providing them with mentoring, support, and incentives that will enable them to test impactful interventions. Interventions that we support will be highly feasible for immediate translation and implementation into practice while advancing science in our areas of thematic focus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The program aims to understand how protein splicing enzymes, or inteins, conditionally catalyze the splicing reaction under environmental cues of salinity, redox state, temperature, or pressure. Given that inteins are used in protein engineering and as biosensors, this understanding of their structure and function could lead to development of better tools for biomedical research. The program also aims to develop small molecule inhibitors of the splicing process, which could lead to the discovery of drugs that block the activity of key proteins in pathogenic fungi and mycobacteria as well as environmentally toxic cyanobacteria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Schistosomiasis is a devastating snail-transmitted parasitic disease of poverty that inﬂicts over 250 million people around the globe. Although host-seeking and infection of snails by larval parasites is a critical chokepoint for the parasite life cycle, the behavioral details and molecular determinants of this process are poorly described, limiting novel approaches for disease control strategies that could target the snail-infective stage. Using cutting-edge experimental technologies and advanced analytical tools, we will describe the snail cues and parasite behaviors that lead to snail infection, setting the stage for high-throughput screening regimens that discover new chemicals for parasite control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to delineate the signaling mechanisms that regulate early processes necessary for the typical development of the cortex. The proposed research has implications for understanding the underlying causes of intellectual disability, which is a core feature of numerous human neurodevelopmental syndromes. This project also supports the inclusive training of undergraduate and graduate students focused on neuroscience and neurodevelopment research at UNLV, which is consistently ranked as one of the nation’s most diverse campuses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – OVERALL Given the continued high prevalence and burden of pain in older people, and the movement away from primary reliance on pharmacological interventions to treat pain, it is crucially important to develop and test treatment alternatives. This proposal seeks to address this need by developing behavioral interventions to mitigate later- life pain with a goal of increasing the health and well being of older adults adversely affected by pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project seeks to understand the genetics behind unique eye morphologies in cave populations of the crustacean Asellus aquaticus. This information will give us a better understanding of the process of eye degeneration by showing whether eye degeneration is linked to other morphologies and by mapping regions responsible for naturally occurring variation in eye size in multiple eyeless lineages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This project focuses on the socioeconomic impact of neuroinvasive/non-neuroinvasive La Crosse virus disease (most common cause of arboviral pediatric encephalitis in the United States) in western North Carolina. Economic wellbeing may contribute to disparities in risk awareness, adherence to personal protection, and clinical recognition and this relationship will be verified, along with site assessments of mosquito-related risks. Findings are expected to contribute to the development of public/environmental health strategies to intervene to improve risk reduction, treatment, and recovery resources, thereby reducing impact on survivors and families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative: Overall The increasing aging population is accompanied by a comparable increase in those who will suffer cognitive impairment, which impacts quality of life for the individual, and at scale, impacts every sector of society. Therefore, maintaining or improving cognition in aged adults at risk of dementia, even for a few months, could have an important effect at the population level. To achieve this, the Roybal Center will conduct Stage 0 through V pilot studies in accordance with the multidirectional, translational NIH Stage Model, to produce potent and implementable principle-driven behavioral interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative The USC-Yale Roybal Center for Behavioral Interventions in Aging aims to improve the general effectiveness of behavioral interventions that address over- and underused health services in aging populations by clarifying their mechanisms of behavior change. The Center will support a Behavioral Interventions Development Core for research and an Administrative Core that oversees all Center activities. The Center will sustain and grow the community of researchers conducting mechanism of behavior change research to encourage appropriate use of medical treatments that affect people aging through the lifespan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: 8. Project Narrative The Department of Ophthalmology and Visual Sciences at the University of Illinois at Chicago (UIC) is proposing to continue their K12 independent clinical vision scientist career development program. This program which has been successful in the past 12 years, aims to provide an academically-rich and supportive environment for early -stage clinicians in a mentored learning experience that facilitates their career advancement in becoming independent vision scientists. By training clinician- vision scientists who will engage in cutting edge eye research, this program will contribute to the improvement of eye health for the society.

PHR: Project Narrative Most adults will experience serious health events in their lifetime, and these events will commonly result in psychological distress that impacts on quality of life and health behaviors that are needed to promote recovery and prevent recurrent events. Our Columbia Roybal Center for Fearless Behavior Change will advance mechanism-driven interventions that target psychological distress and assess whether better health behaviors result. Our existing research infrastructure inclusive of a common measures repository for mechanisms assessment, a standardized electronic assessment suite for behavior, implementation science expertise, and strong collaborations with patient stakeholders and scientific experts in the experimental medicine approach to behavioral intervention development will ensure that the trials conducted in our Center are well-positioned to yield impactful interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Teachers are at notable risk for depression and anxiety. The present study tests an app-based mindfulness intervention for teachers in their final year of training with the goal of preventing the deterioration of their mental health during the transition into the classroom. The project will strengthen the research environment at the University of Alabama and will involve undergraduate research assistants in each step of the research process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative-Overall  The primary objective of the Establishing Mechanisms of Benefit to Reinforce the Alzheimer’s Care Experience AD/ADRD Roybal Center (EMBRACE) is to provide scientific infrastructure to support the testing of mechanisms in tailored home and community dementia care intervention trials across Stages 0-V of the NIH Stage Model. The Aims of EMBRACE are as follows: 1) Leverage the extensive expertise of EMBRACE to attract and support early stage to expert Investigators to test mechanistically driven dementia care interventions across the NIH Stage Model; 2) Advance the science of testing mechanisms of tailored dementia care interventions in home and community settings; and 3) Conduct a robust evaluation of EMBRACE to ensure appropriate progress of supported trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Diagnosis and treatment for neurodegenerative diseases remain insufficient to halt disease progression and improve patient outcomes. In order to find new drug targets and biomarkers, it will be important to identify the genetic pathways, molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying degeneration. We propose to use a genetic approach to identify the signaling network functioning downstream of Tau.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The positive emotional affects of opioid use and negative emotional effects of withdrawal contribute to the development of Opioid Use Disorder, which accounts for tens of thousands of deaths in the United States each year. This project will use mouse models of morphine reward, fentanyl consumption, and naloxone-precipitated withdrawal to investigate how mu-opioid receptors on a subpopulation of neurons in the nucleus accumbens promote opioid reward and aversion. Understanding the neural mechanisms responsible for Opioid Use Disorder will inform future therapies and treatments for the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lack of remyelination results in axonal degeneration and debilitating clinical outcomes in demyelinating diseases like Multiple Sclerosis. Here, we propose to determine how TGFβ1 signaling regulates remyelination through Gpnmb, a novel modulator of the pathway, expressed highly in response to demyelination in neural stem cells. These studies will help to determine new strategies for promoting remyelination in the diseased human brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aging is the number one risk factor associated with disease in the United States. Although we take this granted, genetic discoveries over the last few decades suggest that it is possible to directly intervene on the aging process itself, to date it has been very difficult to look for new mutations affecting aging and longevity because individuals at extreme old age tend to be past the ability to reproduce, even in model organisms. This work aims to expand new genome editing technology to rapidly produce and identify mutations that enhance longevity in post-reproductive individuals, setting the stage for future development of drugs and other interventions aimed at extending health aging in all people.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Oxidative stress is a convergent endpoint for a number of human diseases and conditions such as cancer, aging, and neurodegeneration. The roles of sulfur-containing molecules that make up the thiolome are emerging as a mechanism for cells to counteract the deleterious impact of oxidative stress. This study investigates the role(s) of mitoNEET’s enzymatic activity on maintaining the cellular thiolome in order to combat oxidative stress found in so many human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Neuronal mechanisms that control selective behavioral attention to sensory cues have been a long-standing mystery. Hunger is a powerful motivational state that enhances attraction to food odors but not other olfactory cues through a Neuropeptide Y spotlight; thirst instead enhances attraction to drink odors, but neuronal mechanisms involved remain mysterious. Here, we leverage key molecular features of olfactory subcircuits to investigate (1) how various sensory inputs are distinctly represented in the brain, and (2) how two distinct physiological states- hunger and thirst- differentially influence sensory responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Physical activity is a modifiable health behavior that is among the most promising strategies for slowing cognitive decline and preventing Alzheimer’s Disease and related dementias. Although many strategies have been developed to promote physical activity in midlife and older adults, little is known about how to maintain behavior change following the end of a behavioral intervention. This Center will apply an experimental medicine approach to develop interventions that engage the targets that support long-term maintenance of behavior change and enhance cognitive function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will interrogate a novel cell population identified in the developing human lung, referred to as Fetal Airway Secretory (FAS) cells, that are marked by SCGB3A2/SFTPB/CFTR. Since nothing is known about FAS cells, and there is no analogous population in the murine lung, the overarching goal of this proposal is to use an in vitro model of FAS differentiation to describe these cells in detail, to interrogate their differentiation potential, and to determine how they are regulated, thereby providing foundational descriptive and mechanistic insights into a new cell type in the human lung.

PROJECT_TITLE: Functional interrogation of a novel SCGB3A2+/SFTPB+ cell in the human airway

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to build a Diversity Center for Genome Research at Florida International University (FIU), which is the largest federally designated Hispanic-Serving Institution in the continental U.S. and one of the largest Minority-Serving Institution (MSI). The objectives of this proposal are consistent with the goals of the NIH full-scale Diversity Centers for Genome Research (DCGR) program and will have a significant impact on public health by providing cutting-edge genomic research projects, capacity building, and training in genomics at FIU. This multi-departmental project conducted by a diverse team of highly educated and experienced specialists will provide training and scholarship opportunities to 24 dual enrollment, undergraduate and masters students; training and graduate assistantships to 10 doctoral students; and pilot project grants to 15 early-stage investigators (assistant professors or postdoctoral fellows).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: We propose to develop a series of interactive content and video modules on program evaluation that can be used synchronously or asynchronously to train faculty and lead administrators in the biomedical sciences in effective and equitable evaluation of training programs. We further propose to test our content in five institutions, including an HBCU, with project-trained facilitators leading local learning communities. Our ultimate goal is to instill cycles of improvement based on a deeper understanding of trainee attitudes, behaviors and outcomes and thereby continue to shift the focus of all 1000+ biomedical training programs toward a trainee-centered learning environment, a process started by NIGMS 5 years ago.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project is relevant to public health because a fundamental understanding of second-line responses of macrophages to Group A Streptococcus will inform alternative means of treatment directed at enhancing the cellular response, toward the goal of limiting antibiotic usage. The proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission to enhance health and reduce the burdens of illness. The proposed research will be performed primarily by undergraduate students, achieving the objectives of the AREA program by engaging undergraduate students in biomedical research and encouraging them to consider careers in biomedical sciences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Data support the notion that critical events during pubertal mammary development may influence the breast microenvironment to increase breast cancer risk and promote tumor growth. Advanced glycation end-products (AGEs) are reactive metabolites produced during normal metabolism. Critically, disease states and lifestyle factors such as a sedentary lifestyle, obesity and poor diet increase AGE levels in the body. Our studies indicate that a high AGE diet during puberty disrupts mammary gland development to leave structures in the breast indicative of pre-neoplastic lesions. The objective of this study is to examine if increases in AGE levels during puberty represents a critical event during mammary development that increases future breast cancer risk and promotes tumor growth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Disease or damage to the cerebellum results in a loss of motor coordination and motor learning. This proposal will broaden our understanding of the function of cerebellar output and how it contributes to the learning of new movements. The findings from this study with provide further insight into mechanisms of sensorimotor control to aid in the development of novel therapies for patients with movement disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Risky drinking and alcohol use disorders (AUDs) have serious impacts on health and safety. Development of effective means to prevent negative consequences of heavy drinking, treat AUDs, and better understand the mechanisms that underlie behavior change have the potential to improve individual lives and enhance societal functioning. The proposed training program draws on multiple disciplines to prepare a new generation of researchers to investigate the psychological, social, and biological mechanisms that underpin processes of change; apply this knowledge to developing and testing new models for prevention and treatment; and apply these models to underserved populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT ABSTRACT Opioid misuse and its associated risks of suicide is a national public health emergency. Current estimates suggest that chronic pain impacts nearly half of Veterans, and studies have shown that people who experience chronic pain are at increased risk for a number of adverse health outcomes, including suicide and opioid overdose. Although multiple national initiatives within the Veterans Health Administration (VHA) have attempted to decrease the number of veterans with opioid prescriptions for pain management, these efforts focus on analyzing VA data only. Given that many Veterans receive care and treatment from non-VA community clinics and medical centers, it is imperative to study suicide or accidental overdose risk amongst Veterans with pain disorders by analyzing both VA and non-VA data. The overall objective of this proposal is to integrate large-scale VA and non-VA data across New York, Chicago and Florida to study the risk of suicidal ideation, suicide attempts, suicide and accidental opioid overdose deaths in Veterans receiving chronic opioid therapy (COT).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite an increased understanding of the epidemiology of HPV+ HNC, the incidence of this cancer is rapidly rising and predictive biomarkers to guide treatment as well as HPV-selective therapies are lacking. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease (CVD) accounts for significant morbidity and mortality among persons living with HIV (PWH), even with sustained virologic suppression on modern antiretroviral therapy (ART). The gut mucosa is a key reservoir and site of ongoing immune dysregulation in ART-treated PWH. Using complementary expertise in HIV reservoirs and comorbidities, basic virology/immunology, and cardiovascular clinical/translational research, we propose to define how gut HIV persistence promotes mucosal immune dysregulation and bacterial translocation to drive inflammation and subclinical CVD, providing a framework to identify new therapeutic targets.

PHR: NARRATIVE: Our proposed studies will investigate the mechanism by which BMAL1, alpha-1 antitrypsin, and cathepsin B regulate proteolysis and activity of the renal epithelial sodium channel and association with MARCKS protein leading to alterations in sodium retention and blood pressure as a function of time. The successful completion of these studies will help us understand mechanisms associated with sodium transport and blood pressure control over a 24 hour cycle and should result in the identification of novel drug targets and therapeutics for essential hypertension.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescent Wellness Visits in Tanzania: Bundling evidence-based prevention services to increase uptake of HIV Testing and Counseling and other health services Adolescents are less likely to access prevention-oriented health services such as HIV testing and counseling (HTC) and contraception than adults, yet young people bear a disproportion burden of poor HIV and reproductive health outcomes in many low-resource settings. This study evaluates a new service delivery platform for reaching adolescents in Tanzania with HTC and other evidence-based screening services via clinic-based ‘Adolescent Wellness Visits’ coordinated between primary schools and health facilities that offer a package of youth-friendly services. We posit that by coupling sexual and reproductive health (SRH) services with non- SRH services such as nutrition, vision, dental and mental health screenings, applicable for all adolescents, adolescent health service use including HTC will increase and a tone will be set for a ‘culture of health and wellness’ during this critical developmental period.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: To examine the effectiveness of an evidence-based and culturally-grounded stress-reduction intervention (i.e., the A-CWS), facilitated by indigenous social workers, to increase adaptive coping and reduce active suicidal ideation in African American 9th graders. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE CAR T-cell immunotherapy has emerged as a successful therapy for relapsed and refractory leukemia, yet the patients' responses remains variable and unpredictable. Preclinical evaluation of CAR T-cells, as well as understanding how CAR T-cells dynamically interact with its neighbors via secretion of a broad range of functional cytokines can help improve the clinical outcomes of CAR T-cell immunotherapy. Herein, we will first propose the integration of novel nanoplasmon ruler sensor and microfluidic microwell array into a multi- parametric single-cell cytokine secretion and crosstalk analysis for preclinical evaluation and optimization of CAR T-cell immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / RELEVANCE The Dietary Guidelines for Americans is the cornerstone of nutrition policy in the U.S., impacting WIC and other Federal nutrition assistance programs, health insurance incentives, weight and lifestyle interventions, policies to change the food environment, and nutrition education programs at the national, regional, state and local levels. This project will inform the next edition of the Dietary Guidelines by using cutting-edge analytic approaches to identify diet patterns that promote healthy outcomes of pregnancy. Although the causes of poor pregnancy outcomes are multifactorial, we focus on dietary intake because it is one of the few potentially modifiable risk factors, and has important implications for mother and child well beyond the childbearing years.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intracellular bacterial pathogens spread between host cells by targeting molecules critical to intercellular communication. Some forms of intercellular communication use membrane remodeling, mechanosensitive, and endocytic machinery to transfer cargo and exchange information between cells; processes that are still poorly understood, but are critical for development, tissue homeostasis, and barrier formation. This project will examine how a microbe hijacks these host pathways as it spreads through tissues, which will uncover fundamental mechanisms of host-microbe interactions, and reveal insights into the regulation of intercellular communication during normal or diseased states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Patients with hearing loss who use cochlear implants (CIs) show significant deficits and strong unexplained intersubject variability in their perception and production of spoken emotions in speech. This project will investigate the hypothesis that “cue-weighting”, or how patients utilize the different acoustic cues to emotion, accounts for significant variance in emotional communication with CIs. The results will focus on children with CIs, but parallel measures in postlingually deaf adults with CIs will be made, ensuring that results of these studies benefit social communication by CI patients across the lifespan by informing the development of technological innovations and improved clinical protocols.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rotator cuff tears are a common source of pain and disability in the upper extremity. MRI is commonly used to evaluate rotator cuff pathology and to determine the treatment strategy, but the re-tear rate after surgical repairs is high, up to 57% in elderly patients. Here, we propose development of new, quantitative MRI techniques to evaluate degenerative changes in the rotator cuff tendons and muscles comprehensively, which may help to understand the process of rotator cuff muscle and tendon degeneration, to assess healing effects after surgery, and eventually to determine the optimal treatment strategy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transport inside cells is driven by molecular machines called dynein and kinesin, which move along cellular tracks called microtubules. Defects in the transport machinery cause neurodegenerative and neurodevelopmental diseases in humans. This research will provide key mechanistic insights into how these machines work and how they are regulated to move dozens of cargos.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative: Bronchopulmonary dysplasia remains a significant complication of prematurity, particularly extremely preterm infants and its management often includes the administration of systemic glucocorticoids (sGC), mainly dexamethasone (Dex). However, sGC therapy has been shown to carry significant concerns in neonates for not only short-term systemic side effects, but also detrimental long-term impact on structural brain development. This study seeks to determine whether the sGC prodrug, ciclesonide (CIC), will attenuate hyperoxia-mediated acute lung injury in neonates but NOT trigger the demyelination, astrogliosis, microglia activation or neuronal damage in neonatal brain caused by systemically administered sGCs such as Dex.

PHR: Hexokinase 2 (HK2), which catalyzes the first committed step in glucose metabolism, is not expressed in most normal tissues but is expressed at high level in cancer cells to accelerate glucose metabolism. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ubiquitin is a crucial post-translational modifier that regulates a great deal of eukaryotic cell physiology. This project aims to identify and structurally characterize ubiquitin-dependent protein-protein interactions. In doing so, this study will address a gap in current knowledge on how ubiquitin can mediate noncovalent regulation, interact with ubiquitin receptors, and reveal the structural basis of (poly)ubiquitination in the efforts to define its larger role in human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The complex protein-based network that surrounds living cells, the extracellular matrix, is in many ways as important to organismal development and health as the cells themselves. Produced and continually modified by the underlying cells, the extracellular matrix provides structural support and conveys a wide range of information affecting nearly all aspects of cell behavior. Our studies seek to identify and characterize the genes and cellular processes responsible for generating, maintaining, and modifying this matrix, thereby revealing underlying mechanisms governing human development and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Many breast cancer survivors (estimated 70% in some studies) experience clinically significant depression and/or anxiety in the months and years after finishing cancer treatments. This research will build on the rigor of prior research to reduce breast cancer survivor depression and anxiety with a compassion meditation intervention called CBCT (Cognitively-Based Compassion Training) for online synchronous delivery that is also inclusive of informal caregivers (i.e., adult family members who live with and typically provide half the care for survivors).

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH The Knockout Mouse Phenotyping Program (KOMP2) seeks to create an encyclopedia of gene function for the ~20,000 genes in the mouse and to ultimately create a resource for understanding gene function in humans. The Jackson Laboratory (JAX) KOMP2 Phase 3 Center will contribute to this goal by efficiently generating and characterizing knockout lines and sharing functional data for 600 mouse genes. The JAX team will enhance the value of these data by linking them with current genetic and biological knowledge, enabling the scientific community to discover the roles of these genes in human health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Kidney cancer can run in families; however, in most families with multiple cases of kidney cancer, a specific causative gene cannot be identified. The goals of this project are to determine if inherited mutations in a gene called KEAP1 increases the likelihood of developing kidney cancer and to determine whether kidney cancers with mutations in KEAP1 may behave differently than other kidney cancers. A better understanding of the role of KEAP1 and other genes in the development of kidney cancers may lead to earlier identification of kidney cancers through screening and to better therapies for patients with kidney cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this new T32 program is to provide postdoctoral training in embedded mental health services research leveraging the established infrastructure across the Mental Health Research Network (MHRN), a practice-based research network. The proposed program will offer postdoctoral fellows training and mentorship led by scientists embedded within MHRN health systems in close collaboration with stakeholders. During the 5- year award period, a total of 10 postdoctoral fellows will complete 2-year training programs, including didactics in health services research and mental health disorders, tailored mentorship in grant writing, professional development, project leadership, and multi-site research collaboration, and opportunities to conduct research and participate in ongoing activities across MHRN, in preparation for independent careers with the necessary training to conduct NIH-supported embedded mental health services research.
PROJECT_TERMS: Health system;Mental Health Services;Postdoctoral Fellow;Research Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Embedded Mental Health Services Postdoctoral Research Training in Health Systems

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This project is relevant to public health because the development of tools and acquisition of knowledge related to bacterial trehalose metabolism will support the development of new strategies to detect and treat bacterial infections. This project focuses on an important class of trehalose-utilizing bacteria, mycobacteria, which include the tuberculosis-causing pathogen that kills 1.5 million people per year. Thus, this research is relevant to NIH’s mission in that its contributions in terms of technology and fundamental knowledge are ultimately expected to help understand and combat bacterial pathogens that have a major impact on human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Myeloproliferative disorders (MPNs) are chronic bone marrow stem cell disorders that can lead to significant symptoms including abnormal blood counts, an enlarged spleen, and, in advanced cases, significantly shortened survival. While currently available treatments alleviate symptoms, they can have serious adverse effects, and do not significantly alter the course of the disease. To address this critical problem, we propose to develop AB062, a liver-targeted thrombopoietin gene antisense oligonucleotide (THPO-ASO) drug candidate that could provide a safer novel pharmacological treatment that may be able to alter the natural disease course for this small but severely ill patient population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Racial/ethnic disparities are still prevalent for maternal and infant outcomes, and popular programs for vulnerable populations involve resource-intensive home visits or non-personalized health information materials. We propose the development of a chatbot that addresses both of these possible limitations by representing a scalable tool that can have widespread reach across geographies and is personalized and responsive to an individual’s specific informational needs. Results from our project can be utilized to inform strategies to reduce health disparities by lowering barriers to timely and verified health information.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The autonomic innervation of the heart provides regulatory roles in heart function. Here, we propose to develop a 3D microphysiological co-culture platform to better understand fundamental aspects of sympatho-cardiac interaction and reciprocal regulation and growth of cardiac and autonomic cells. We will also establish a human model of cardiac muscle disease with sympathetic neurons, which will provide novel insights into understanding neuromodulation of cardiac pathogenesis.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We will investigate the contribution of structural racism to mortality among Black, Hispanic/Latino, Japanese American, and Native Hawaiian adults, leveraging the well-characterized and racial/ethnically and socioeconomically diverse Multiethnic Cohort Study in Southern California and Hawaii. New measures of structural racism including variables from housing, education, employment, criminal justice, political participation, and healthcare will be developed to reflect experiences of each racial/ethnic group.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because, while bacterial small RNAs (sRNAs) have been implicated in bacterial pathogenicity, much remains to be learned about their mechanisms of action and dependence on chaperone proteins. This work will uncover a wealth of fundamental biological knowledge about the mechanisms of bacterial RNA chaperone proteins, laying the foundation for them to serve as future targets for novel antibiotics. Thus, the project is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to reducing illness and to the specific interest of the Institute of General Medical Sciences in understanding noncoding RNA mechanisms of action and function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A growing number of studies suggest that increasing dietary protein intake and lowering the dietary acid load of the diet improves markers of muscle health in older adults. This proposal describes a study designed to determine whether adding an alkaline salt, potassium bicarbonate, to reduce the dietary acid load of a high protein diet can further enhance the beneficial impact of a high protein diet alone on muscle performance and mass. Understanding whether high protein and alkali supplementation have an additive benefit to muscle in older adults is critically important in moving the field forward towards development of innovative therapeutic approaches to reduce the physical disability in our aging society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Adipose tissue turnover plays a critical role in body weight maintenance, and obesity is underscored by the dysregulated balance between fat breakdown and synthesis. Although there are clear health-related benefits of physical activity, little is known about how resistance exercise, as opposed to endurance exercise, can reduce the risk of metabolic disorders, particularly in women. The goal of the proposed study is to investigate the effectiveness of resistance training to improve basal and stimulated fat metabolism in postmenopausal women with obesity and pre-diabetes, potentially serving as a viable and practical approach to prevent the onset of type 2 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Despite tremendous progress in our understanding of peroxisomal matrix and membrane protein import and the machinery involved in these aspects of peroxisome biogenesis, we know little about how this organelle is formed de novo. This proposal will define and characterize the genes/proteins involved in this process, study the functions of a subset of both new and known proteins in peroxisome biogenesis, and also define the mechanism of how mitochondrial metabolites and energy production influence peroxisome proliferation. Although our work uses yeast models, we expect the outcomes to be relevant to human peroxisome biogenesis disorders, because the processes we are investigating are conserved in evolution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Treatment of pain remains a major unmet need. Opiates continue to be useful pharmacotherapy for treatment of moderate to chronic pain but suffer from severe side effects that has led to an epidemic in America. The development of safe, effective and well-tolerated pain medications without side effects based on delta opioid receptors will be a major advancement in the treatment of pain that would greatly enhance both quality and length of life of patients both in the US and worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative The emergency department (ED) provides care for patients with alcohol use disorders (AUD) and a variety of problems including illness, injury, or alcohol-related complication, creating a unique environment to intervene, enhance motivation, and initiate treatment among treatment and non-treatment seeking patients. This project is designed to test two clinically relevant ED-initiated treatment models for patients with alcohol use disorders (AUD) with facilitated referal and direct linkage to ongoing treatment. Our two models include currently underutilized psychosocial and pharmacological interventions with referral for continuation AUD treatment with the goal of promoting ongoing treatment engagement and less heavy drinking days.

PHR: Project Narrative: This program will provide unique research training experiences in infectious, developmental, and degenerative nervous system diseases. By combining cross-disciplinary team-mentored training in the immune-brain axis, the next generation of neuroscientists can incorporate multidisciplinary approaches towards that enable breakthrough advances. This is done to develop state-of-the-art diagnostic and therapeutic disease interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While advances in developmental biology and genetics have significantly improved our understanding of the basic signals that direct development and repair of the lung, targeted treatments for lung diseases remain limited. How tightly our genetic material is packaged in a structure called chromatin is emerging as means by which basic signals are integrated during development to direct lung formation and repair. By understanding the mechanisms by which PRDM3/16 regulates chromatin accessibility during lung development and lung injury, we aim to provide a foundation for the development of targeted strategies to modulate the epigenome to treat lung diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Dental fear negatively affects the health of over 53 million American adults. Standard dental treatment (anti-anxiety medication or anesthesia) is compassionate but maintains the cycle of fear and avoidance; psychological treatments are effective but are rarely available and not easily disseminated. We will test a highly disseminable stepped-care approach, comprising a low intensity level (app + worksheet to foster dentist-patient communication around fear) and higher intensity level (for those needing more intensive treatment — 1- or 2-hours of in-person fear treatment from a mental health professional performed in the dentist's office).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The majority of health care appointments in the United States end with at least one prescription being written for the patient, but doctors may not have the necessary tools to chose the best medication and dose for any given disease or condition. The overarching goal of this proposal is to develop improved strategies that better inform clinicians on how to prescribe therapy that maximizes efficacy and minimizes harm based on the unique characteristics (demographics, genes, environment, and lifestyle) of a given patient. To do this, we will study past electronic health records from hundreds of thousands of patients to observe how they responded to drug therapy and look for patterns that link unique characteristics to favorable outcomes after taking a given medication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The feasibility and clinical benefit of using a patient’s genotype to guide antiplatelet therapy prescribing decisions has been recently demonstrated. However, a more precise understanding of who to genotype, what to include on a genetic testing panel, and how to change antiplatelet therapy based on genotype results and other patient-specific factors is essential in order to optimize the impact of genotype-guided antiplatelet therapy on patient outcomes. Completion of this research project will elucidate the key factors that influence outcomes with a genotype-guided precision medicine approach to antiplatelet therapy, and establish optimal strategies that improve outcomes with this approach in a diverse, real-world setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Narrative: Public Health Relevance Atrial fibrillation (AF) is one of the most common heart diseases in the US. It is currently treated with radiofrequency ablation (RFA), but the 1-year recurrence rate is high (30-50%). We aim to create a multi-modal feedback-based navigation system and MR-compatible robotic platform that enables precise, continuous, and durable ablation lesion creation during MR-guided RFA for improved AF treatment

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The need for well-trained investigators in the field of cardiovascular medicine is the justification for this program's existence and continuation. There are too few rigorously-trained cardiovascular investigators to take advantage of today's enormous growth in genetics, imaging, and technological advances. Since this program was first funded in 1984, the University of Utah has successfully trained over 110 cardiovascular investigators and is well-equipped to continue this success.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early atrophic age-related macular degeneration (AMD) represents an important time window in the course of so far untreatable atrophic AMD, as patients typically experience only some degree of visual dysfunction, while being at significant risk for marked further loss of vision. To allow the precise evaluation of upcoming therapeutic interventions, a better understanding of the manifestation and variable disease progression is needed. This project aims to investigate refined tools to detect and monitor early atrophic AMD more accurately, including the impact on visual dysfunction and quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Biomedical research now requires the use of computational methods and systems models to (i) process the large data current technologies generate, (ii) integrate different data types into a cohesive picture of the biological processes that are studied, (iii) test hypotheses about how the biological processes function, and (iv) generate new, testable hypotheses that further our biological understanding. Scientists that can develop and use these computational methods and systems models require cross-disciplinary training in collaboration, scientific rigor, and quantitative methods. The Systems & Biomolecular Data Sciences training program brings together 12 degree-granting programs and 34 faculty mentors across the UVA Schools of Medicine, Engineering, Data Science, and Arts & Sciences to prepare this next generation of transdisciplinary biomedical scientists at the interface of quantitative biology, systems biology, machine learning, and informatics.
PROJECT_TERMS: Data Science;System;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Interdisciplinary Training in Systems & Biomolecular Data Science
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Training and Workforce Development Study Section - B[TWD-B]

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: One hundred and fifty infant, under 2 years of age, with cerebral palsy, will be enrolled from 3 regions of the USA and randomized to receive intervention focused on motor-based problem solving or motor skills using normalized movement patterns. The interventions are dose (24 visits over 3 months), provider (physical therapists), and setting (home) matched to allow for direct comparison of the principles of the intervention. Outcomes including change in sitting ability, motor and cognitive development will be assessed at 3, 6, 9, and 12 months after enrollment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Some pulmonary diseases occur disproportionately or almost exclusively in women, such as pulmonary LAM. Yet, the underlying mechanisms of specifically women’s susceptibility to LAM are still not been understood. Our current study of LAM lung cell composition and novel LAM-relevant genetic animal model lay the groundwork for developing a novel mechanistic understanding of LAM involving mTORC1-WNT signaling crosstalk and provide essential knowledge towards expanding effective therapy for this devastating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE: Approximately one third of non-hospitalized COVID-19 patients report persistent symptoms after recovering from the acute stage of SARS-CoV-2 infection, with common complaints of “brain fog” and objective cognitive deficits. This project examines whether this post-acute COVID-19 syndrome involves dysfunctions in brain vasculature and the gut, as well as how such dysfunctions relate to chronic cognitive symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative These studies will provide novel insights into the regulatory mechanism of chitinase 1 (Chit1) in the pathogenesis of pulmonary fibrosis, a devastating lung disease with few therapeutic options. They will investigate mechanism and therapeutic effect of Kasugamycin, a small molecule with strong anti-chitinase and anti-fibrotic activities, using animal models of pulmonary fibrosis. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH's mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge that helps to reduce the burdens of human disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative! The proposed research aims to customize treatment and thereby improve clinical outcomes for African American (AA) patients with an aggressive type of breast cancer to which they are predisposed called triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC). This project will advance knowledge about how to customize treatment for AA TNBC patients by validating whether a novel protein biomarker, nuclear HSET, can better predict risk of poor clinical outcomes in AA than European American (EA) TNBC patients after accounting for factors that could confound analyses (like African genetic ancestry); how nuclear HSET may drive more aggressive tumor biology in TNBCs from AAs than EAs; and the potential clinical benefit of targeting nuclear HSET as an adjuvant to chemotherapy in AA and EA TNBCs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Having health workers assist HIV-infected persons with the recruitment and testing of their sexual contacts and biological children is an effective and efficient way of identifying persons in need of HIV treatment and prevention. However, in Malawi, a country with a generalized HIV epidemic, health workers lack the counseling and coordination skills to routinely assist their HIV-infected clients with these services. This study will determine how to help health workers in Malawi to provide these services through a set of digital capacity-building tools.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH NARRATIVE  Major life transitions for emerging adults (the developmental period from ages 18-25), including graduation from high school and from college, are associated with changes in risk for alcohol misuse (heavy alcohol consumption and negative alcohol-related consequences). These transitions correspond with changes in facets of the self-concept related to drinking alcohol (or drinking identity), which has emerged as a promising, novel cognitive risk factor for alcohol misuse. We propose to evaluate the malleability of drinking identity and its subsequent effect on alcohol misuse during the transition out of high school and out of college by adapting a theory-based, social/personality psychology intervention strategy to change self- concept.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV infection is often comorbid with opioid use disorder, with both conditions interacting in a reciprocal manner to exacerbate the other condition, yet underlying brain mechanisms remain poorly understood. Here, we will use single cell sequencing technologies to define transcriptional responses to HIV infection and/or volitional opioid consumption in addiction-and cognition-relevant brain circuits in a cell type-specific manner in mice of which will investigate the contributions of cell type-specific transcriptional responses to the deleterious effects of HIV infection on cognition and on the development of opioid addiction-related behavioral abnormalities. If successful, this program of research may yield significant new insights into disease-relevant interactions between HIV and opioid use disorder with unprecedented cellular resolution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Rising rates of alcohol-related liver disease (ALD) and mortality from alcohol consumption in ALD patients make connecting these patients to alcohol treatment critically important. There is an urgent need for interventions to improve alcohol treatment engagement in patients with ALD. This sequential, multiple-assignment, randomized trial (SMART) will test the efficacy of an adaptive intervention for improving rates of alcohol treatment engagement among patients with ALD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Suicide is the 2nd leading cause of death for adolescents and the rate of suicidal behavior has been increasing rapidly in Black youth. This Center, ETUDES (Enhancing Treatment and Utilization for Depression and Emergent Suicidality) is focused on augmenting the capacity of pediatric primary care to identify, refer, and manage youth at risk for suicidal behavior, with a special emphasis on making sure that the tools we develop to identify, refer, and reduce suicidal risk are effective and acceptable to Black youth and their families. In this Center, we will test novel methods of using health care records and mobile sensing to detect suicidal risk in youth, test interventions to improve referral, treatment engagement, and safety planning in primary care for suicidal youth, and test novel interventions designed to target known risk factors for depression and suicidal behavior, namely poor sleep, low activity, and online victimization that also may contribute to racial disparities in suicide risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: NARRATIVE  Defined regions of the United States that have historically received lower levels of NIH funding face specific challenges for accessing key research resources to facilitate biomedical research within the mission of the National Institute of General Medical Sciences (NIGMS). To alleviate one such challenge in these regions, we will provide access to a national quantitative proteomics resource through the IDeA National Resource for Quantitative Proteomics. We will provide investigators in these regions of the United States access to user- friendly services for state-of-the-art, quantitative proteomics that will guide the user from service request to sample analysis to delivery of publication ready data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Many genetic loci associated with phenotypic traits do not code for proteins but reside in noncoding regions by dysregulating gene expression. The dynamic nature of gene expression in specific cells and at particular developmental stages has prevented us from understanding noncoding mutations in human diseases and evolution. The goal of the proposed project is to introduce single-cell analysis in our human genome research: by leveraging a deep learning framework to integrate single-cell epigenomes and large-scale patient genomes, we will be able to determine the molecular context where noncoding mutations exert their pathogenic effects, and this new framework is expected to foster the development of therapeutic strategies targeting the most vulnerable cell types in human diseases. 1

PROJECT_TITLE: Single-Cell Analysis of the Noncoding Genome in Human Diseases and Evolution

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hepatocellular carcinoma is on pace to become the leading global indication for liver transplantation, and rejection continues to be an important cause of graft loss and failure post-transplant. The diagnosis of rejection is not correlative to changes in liver blood tests and thus requires an invasive biopsy, and very little is known about which immune cells mediate this disease process. This application seeks to overcome this barrier by developing new mass cytometry-based methods to measure liver transplant rejection severity and progression, and these methods may become valuable tools for future clinical trials of immunosuppression minimization or withdrawal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Diabetes and obesity are two major non-communicable diseases that are having a tremendous negative impact on the health and welfare of citizens in the United States and around the world. Despite considerable advances at the basic and clinical science levels, major unanswered questions regarding the pathogenesis of these disorders continue to limit our capacity to treat them. Effective training for scientists in diabetes, obesity and metabolic regulation are therefore fundamental priorities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE  Oral cavity squamous cell carcinoma (OCSCC) is a very aggressive and deadly disease with poor survival rates following maximal treatments such as surgery and chemoradiotherapy. Myeloid cells are thought to play an important role in head and neck cancer treatment resistance and the immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment. This proposal will test the hypothesis that a novel tumor derived RNA-nanoparticle vaccine can reprogram the myeloid cell compartment to unlock anti-tumor immunity; we will determine mechanisms of myeloid mediated vaccine efficacy in addition to checkpoint inhibitor synergy, and on the path towards human translation, we will evaluate the safety and efficacy of RNA-nanoparticle vaccines in client-owned felines with spontaneously occurring oral squamous cell carcinoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nearly all glioma patients experience seizures. The brain tumor microenvironment has been shown to be a crucial regulator of cancer initiation and progression, specifically neuronal activity has been shown to impact glioma cell proliferation. The interaction between neurons, microglia, and glioma cells is poorly understood. This proposal aims to investigate the cohesive interactions between neuronal activity, microglia, and glioma cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Acinetobacter baumannii has posed a serious threat to human health worldwide. This project further expands our observation that Human Serum Albumin (HSA) plays a role in the ability of A. baumannii to emerge as a hard pathogen to be treated and will determine the mechanistic aspect of this host pathogen interaction. Knowledge gained from this study would potentially identify new/alternative targets much needed for the development of novel approaches to control A. baumannii antibiotic resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: While new classes of drugs and advances in surgical interventions has reduced the cardiovascular mortality rate, cardiovascular disease incidence has begun to rise again in recent years, suggesting a continued investment in biomedical research will be critical to further reduce residual cardiovascular disease risk. Due to the complexity of cardiovascular disease and advanced research techniques used to understand these disease processes, it is imperative that the next generation of research scientists receive training across a variety of disciplines, including cardiovascular physiology, cellular and molecular biology, and disease pathogenesis. The goal of the Multidisciplinary Training in Cardiovascular Pathophysiology (MCTP) Training Program is to establish a research program to meet the need for advanced interdisciplinary training for Predoctoral Fellows and to provide a diverse pool of scientists to the study of cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Nearly 60% of the global population is at risk for malaria, a disease caused by mosquito-borne parasites that circulate in human blood. These studies focus on two molecules, histamine and serotonin, which circulate in blood, are associated with dangerous symptoms of malaria, and are ingested by mosquitoes when they feed on blood. We hypothesize that ingested histamine and serotonin alter mosquito physiology to favor malaria parasite transmission, suggesting that future interventions to block these small molecules in humans would reduce both disease and mosquito transmission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Hydrogels derived from extracellular matrix induce brain tissue regeneration by attracting brain cells into the stroke cavity. However, little is known about the spatio-temporal characteristics of neural progneitors migrating from the subventricular zone to the bioscaffold. A major limitation to map and understand the contribution of neurogenesis to brain tissue regeneration is the lack of in vivo imaging tools that can be utilized to visualize this process. We here described a novel method in which we inject gadolinium- gold nanoparticles into the lateral ventricle to tag newly born neural progenitors and track their migration using T1-weighted MRI. The positive signal emanating from these cells can unequivocally be attributed to labeled cells and allow us to increase spatial resolution to resolve a very detailed brain anatomy, specifically the tissue-bioscaffold interface. We further here propose to conduct experiments that will exploit this in vivo MR imaging to study the role neurogenesis plays in brain tissue regeneration. These studies will dramatically improve our ability to further develop bioscaffold for tissue regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The challenges of suicide prevention among Black youth are manifold. Many suicidal Black youth are unidentified, fewer than half are referred to treatment following an emergency department visit, and many referred youth do not adhere to treatment. Yet, prior research has not examined the effectiveness of a system of care for Black youth that combines suicide risk screening with an intervention to enhance linkage to quality mental health services.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Psychostimulants, which are the second most prescribed medication class for long-term use in children and adolescents with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), increase osteoclast differentiation and activity, promoting bone resorption. This observational study in 7 to 16 year-olds starting treatment for ADHD will be the first to prospectively examine whether psychostimulants impair bone microarchitecture and mineral accrual during this critical developmental period, increasing one's risk for low bone mass later in life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite improvements in screening and treatment, breast cancer remains the 2nd most common cause of cancer related death among U.S. women. With current EDRN funding we conducted successful Phase 2 and 3 validation studies of breast cancer biomarkers for clearly defined clinical applications. Herein we propose Phase 2, 3, and 4 validation studies, development of clinical grade assays, and integration of imaging data with the goal of implementing a novel strategy to improve the early detection of breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The dynamic regulation of metabolic pathways is critical for cellular adaptation to stress and starvation and ultimately cell survival. We found that inter-organelle contact sites are hotspots for spatially coordinating the interplay between lipids and methionine metabolism. By understanding how changes in methionine metabolism influence the lipidome, we will make important insights into the mechanisms underlying various human pathologies including cancers, liver diseases, and cardiovascular diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The optimal strategy for management of people who experience treatment failure on tenofovir, lamivudine, and dolutegravir (TLD), the preferred first-line antiretroviral therapy regimen for over 25 million people in sub- Saharan Africa, is unknown. In this project, we will respond to this critical knowledge gap by conducting a randomized clinical trial in Uganda and South Africa to determine the most effective management strategy for people with treatment failure on TLD and will leverage data from the clinical trial to conduct a modeling analysis, which will compare the cost-effectiveness of each approach. Our results will inform regional HIV guidelines by identifying the most clinically effective and cost-effective strategy for the management of treatment failure on TLD in sub-Saharan Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is a lifelong condition that affects a growing number of adults. This project will establish one of the largest and most comprehensive cohorts of autistic adults to provide critical foundations for understanding the clinical, health, neurobiological, and genetic processes associated with aging in autism and investigate whether aging is accelerated in autistic individuals. Results will provide new information identifying ways to best support and promote health, well-being, and resilience in autistic adults and provide critical information that can be used to plan appropriate services and resources for these adults.
