IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative The preparation of small organic molecules in efficient, concise, and convenient manner is critical for the discovery, development, and eventual production of pharmaceutical agents and other bioactive molecules for biomedical research. In this proposal, new organic reaction methodologies that employ simple and readily available alkene and alkyne containing starting materials are proposed for the expedited synthesis of molecules with direct relevance to the preparation of bioactive molecules. Thus, the successful development of these strategies will have a substantially positive impact on the achievement of public health goals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ovarian cancer affects only women for which cisplatin is a commonly used chemotherapeutic drug but it causes neurotoxicity leading to painful neuropathy, cognitive decline, called `chemobrain' and alterations in gait with increased propensity to fall/fractures, which may continue even after the discontinuation of treatment. We hypothesize that the activation of p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase and c-Jun N-terminal kinase plays a critical role in cisplatin-induced damage to the nervous system and that inhibition of these pathways will attenuate cisplatin-induced neurotoxic side effects in female mice with ovarian cancer. We expect that the results of our study will lead to the development of novel therapeutics to reduce the debilitating sequelae of cisplatin in women with ovarian and other cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE It is increasingly recognized that certain molecules produced by microbes living in the human gut play important roles in host health and disease. Controlling the concentration of these metabolites within a target window could provide new therapeutic modalities for a variety of diseases - including irritable bowel disease - but achieving this degree of control in the chemically complex, temporally variable gut environment is challenging with existing technologies. This project seeks to overcome this challenge and provide a new control strategy based on engineering commensal microbes programmed to dynamically sense and respond to the level of a target metabolite in their local environment, restoring the desired level by either degrading the compound or producing more of it.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute rejection remains a major cause of morbidity and mortality in pediatric patients after heart transplant. In order to screen for rejection, most centers perform heart catheterizations with endomyocardial biopsies frequently in the first year post transplant and then every 1-2 years thereafter; these biopsies are associated with complications, can cause significant anxiety in patients and family members, and are a significant cost for the healthcare system. This project will evaluate non-invasive methods of detecting rejection using cardiac magnetic resonance imaging and blood testing with a goal to reduce the required number of cardiac catheterizations.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study will address the intersecting stigmas of HIV, violence and depression among adolescents and young adults (15-24) living with HIV (AYALHIV) in Zambia. The study will integrate a problem management-based mental health approach into an existing HIV-stigma-reducing intervention, and refine measures of internalized and intersecting stigmas, to create and test the feasibility of Project YES+- a combined youth peer mentoring and lay mental health intervention. This research aims to shift HIV care and treatment for AYALHIV by addressing the multiple internalized and intersecting stigmas that impeded antiretroviral adherence and HIV viral suppression.

NARRATIVE In this application, we propose to determine the effect of the newly identified neutrophil subpopulations on the progression of liver and gastrointestinal disease in ART-treated HIV-1-infected individuals. IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Meibomian gland dysfunction, a disorder of the oil glands situated in the eyelid, is the leading cause of dry eye disease and the most common reason for patients seeking professional eyecare in the U.S. Yet there are no FDA approved medicines for this condition. The focus of this grant is to understand how inflammation of the eyelid and surrounding eye tissues, which is typically accompanied by Meibomian gland dysfunction, contribute to this condition and thereby will lay the groundwork for future identification of new drug targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement Ending the HIV epidemic in America will require effective delivery of treatment to all people living with HIV. Low-barrier care improves access to HIV treatment for people with complex medical and social needs who have not done well with regular medical care. We will study the expansion of low-barrier care in Seattle/King County, Washington and prepare for scale-up of low-barrier care in other parts of the United States.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Despite a heightened focus on patient safety over the past two decades, preventable harms remain excessively high with implications for mortality, morbidity, and quality of life. This innovative health services research training program focuses on patient safety in the hospital setting, with direct application to policy and patient care. This interdisciplinary postdoctoral research training program will prepare the next generation of diverse health services researchers to generate evidence to improve safety, quality, equity, and outcomes in healthcare delivery.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Patient Safety and Health Services Research Training

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE COVID-19 has highlighted many of the finest and poorest aspects of the U.S. health care system - new vaccines were developed and delivered in record time through joint public-private partnerships, but there have been huge inequities in hospitalization and mortality rates among racial minoritized groups. The pandemic also highlighted a lack of preparedness: having a sufficient number of well-trained public health workers who can be mobilized on short notice as well as a sufficient stockpile of equipment such as surgical-quality masks. The proposed training program will make significant and distinctive contributions to the field by shepherding new scholars who will work in academia, research organizations, health care delivery systems and industry research groups to address this and many other of the country’s ongoing health and healthcare challenges.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Los Angeles Area Health Services Research Training Program

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative The US health care system is rapidly transforming in response to social, economic and policy changes and requires timely research designed to be informative to and actionable by health care professionals, delivery systems, policymakers, and the public. Skilled researchers are needed to assist in these changes so as to maximize the quality, equity, and efficiency of clinical care delivery, and to address current disparities in health and health care. The Sheps Center at UNC Chapel Hill proposes to train PhD and clinical investigators in the methods of health services research toward those goals.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: UNC-CH Training Program in Health Services Research

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite years of research, morbidity and mortality from pediatric septic shock remains unacceptably high, particularly in children who develop acute kidney injury. The heterogeneity of sepsis (and, by extension, sepsis- associated acute kidney injury) dictates that precision medicine approaches to diagnosis and management are sorely needed to identify effective therapies and improve outcomes in these children. As such, this proposal seeks to leverage large-scale clinical and biomarker data to better characterize sepsis-associated acute kidney injury through the identification of novel subphenotypes for prognostic and predictive enrichment, and identify strategies for successful implementation of personalized approaches to care at the bedside.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Electrical microstimulation may prove to be a useful technique for delivering information from neuroprosthetic devices to the cerebral cortex. Current efforts to understand how the brain uses such information have focused on the effects of stimulation on nerve cells in close proximity to the electrode tip, though electrical stimulation may influence neural activity far from the stimulation site. The proposed studies will test the hypothesis that electrical stimulation affects nerve cells in distant cortical areas as the brain learns to interpret the stimulation and quantify how those effects evolve over time with training, which will provide insights for improving the utility of electrical stimulation in neuroprosthetic devices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research seeks to elucidate the role of placental senescence in peripartum cardiomyopathy (PPCM). This research plan is relevant to public health because it is expected to provide fundamental insights into the underlying pathophysiological mechanisms driving PPCM, a leading cause of maternal heart failure. Thus, it accomplishes the NIH and NHLBI’s missions and initiatives by not only providing novel insights into our understanding of the biology underlying cardiovascular disease, but also potential therapeutic advancements that could improve the longevity and health of individuals afflicted with heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Opioid use has greatly increased in recent decades and has been characterized as a public health crisis. Even amongst those using prescription opioids under physician supervision for chronic pain, these medications may lead to adverse effects, potentially by contributing to breathing issues during sleep. The goal of this research is to understand how these breathing issues might affect patients using opioids, as well as to help identify treatments that will improve symptoms and potentially decrease the risk of poor health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: NARRATIVE Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) is the second leading cause of death from infection today after COVID-19. Mtb’s fate in the host is largely controlled by host cells called macrophages, but Mtb eventually kills the macrophages in which it resides and goes on to infect more macrophages. Surprisingly, the Mtb-infected macrophage participates in its own death by responding to its own interferon-beta, and this proposal aims to find out how, so that future studies might develop drugs that help macrophages better control tuberculosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Heart failure is a leading cause of death worldwide. Pathological cardiac remodeling in response to hypertension induces the unfolded protein response in cardiomyocytes, of which precise roles and mechanisms- of-action are elusive. Experiments laid out here will focus on a novel function of the unfolded protein response in pressure overload-induced cardiomyopathy and heart failure, which may provide new insights for our understanding of hypertensive heart disease and shed light on novel therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exocrine pancreatic insufficiency (EPI), the result of inadequate secretion of digestive juice from the pancreas, results from multiple diseases including chronic pancreatitis (CP) and can have serious effects in children including malnutrition and growth failure. Unfortunately, accurate diagnosis of EPI requires invasive testing under anesthesia, and prediction of progression to CP and EPI is not currently possible. We propose to develop accurate, non-invasive imaging methods to diagnose EPI and predict progression to CP to allow early and effective intervention and improved management of pediatric pancreatic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Endothelial cell (EC) alterations that occur in critically ill children can cause capillary leak with severe clinical consequences, but the mechanisms by which the capillary barrier becomes disrupted are unknown, limiting the development of effective therapies. We have identified changes in human ECs isolated from children presenting with multiple organ failures who later develop capillary leak associated with para- and transcellular leak and identified specific pharmacologic inhibitors. We will elucidate the mechanisms of these changes in appropriate culture models of human capillary ECs and validate our cell culture findings using an in vivo model of human skin capillaries implanted and perfused in immunodeficient mouse hosts in ex vivo perfused human lungs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to address the crucial question of how reward-based memories are encoded in the brain. It will directly test the role of spontaneous reactivation of memory-relevant neurons distributed in multiple brain regions in memory formation and consolidation. These findings will be important not only for understanding the physiological basis of reward-based memories, but also relevant to human brain disorders such as addiction and Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Binge eating is a maladaptive behavior widely present in the general population that is strongly associated with obesity risk. Loss of control over eating, a core diagnostic feature, is associated with difficulties disengaging from eating, and research examining feeding offset is needed to dissect circuit abnormalities. This project will characterize neural activity patterns contributing to feeding offset to ultimately develop improved treatments for aberrant eating contributing to obesity risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: This proposed technology-development study will significantly advance quantitative acoustic microscopy (QAM) systems and ultimately pave the way towards wide acceptance of the technology. QAM systems permit formation of maps of the acoustical and mechanical properties of tissues at microscopic resolutions. Data-science methods and technological advances will be applied to make new, easy-to-use, low-cost, fine-resolution, QAM systems possible. Optimal methods will be incorporated in a prototype QAM (pQAM) instrument capable of producing images with ultra-fine spatial resolution (< 2 µm), much faster (<1 min), and at a much lower cost (<$40k) than current state-of-the-art QAM systems. In addition, pQAM use will be ``turn-key'' (i.e., requiring no technical knowledge and less than 1 hour of training.)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Loss of intestinal homeostasis can occur in response to external stimuli such as allergens and worm parasites that cause Type 2 inflammation in the intestinal epithelium. Critically, bioactive lipid pathways are highly active in intestinal inflammation, but how these pathways control Type 2 inflammatory changes in the epithelium is unclear, representing a major gap in our understanding of how the intestine maintains homeostasis. Studies in this application will define how the lipid prostaglandin D2 and its receptor CRTH2 (chemoattractant receptor- homologous molecule expressed on Th2 cells) regulate intestinal epithelial biology during Type 2 inflammation to restore homeostasis, which will inform efforts to target prostaglandin pathways to treat intestinal diseases associated with a loss of homeostasis, including inflammatory bowel disease, cancer, and infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Social media have been increasingly used to disseminate e-cigarette use prevention messages, however, very limited research has comprehensively examined the amount, themes, and sources of these campaigns and the social networks embedded in the campaign conversations. This project will fill this gap by measuring reach and engagement of such campaigns and analyzing comparative themes, major strategies countering these interventions, and the social networks upon which campaign effectiveness depends. These insights will then be used to develop concepts and technologies to help create effective social media campaigns preventing e-cigarette use among youth and young adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE  During the onset of type 1 diabetes (T1D), many immune cell types infiltrate into pancreatic islets, but the infiltration of each individual islet varies substantially within an individual mouse or human. We propose experiments to identify the molecular details of transcriptional programs that control immune cell function in pancreatic islets over the onset of T1D. These analyses will deﬁne transcriptional control of autoimmune responses and identify potential therapeutic targets to limit autoimmunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: The proposed research is relevant to public health because vancomycin is the single most commonly administered antibiotic in the hospital setting, causing attributable acute kidney injury in more than 10% of patients and leading to 300,000 potentially preventable new kidney injuries per year. Despite known mechanisms, it is unknown if proximal tubular necrosis via an oxidative mechanism or vancomycin uromodulin complexes leading to obstruction/renal tubular epithelial dam- age is the initiation event that begins a pathway of damage. Defining the inciting mechanism will pave the way for AKI prevention studies that will precisely target: A) avoidance of cellular uptake at the proximal tubule cell for vancomycin and many other nephrotoxins, e.g. megalin mediated uptake or B) tubular conditions the minimize the likelihood of uromodulin complex formation, i.e. osmotic gradient management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Interferon-lambda (IFN-λ) provides antiviral protection against SARS-CoV-2 and is in clinical trials as a therapeutic for COVID-19, but the endogenous role for IFN-λ its mechanisms in regulating pathogenesis and immunity during SARS-CoV-2 infection remain unknown. Our preliminary data has identified novel roles for IFN-λ promoting CD8 T cell immunity and limiting pulmonary pathogenesis repair programs in a murine model of SARS-CoV-2 infection. This proposal will investigate the mechanisms underlying these non-canonical functions of IFN-λ during SARS-CoV-2 infection to inform therapeutic use in preventing COVID-19.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Dental adhesives are employed to create a sturdy and long-lasting bond between dentin and composite restorations, through the formation of a robust hybrid layer comprised of a three-dimensional polymer network that interlocks with native bone tissue. To date, the performance of such adhesives is sub-optimal, as the majority of composite failures are observed at restoration margins. The fundamental goal of this project is to understand the phase structure and composition of heterogeneities that form during adhesive polymerization, and to reinforce weakened regions of the hybrid layer through the development and application of monomers capable of adaptable, dynamic bond rearrangement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol use problems and sleep problems each cause significant negative consequences to individuals and to societies. They also happen to occur together very often, with insomnia often making alcohol use worse and diminishing the effects of alcohol treatment. The project will focus on improving sleep with a brief, phone- based, behavioral insomnia intervention as an approach to reduce hazardous alcohol use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Developmental anomalies affect more than 120,000 births annually in the United States; however, the perturbations in embryogenesis that lead to these anomalies have not been identified in many cases including certain neurodevelopmental disorders. The proposed research creates strategies for detailed mapping of developmental events in mammalian model systems to advance the understanding of the genetic factors that contribute to these disorders. These strategies are relevant to public health and the NIH’s mission because they would help determine how genomic mutations disrupt cell proliferation and differentiation during embryogenesis to lead to developmental anomalies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The goal of the proposed research is to understand how certain KRAS-driven lung cancers silence STING and to develop pre-clinical therapeutic strategies that force them to deal with re-activation of this critical DNA sensor. By inducing this antiviral protein and boosting its activity, KRAS-LKB1 mutant lung cancers are forced to deal with consequences, which not only promotes cellular cytotoxicity but also enhanced immunogenicity. These studies build upon our initial efforts to target TBK1 and provide a more straightforward approach to rewire its activity in lung cancer and ultimately have a significant impact on public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Maternal obesity is a strong risk factor for pediatric nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), which affects 35% of obese youth and up to 10% of all children. Using a nonhuman primate model of maternal obesity, we will investigate mechanisms by which maternal western style diet can reprogram immune cells and liver beginning in fetuses to promote NAFLD and liver fibrosis in juvenile offspring. The results of this study will have direct clinical and translational implications for understanding and potentially halting pediatric NAFLD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Major depressive disorder (MDD), one of the most prevalent and disabling psychiatric disorders worldwide, may accelerate brain aging and increase risk for dementia. We propose a novel accelerated longitudinal in vivo positron emission tomography imaging study to determine the role of MDD in accelerating brain aging in later life, and evaluate the role of these changes in contributing to emotional dysregulation and cognitive dysfunction in this disorder. Given the aging of the general adult population and role of MDD as a risk factor for dementia, elucidation of molecular mechanisms underlying the link between MDD and accelerated brain aging is critical to identifying biomarkers of at-risk individuals, and informing novel targets for prevention and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Significant geographic, racial, and gender disparities in HIV incidence exist in the United States, with Black cisgender women in the Southern U.S. having disproportionately high rates of HIV infection yet low rates of PrEP utilization. Through preliminary work, we have identified successful strategies to increase PrEP uptake and support PrEP persistence among Black cisgender women in community health clinic settings. Using the Exploration, Preparation, Implementation and Sustainment (EPIS) implementation science framework, this proposal will adapt these strategies for implementation and scale up in the Southern U.S. to improve PrEP care continuum outcomes among Black cisgender women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Sudden unexplained death in epilepsy (SUDEP) is a major cause of morbidity in patients with seizures; however, the mechanisms of SUDEP remain largely unknown. We have identified a pathologic mutation in the Na/K-ATPase ATP1A3 which results in SUDEP through a predisposition to ventricular arrhythmias and propose leveraging human cardiac myocytes and mouse models to determine the mechanism of SUDEP. This approach represents a unique opportunity to dissect a key mechanism of SUDEP, gain insight into mechanisms of ventricular arrhythmias, and to explore the role of ATP1A3 in the heart more broadly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement: Project Narrative Due to the lack of model systems, it has been difficult to study complex gene-environment interactions in Parkinson's disease. Using a combination of Drosophila genetics and patient-derived induced pluripotent stem cells, we can develop a model that can be utilized to identify and study the mechanisms of interaction among GWAS candidate genes, environmental factors, and α-synuclein. This K99/R00 proposal aims to characterize a novel interaction among LRRK2, rotenone, and α-synuclein, study the mechanism of the interaction and subsequently validate this novel multiplex system, which can be used to study these previously unknown interactions among environmental and genetic factors and is a step towards personalized medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative ALS is an incurable and fatal disease of progressive weakness, caused by the degeneration of muscle cells and the nerves controlling them. Enhancing muscle membrane repair can slow the progressive damage and loss of neuromuscular junctions (NMJs) – where nerve and muscle cells connect. This project combines multiple techniques to study and visualize the ongoing balance between membrane damage and repair mechanisms in muscle cells from ALS patients and mouse models, and uses these models to test whether a novel therapy to increase muscle membrane repair can slow ALS progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many U.S. agencies are calling for interventions to prevent and reduce the large and persistent inequities in alcohol use for sexual and gender minority youth (SGMY)—but this goal cannot be achieved without additional evidence-based interventions. The goals of the proposed research are to conduct a randomized controlled trial to test a highly acceptable, theory-based, SGMY-informed, game-based intervention for preventing and reducing SGMY binge drinking. Given the dearth of evidence-based interventions for reducing alcohol use for SGMY, this project will provide novel scientific contributions that can help foster health equity for sexual and gender minority youth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE It has been over 50 years since the FDA approved a new class of drugs to treat infections caused by Gram-negative pathogens such as E. coli, K. pneumoniae, and A. baumannii, and as such there are now limited options for these infections. We have identified a very promising antibiotic candidate, called fabimycin, that has single-agent efficacy against these drug-resistant Gram-negative pathogens, is from a novel drug class, acts through a novel mechanism (inhibition of FabI), has a low frequency of resistance, has efficacy in challenging rodent infection models, and has no effect on commensal bacteria, suggesting the possibility that it could spare the gut microbiome. Herein we propose a comprehensive and systematic plan to develop novel versions of fabimycin where the Therapeutic Index is widened such that the lead can advance as a true translational candidate; such an antibiotic with single-agent efficacy against drug- resistant Gram-negative bacteria and that is gut-microbiome sparing would have an immediate impact on patients stricken with such infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Deaf and hard of hearing (D/HH) persons are a linguistic and cultural minority group that is greatly underrepresented among biomedical scientists and academic faculty members. This program is a partnership between a research-intensive University (University of Rochester) and a teaching-intensive University (Rochester Institute of Technology) that is the 3rd largest producer of undergraduate STEM graduates among private universities in the U.S, and home to the world's first and largest technological college for the post- secondary education of D/HH persons (the National Technical Institute for the Deaf; NTID). This program will prepare D/HH postdoctoral Scholars for careers as academic faculty members, by developing and refining their skills in research, teaching and professionalism; by doing so, it will address the shortage of D/HH faculty in our academic workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The innovative magnetic resonance imaging technologies and probes for multifunctional in vivo mapping of chemical parameters in tumor tissue microenvironment will be developed. Applications in a mouse model of breast cancer will provide new knowledge on stage-specific TME evolution during tumor progression, and will equip the professionals with a knowledge required to optimize TME-targeted anticancer therapies as well as provide scientific basis to evoke public awareness of high content of the phosphate-based modifiers in the processed food and the potential health risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The vacuolar ATPases (V-ATPases) are large, multi-subunit proton pumps that are essential for many fundamental physiological processes in all eukaryotic organisms and malfunction of V-ATPases is associated with devastating human diseases including cancer, renal tubular acidosis, osteoporosis, diabetes, neurodegenerative diseases, and AIDS. Elucidating the structures and molecular mechanisms of V-ATPases assembly, biogenesis, regulation, and signaling will greatly advance our understanding of these V-ATPase-associated diseases. The completion of the project will not only advance our understanding on V-ATPases but also offer mechanistic insights to modulate human V- ATPase activity for disease treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: RELEVANCE: Only 1 in 5 lung cancer patients treated with immunotherapy (IO) has a favorable response. Additionally, the cost of IO is extremely high, >$200K/year per patient. The goal of this project is to develop novel computational radiomic tools which in conjunction with routine CT scans from IO clinical trials will allow for (1) identifying pre-IO therapy as to which non-small cell lung cancer patients could potentially benefit from immune checkpoint inhibitors and (2) quantitatively monitor serial changes in tumor heterogeneity during IO treatment for early identification of responders and non-responders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease remains the major cause of death in the US. Through the renewal and expansion of this highly successful postdoctoral training program, we align ourselves with the stated goal of the NHLBI to “provide a sustained flow of qualified physician-scientists able to think critically and translate findings freely between the basic and clinical spheres.” We will accomplish this goal through strong mentorship by established experts in the field, specialized didactics, and intensive training through basic, translational and/or clinical research projects tackling the major forms of cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Acetyl-transfer reactions play an important regulatory function in the vast majority of the human proteome, RNAome and metabolome, and aberrant acetyl-transfer reaction function is correlated with human disease. Despite the importance of acetyl-transfer reactions, mechanistic information regarding their distinct modes of regulation are poorly understood. In this proposal, we will address the molecular mechanisms of how how protein and RNA acetyltransferases target their cognate substrates, how auxiliary proteins and ribosome association contribute to certain acetyl-transfer reactions, how acetyl-CoA metabolism link to chromatin regulation and fatty acid synthesis, and how we can leverage mechanistic and structural information to develop potent and selective acetyl-transfer reaction inhibitors for therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study addresses a key NIH priority, strengthening care for people living with HIV at high risk of treatment failure, and will be one of the first studies to use an innovative framework, MOST, to focus on the HIV care cascade in a high-burden, resource-strained setting (South Africa). To do so, the study will employ a fractional factorial design to determine the effects of five intervention components on the primary outcome (HIV viral suppression) and secondary outcomes, assess cost and other implementation features of each component, and then construct an optimized intervention package, with no inactive or poorly performing components.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) is a life-threatening condition that can result in acute respiratory failure and severe hypoxemia due to a significant impairment of gas exchange. ARDS affects approximately 200,000 individuals annually in the US, and, despite medical advances in the understanding of protective ventilation strategies and modern life support techniques, leads to nearly 75,000 deaths, with an unacceptably high mortality rate that has not improved in two decades. Following discovery of the potent water-soluble allosteric modifier VZHE-039.glycine HCl, which can rapidly increase the capacity of hemoglobin to bind and transport oxygen in a dose-dependent manner, we propose a definitive efficacy study to evaluate the potential of our novel drug to improve clinically-meaningful outcomes for ARDS patients to support advancement into a human clinical trial.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Much remains unknown about the rate and dynamics of human somatic mutations, which are known drivers of cancer and are hypothesized to play a role in aging. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The goal of this training program is to prepare exceptional, rigorous and collaborative PhD graduates for productive, science-related careers in Biophysics or other fields. Well-trained biophysicists play essential roles in elucidating the molecular basis of human health and disease. Such researchers investigate the structures, mechanisms, and functions of crucial cellular components, thereby providing the information needed to (i) understand disease on a molecular level and (ii) design new treatments targeting diseases including cancer, diabetes, inflammation, heart disease, immune and neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE This proposal is relevant to the public health because it will introduce novel, nonperturbative, nondestructive, elasticity-based metrics and finite element modeling to the evaluation of corneal cross-linking procedures, which are the current first line treatment for corneal ectatic disorders such as keratoconus. This approach will allow for the first in vivo analysis of the cross-linking procedure and facilitate new protocol development to individualize treatment parameters resulting in improved efficacy and safety and provide the first step necessary towards visual improvement for patients with keratoconus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Chlamydia is a major cause of sexually transmitted infections in the U.S., and more cases of chlamydial genital infections are reported to the CDC than any other infectious disease. This project will investigate two new effects of Chlamydia on a differentiated host cell: primary cilia loss and cell cycle re-entry. The project will study the mechanisms by which Chlamydia infection induces these effects on its host cell and will test if these two host-pathogen interactions are functionally linked. Interventions to prevent Chlamydia-induced primary cilia loss and cell cycle re-entry may lead to a novel therapeutic strategy against Chlamydia infections.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative Aflatoxin B1 (AFB1) is a liver carcinogen that is a common contaminant of foods in sub- Saharan Africa where exposure starts very early in life during pregnancy. This study aims to find out if early life AFB1 exposure is associated with altered regulation of tumor suppressor genes in Nigerian newborns. The findings of this research could provide an understanding of how early- in-life AFB1 exposure increases the risk of early-onset liver cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE: There is increasing evidence that there are clear differences between men and women in cognitive impairment particularly Alzheimer’s Disease. Mid-life levels of obesity, diabetes, hypertension, and particularly high cholesterol are risk factors for cognitive impairment and dementia in old age, and they may even cause cognitive decline in young adults. We will feed a high-cholesterol diet to male and female animals as an unconventional, but promising model of late-onset Alzheimer’s Disease, and determine how estrogen and estrogen receptors affect learning and memory and the underlying molecular pathways and brain pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: One of the most devastating effects of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) is the progressive loss of speech function. By creating a digital tool for assessing speech on a patient’s own computer or mobile device, Modality.AI and MGH of Health Professionals aim to develop a telehealth service to determine communication status in patients with ALS and document treatment outcomes in a real-world setting. Ultimately, this technology aims to improve diagnosis for patients with ALS, decrease costs for patients and healthcare providers, and provide access to accurate speech assessments while eliminating the need for travel.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current therapies aimed at heart failure, a global health problem, have been directed mainly at end-stage disease. We seek to better understand the processes that occur early in the genesis of heart failure in order to identify new therapeutic strategies aimed at early stage disease. In this project, we will focus on the observation that the early stage failing heart becomes “energy-starved” due to abnormalities in proteins involved in converting fuels to a usable energy source.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Excessive use of prescribed opioids during and after major surgery is a significant contributor to persistent opioid use, misuse and ongoing opioid epidemic, which are recently worsened by the pandemic. The proposed research has significant public health relevance because it aims to reduce surgical pain and opioid use with a promising non-pharmacological tool, Auriculotherapy, that stimulates ear nerves. By proactively reducing surgical pain, postoperative opioid use and opioid-related serious adverse effects with Auriculotherapy, this research will enable the best-in-class post-surgical pain and opioid-related outcomes in millions of Americans undergoing painful surgeries every year while minimizing the nation’s opioid epidemic burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cervical spinal injury leads to paralysis and possible death from respiratory failure or related comorbidities, thus our goal is to restore respiratory function in a rat model of upper cervical spinal cord injury by utilizing closed- loop cervical spinal epidural stimulation. We propose that induction of respiratory neuroplasticity may rely on activity-dependent upregulation of key neurotrophic factors (e.g. BDNF, TrkB) within phrenic motor neurons, thereby enhancing ventilatory capacity beyond the period of stimulation (i.e. plasticity). Through a detailed understanding of these mechanisms, this project may lead to novel therapies to extend and improve life for patients with cervical spinal cord injury by preserving breathing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Encephalitic alphaviruses such as Eastern equine encephalitis virus (EEEV) are highly lethal pathogens with no current FDA-approved therapeutics or vaccines. Antibody-mediated neutralization and protection of EEEV has not been well defined, and we still lack fundamental knowledge of important antigenic sites that inform vaccine design. The research we are proposing will provide important information defining the humoral immune response and mechanistic correlates of protection for alphavirus infections including engineered antibodies that transport to brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Influenza virus is a significant pathogen in solid organ transplant (SOT) patients, but these individuals respond poorly to standard-dose (SD) inactivated influenza vaccine (IIV). Studies suggest that two doses of SD-IIV or one dose of high-dose (HD-IIV) is superior to one dose of SD-IIV; however, this has not been tested in the early post-transplantation period when SOT recipients are at highest risk of severe influenza disease and complications. This study aims to find the optimal influenza vaccine strategy by comparing one dose of HD-IIV, two doses of SD-IIV, or two doses of HD-IIV over one influenza season in adult, kidney, heart, and/or liver SOT recipients in the early transplant period.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Based at the University of Chicago, this cross-disciplinary T32 program leverages the intellectually rich environment on campus and its resources in immunology, medicine, molecular engineering, and data science to train postdoctoral fellows in the rapidly emerging field of Immunoengineering. Designed for early postdoctoral bioengineers or immunologists, the training plan funds participation in an immersive short course in each other's fields, as well as elective workshops and outreach opportunities to improve teaching & science communications skills, and grant- and proposal-writing abilities. Postdoctoral fellows will be mentored by a panel of immunologists and bioengineers to develop novel collaborative projects that address today's biggest unanswered questions at the interface and translate these insights into new solutions that improve health, lengthen life, and reduce illness and disability.
PROJECT_TERMS: immunoengineering;post-doctoral training;Training Programs
PROJECT_TITLE: Immunoengineering Postdoctoral Training Program - Resubmission - 1
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Allergy, Immunology, and Transplantation Research Committee[AITC]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Nerve signals originating in the rod and cone photoreceptors are processed by circuits in the inner retina to give rise to separate visual streams that carry information about, for example, object motion and color. These circuits become disrupted following photoreceptor degeneration in both genetic and age-onset disease. Our work will help to define the wiring and functions of these circuits in the healthy retina and will provide the background for understanding circuit changes in the diseased state.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative Lipid droplets are cellular organelles that store fat and are misregulated in many human diseases. They also have a major function in protein handling, including for certain viral and nuclear proteins. This project analyzes how lipid droplets exchange proteins between each other, how cells turn this exchange on and off, and how it affects cellular function, potentially uncovering new principles of how lipid droplets promote health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Aggregation of human islet amyloid polypeptide (hIAPP) is associated with type-2 diabetes (T2D). We propose to uncover mechanisms of hIAPP aggregation and cross-interactions with other amyloid proteins, and design engineered nanoparticles to mitigate aggregation and the associated toxicity. Outcome of the proposed research will help better understand disease mechanisms of T2D and pathological correlations with other amyloid diseases, and aid in the design of anti-amyloid nanomedicine against T2D. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative This application seeks to discover and characterize the molecular mechanisms controlling the synthesis and remodeling of bacterial cell envelope polymers called teichoic acids and define how this regulation is corrupted by antibiotics to trigger cell lysis using the pathogen Streptococcus pneumoniae as a model system. The research proposed here will yield a mechanistic understanding of how these cell envelope biogenesis and remodeling systems affect bacterial physiology and uncover new ways to inhibit these processes for the development of therapeutics against infections caused by S. pneumoniae and related pathogens. Since many virulence determinants are embedded within or secreted across the cell envelope, our results will also impact pathogenesis research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Cervical injury to the spinal cord results in dimished forelimb function. We have recently identified that the C3-C4 propriospinal neurons, which connect to the lateral reticular nucleus, can promote recovery of forelimb function after cervical lesions and rehabilitative training. We hypothesize that rehabilitation promotes recovery by inducing sprouting along the propriospinal- lateral reticular formation-cerebellar-brainstem loop and important pathway that normal functions to correct forelimb-patterning errors during the movement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research will test the hypothesis that objective social isolation and loneliness are linked to neurobehavioral mechanisms involved in social perception and motivation in individuals with and without serious mental illness. It will also investigate the specific dynamic interactions among these phenomena in daily life and how they, as well as the neurobehavioral predictors, are linked to day-to-day functioning. The findings of this project could provide novel targets for therapeutics aimed at improving functioning and overall quality of life in individuals with serious mental illnesses, as well as quantitative phenotypes for use in genetic investigations and early detection efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: We proposal to use fertilization in the unicellular green alga Chlamydomonas as a model system to study conserved mechanism of ciliary signaling and the gamete membrane fusion reaction. We will determine the cellular and molecular mechanisms that underlie coupling between the cilium and the cytoplasm cilium generated signaling. And, we will use our recent discovery that gamete lipid bilayer merger depends on an ancient class II fusion protein as the foundation for a more complete molecular understanding of gamete fusion.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Addressing a paucity of training in multilingual research methods, we propose a unique, short-term education program to provide child health researchers with the sensitivity, skills, and knowledge to recruit and engage Limited English Proficiency (LEP) children and families in research. In the US there are approximately 7.8 million children and adolescents with no English-proficient parents, and these children and youth are disproportionately excluded from child health research because of language barriers. By training and supporting a cohort of investigators specializing in multilingual research methods, we hope to enhance the rigor, validity, and generalizability of child health research by making inclusion of LEP children and families the norm rather than the exception.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE  Exposure to elevated manganese (Mn) induces incurable neurotoxicity in humans that manifests as parkinsonism in adults, and motor and executive function deficits in children. This study will determine the role of Mn excretion in regulating the risks and outcomes of Mn neurotoxicity. Proposed work will also determine whether increasing Mn excretion is a therapeutically-viable strategy for the management of Mn-induced neurological disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This project investigates the basic mechanisms of how lipids are stored and released in tissues that are important for metabolic health. The processes of lipid synthesis and mobilization involve the assembly and interactions of protein complexes on the surface of specific intracellular organelles. This work will determine the composition of these protein complexes in liver and fat tissue and examine their function in response to physiological and pharmacological challenges, thereby clarifying how lipid levels in fat and liver are controlled and identifying novel points for therapeutic intervention.

ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE By revealing the mechanism through which the DNA replication machinery coordinates its functions at active and stalled replication forks, this study will provide new insight into how disruption of the replisome activity is linked to the perturbation of DNA replication fork integrity and genome instability. Gaining fundamental knowledge on how DNA replication process is kept in check against genotoxic stress will facilitate our effort to harness aberrant DNA replication problems of tumor cells for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH NARRATIVE In humans, either prolonged dietary vitamin A deficiency (VAD) or inherited mutations in retinoid/visual cycle genes manifests in similar retinal degenerative phenotypes, eventually leading to vision loss and blindness. This study proposes to test the novel hypothesis that the retinol binding protein receptor 2 (RBPR2) facilitates and regulates dietary vitamin A transport and hence physiologically plays an important role in photoreceptor health and vision. At the completion of this project, a mechanistic understanding of RBPR2 function for ocular vitamin A homeostasis will help design strategies aimed at modulation of such eye-related ROL transporters for improving vision in humans with inherited retinal diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project narrative To achieve a high level of granularity, existing sleep apnea detection methods based on physiological signals usually require fine-grained annotations on the sleep status that are expensive and time-consuming to obtain. To address this issue, the proposed project aims to incorporate annotations of different granularity levels and clinical domain knowledge into a deep learning framework for sleep apnea detection. It can be extended to wide range of practical, patient-centered applications and support our ultimate research goal to establish an efficient and cost-effective weakly supervised learning framework for complex biomedical data analytics to support clinical decision-making.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative While it is known that CD4 T cells protect against active tuberculosis, the M. tuberculosis antigens that are recognized by the CD4 T cells that provide protection remain to be identified. We identified a small set of M. tuberculosis antigens that are unusual for their evidence of evolutionary selection pressure and recognition by human and mouse CD4 T cells. In this proposed work, we will extend our discovery that human T cells that recognize these antigens exhibit distinct properties, and we will determine if CD4 T cells that recognize these antigens are associated with protection from active TB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding how healthy interactions between intestinal bacteria and the immune system are established and maintained is important for developing treatments for intestinal inflammation diseases like inflammatory bowel diseases and colorectal cancers. Akkermansia muciniphila is a human intestinal bacterium that produces anti-inflammatory factors in response to the diverse sugars that line the gut. This project will explore how Akkermansia senses and binds to sugars on the gut lining and on other gut bacteria and determine how these pathways shape intestinal health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Overall Component: Project Narrative Addressing a problem as daunting as persistent poverty and cancer requires approaches with a focus on changing the hazardous conditions in which people live, learn, work and play. The UPSTREAM Research Center, working with policy makers and community partners, will advance the science and practice of anti- poverty policies to prevent cancer in persistent poverty communities. Results from this work will lay the foundation for transformative approaches to address cancer prevention and control programs in the face of severe economic and social disadvantage through capacity building and sustainable partnerships with policymakers, state and local agencies and community partners.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Contemporary research on schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders reflects the general consensus that these are neurodevelopmental disorders. In parallel, in the past few decades, there has been a burgeoning body of research showing various environmental exposures during childhood to be associated with risk for psychosis. The proposed research will test the novel hypothesis that neighborhood residential instability (defined as the percentage of people in a neighborhood living in a different house in the past year) leads to psychosocial deprivation, which in turn contributes to reduction in corticolimbic gray matter volume, and ultimately increases risk for psychosis in at-risk youth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Characterizing the contributions of high-dimensional biomarkers to susceptibility of neuropsychiatric disorders such as autism is critically important for advancing our understanding of their etiology and for developing new treatments. The fraction of variance explained (FVE) by a set of biomarkers is a measure of the total amount of information for an outcome contained in the predictor variables. In this project, we propose a general framework for FVE estimation, applicable to high-dimensional data including both GWAS and brain imaging settings, and apply these methods to the NIH-funded Adolescent Brain Cognitive Development (ABCD) Study, comprising longitudinal, multi-modal brain imaging, GWAS SNPs, and autism-related assessments for 11,875 participants aged 9-10 at baseline and continuing into early adulthood. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Most smokers want to quit smoking, and most smokers try to quit smoking each year, but the vast majority of quit attempts end in failure, even when FDA-approved pharmacotherapies are used. The proposed study will investigate the best course of action when following an unsuccessful quit attempt with pharmacotherapy. Results will guide clinical decision making for smoking cessation treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Food intake can be triggered not only by hunger for calories, but also by deficiencies for specific nutrients, or by need-independent mechanisms. In this proposed study, I will characterize the molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying protein specific appetite, and elucidate how environmental blue light drives eating. This study will thus provide novel insights into the fundamental principles for the organization and modulation of feeding behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The proposed request for resource support is to allow continued access for thousands of users to the state-of- the-art technologies important in defining protein-glycan interactions, which are necessary for understanding the expression and functions of glycans in biological systems in health and disease, and glycan recognition by antibodies, glycan-binding proteins (GBPs), and lectins. To date, over 7,000 users and hundreds of laboratories have utilized the NCFG databases and resources, seeking information and assistance related to Functional Glycomics and our Resource research data has led them to explore glycosciences. This Resource provides unique and necessary capabilities in technology, teaching, and service related to understanding protein-glycan interactions to a broad swath of researchers that are experts and non-experts in the field of glycosciences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The scientific community has struggled to keep pace with the impact of the changing landscape of cannabis use and policy in the U.S. An important barrier to progress is the lack of adequate measures of cannabis consumption that can be used to identify low vs. high risk use patterns. We propose to address this challenge via a rigorous cannabis measure development / validation project that will enhance the capacities of clinical, epidemiologic and policy studies and lead to more informed communication about cannabis and its risks to clinicians, health educators and policy makers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although anti-Disialoganglioside (anti-GD2) therapy is standard of care for High-Risk Neuroblastoma, it is associated with a highly variable treatment response and life-threatening side effects. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it seeks to identify and characterize novel biomarkers that predict anti- GD2 response in High-Risk Neuroblastoma. The proposed research pertains to the NCI’s mission of improving cancer treatment because there are currently no predictive biomarkers for anti-GD2 response in High-Risk Neuroblastoma and little mechanistic insight into why children fail to respond to treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Effective nociception monitoring and control during surgery can minimize post-operative pain and reduce post- operative opioid requirements among surgical patients, thereby decreasing their chances of opioid dependency, but existing nociception monitoring tools are imperfect in that they monitor markers such as heart rate and blood pressure that are inherently influenced by various intraoperative factors. This leads to suboptimal opioid administration for nociception control. This project proposes to develop a novel surgical nociception monitor that comprises of an integrated measure of nociceptive control based on neurophysiological (EEG) and autonomic (EDA) markers of arousal and nociception that aren’t susceptible to intraoperative factors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infant health and neurodevelopment in early life may be impaired by a wide range of both prenatal and postnatal factors including maternal infection and the socio-behavioral postnatal environment, however research is rarely able to simultaneously measure the impact of each of these factors. In this study, I will use novel multidisciplinary methods to produce estimates of the independent effects of in utero exposure to HIV infection, HIV-related immune perturbations and post-natal environment in HIV-exposed uninfected infants at birth. This project will provide me with training in incorporating multidisciplinary methods in infectious disease research while informing the design and implementation of effective interventions to improve health and development among HIV-exposed uninfected children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health, because African Americans/Blacks suffer with higher obesity rates and have more trouble losing weight loss than others. Trained Community Health Workers will deliver the Diabetes Prevention Program (DPP); early during the program, the researchers will identify participants who are not losing weight and the Community Health Workers will offer these participants extra support to help them overcome weight loss barriers. If this extra support works, the National DPP and others can adopt it to achieve better weight loss outcomes among DPP participants, thereby having a significant public health impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT: Sepsis is a common and deadly syndrome for which there is no specific treatment other than antibiotics and advanced support. In this project, we will characterize a novel population of neutrophils, assess how the inflammatory mediator eCIRP induces them, investigate how these cells worsen sepsis and the post-sepsis dysfunction, and evaluate the benefit of a new eCIRP inhibitor, A12, on acute sepsis, sepsis survival, and post-sepsis dysfunction. This project will establish the importance of these newly discovered cells for sepsis severity, mortality and late sequelae, and explore a new way to treat septic patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROGRAM NARRATIVE Protein-protein and protein-DNA interaction (PPI and PDI) networks control virtually all cellular processes, and they are commonly perturbed by devastating human diseases. To overcome key challenges in interaction network analysis, we will develop novel, transformative bioanalytical methods to quantify cellular PPI and PDI networks and their dynamic perturbation in disease, thereby enabling groundbreaking, broadly relevant discoveries of disease mechanisms and drug targets. We will apply our methods to unravel the interaction networks that control cellular plasticity, a biological process driving diverse pathological processes, including cancer metastasis, organ fibrosis, viral infection, drug resistance, and immune escape.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Depression is one of the most debilitating psychiatric illnesses to emerge during adolescence, a period of critical brain development and transition towards adulthood. Cognitive and motivational deficits are prominent symptoms and the associated neural systems undergo adolescent-specific development, making understanding cognitive and motivational neurobehavioral interactions in adolescent depression crucial to designing future treatments and prevention strategies. This study proposes complementary approaches to examine cognitive-motivational neurobehavioral interactions, using: an incentivized spatial working memory neuroimaging paradigm in adolescents with depression, with longitudinal re-examination, and data-driven approaches applied to a large-scale dataset in typical children aimed at characterizing cognitive-motivational phenotypes as a platform for future studies to examine depression risk in adolescence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  We identified that the bone marrow of the skull bone (calvarium) unlike other bone marrow compartments is protected from the adverse impact of diabetes and supplies vascular reparative cells to the retinal until the late-stage diabetes occurs. We postulate that this protection is due to the direct connection between the calvarium and the cerebral spinal fluid (CSF) as the CSF provides the calvarium with brain- derived protective hematopoietic factors. We will identify these protective factors in the CSF and also deliver a drug to the calvarium of late stage diabetic mice to determine if we can restore levels of bone marrow-derived vascular reparative cells back to normal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Infections with Mycobacterium tuberculosis remain a worldwide public health concern causing over 1.5 million deaths annually. We found that the glycerol synthase kinase 3a and 3b (GSK3a/b) are required for host responses by controlling the activation of macrophages by the essential cytokine Interferon-gamma (IFNγ). Here, we will understand the mechanisms of GSK3a/b control of IFNγ signaling and dissect the contribution of GSK3a/b to IFNγ-mediated control of M. tuberculosis growth, inflammation and T cell responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Telomeres are specialized structures located at the ends of chromosomes that fulfill an essential role in maintaining genetic integrity and cancer prevention. However, cancer causing mutations can bypass this arrest in cell division and re-initiate cellular division. These cells must also re-activate a mechanism that ensures that telomeres once again maintain the structural integrity of chromosomes but are no longer capable of blocking cell division. This is achieved by activating one of two different telomere maintenance mechanisms. One of these mechanisms is known as alternative lengthening of telomeres, or simply ALT. Cancers that rely on ALT tend to be among the most aggressive and patients often have a poor prognosis. Therefore, understanding the molecular basis for the activation and maintenance of the ALT pathway and identifying the key regulators of ALT is critically important for improving the detection and treatment of this devastating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance: More than 40% of HIV-1 infected people on anti-retroviral drug (ARD) therapies have early-onset diastolic heart failure (dHF), a harbinger for adverse clinical outcomes including frequent hospitalizations and sudden death. To date, the molecular reasons for the development of dHF remain poorly understood. This multi-PI project brings together the expertise of Drs. Keshore R. Bidasee (cardiovascular diseases including heart failure) and Santhi Gorantla (humanized mice and HIV-1 infection) with assistance from Dr. Prasanta Dash (HIV-1 eradication and cardiovascular complications), to characterize novel link between glycolysis and heart failure in the setting of HIV infection and ARD, paving the way for the development of urgently needed drugs to attenuate dHF in people living with HIV infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project explores a new hypothesis related to progressive lung inflammation in patients with cystic fibrosis (CF). We will focus on the role of extracellular vesicles as drivers of chronic lung neutrophil reprogramming and investigate newly discovered upstream causative processes and downstream effector pathways. This study will inform therapies for CF and other human diseases associated with intractable neutrophilic lung inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Surgical site infections (SSIs) alone account for 20% of all healthcare-associated infections (HAIs) and approximately 160,000-300,000 SSIs occur each year in the United States. These infections account for about 8200 death and nearly $3.5-10 billion annually in additional healthcare costs. The application outlines a strategy to develop therapeutic anti-infective wound dressings that improve the host immune response to attack the pathogen on numerous fronts rather than a single front like traditional antibiotics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Many female and gender diverse autistic people are late-, mis- or never diagnosed, putting them at greater risk for depression, anxiety and self-harm. We will tackle this problem and develop a tool to speed up diagnosis. This will help autistic people to get the right help at the right time, and improve quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The development of ligands that modify epigenetic marks has become an active area of investigation within academia and industry across diverse therapy areas. However, the great promise of this effort has yet to be fully realized due to the complexity of the epigenetic chromatin landscape. In this proposal we describe proximity proteomics methods for mechanism of action elucidation within epigenetic drug discovery, providing a new vector for small molecule screening and analysis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Inflammation is important for innate immune responses to infection but also can cause blood disorders including bone marrow failure, aplastic anemia, myelodysplastic syndrome, and clonal hematopoiesis. The goal of this project is to delineate the mechanisms by which inflammatory cytokine signaling drives hematopoietic stem cell differentiation, depletion, clonal competition, and immunologic reprogramming with the long-term goal of revealing therapeutic targets to support healthy blood production throughout life.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) are a risk factor for childhood obesity, though the ACEs-obesity relationship is not well understood. The impact of neighborhood environment is particularly understudied, despite its influence on both ACEs and obesity risk. This study will examine the relationship between neighborhood environment, ACEs, and childhood obesity in order to inform targeted approaches to reducing obesity for the millions of children who experience ACEs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The development of a systematic census of cell types in mammalian species is a critical priority for the BRAIN Initiative Cell Atlas Network Program (BICAN) towards understanding human brain function in health and disease. BICAN scientists will need to collaboratively share, curate, and annotate brain cell types taxonomies produced from their data, and public researchers will be eager to understand BICAN findings, map their data against BICAN taxonomies, and contribute their own findings to the bolas of community knowledge. This proposal is to develop an extensible Brain Cell Knowledge Base (BCKB) to support BICAN’s development of a multimodal, multi-species brain cell atlas and utilization of that atlas as an open community resource for advancing knowledge of the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This project aims to make a broad impact upon the neuroimaging community by extending, solidifying and disseminating a set of universal JSON-based neuroimaging data exchange format specifications, and readily enable the ability in both local and cloud-based data analysis pipelines to handle large, complex neuroimaging datasets via widely used NoSQL database technology. The success of this project is expected to greatly improve our ability to integrate, manipulate, reuse and disseminate existing public and NIH-funded neuroimaging datasets, accommodate fast-growing neuroimaging data in both size and complexity, and modernize widely used neuroimaging data analysis pipelines to be ready for automation, large-scale data processing, easy data exchange, and backward-compatible future extensions.

PHR: Project Narrative Following traumatic brain injury (TBI), patients often develop persistent disabilities, and specific problems with memory underlie much of the long-term adverse outcomes associated with serious brain injury. We have recently demonstrated that the some of the spontaneous recovery that occurs after TBI is due to generation of new neurons within the hippocampus, the part of the brain that mediates memory formation. We have also demonstrated that ApoE, a gene long associated with outcome following TBI, directs hippocampal development and the purpose of this project is to determine how ApoE regulates injury-induced neurogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The Hippo pathway plays a major role in cell growth, tissue homeostasis, and organ size, and is frequently altered in human cancer. The main goal of this proposal is to elucidate the molecular mechanisms of Hippo pathway regulation, particularly the role of phosphoinositides. Completion of this project will not only address fundamental questions in Hippo regulation, but also provide valuable leads for therapeutic intervention of the Hippo pathway for cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most colorectal cancer patients have microsatellite stable phenotype (immune cold) tumors with poor T cell infiltration. This pilot study will establish that tumor-enriched metabolites influence immunosuppressive macrophage abundance in colorectal cancer. The results from this study will provide insights into metabolites that can be targeted to improve anti-tumor immune responses in colorectal cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Social learning is the foundation for speech, music and athletics but full mastery of these complex behaviors requires the fluent coordination of learned and innate motor programs. The goal of this proposal is to test the hypothesis that a neural circuit comprising a midbrain dopamine cell group and its cortical and subcortical projections is crucial to social learning and the coordination of learned and innate motor programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Candida glabrata is a major fungal pathogen causing opportunistic, life-threatening infections in individuals with reduced immunity, such as transplant patients, those with HIV, premature infants, and, recently, COVID-19 patients. Among fungi causing invasive fungal infections, C. glabrata accounts for the greatest total incidence of drug resistance, with the highest resistance to echinocandins, a first-line antifungal drug class. In this proposal we will elucidate the determinants of C. glabrata echinocandin tolerance and resistance specifically in the physiologically relevant host niches, such as macrophages and the gastrointestinal tract.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: This project will investigate the role of noise in the vestibular system, and in particular its effects on the variability (precision) of vestibular-mediated behaviors. We will study vestibular precision in normal subjects and patients with peripheral vestibular damage, and will investigate its potential plasticity. The goals are to develop a better understanding of the role played by noise in the vestibular system in normal and pathologic populations, and to determine if the brain can learn to improve signal recognition within its inherently noisy neural environment, which would result in improved behavioral precision.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this research project is to test the hypothesis that that the experiences of listeners in their daily lives can be more strongly related to performance in a controlled test environment by using enhanced environments involving both virtual reality elements and game-based modifications to the testing procedures. A secondary, and potentially alternative, hypothesis is that the benefit of these enhancements will vary based on individual differences. Upon completion of this project there will exist, freely available, an extensive set of engaging, enhanced auditory assessments with established regions of normal performance as a function of age and hearing loss, and known relationships to various established tests of speech in noise that run on inexpensive consumer-grade equipment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE During development, individual neurons extend highly branched neurites that innervate the surrounding territory with minimal overlap to form appropriate synaptic connections and failure to establish proper neural networks has been linked to neurodevelopmental and neuropsychiatric disorders, including Autism Spectrum Disorder, Schizophrenia and Major Depressive Disorder. Our proposal will investigate the molecular mechanisms by which de novo single nucleotide variants in the protocadherin gene cluster identified in ASD cases contribute to the etiology of ASD by altering neural circuit formation during development. This work aims to provide new insights into disease mechanisms, motivating the development of new therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Hepatitis delta virus causes serious acute and chronic liver disease but lacks effective treatment. To develop therapies and tackle the disease, it is necessary to better understand the virus’ unique replication strategy, which relies on the synthesis of three viral RNAs. This project will apply newly developed methods from my laboratory to advance our basic understanding of key processes in the synthesis of these viral RNAs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chagas disease (CD) is a global health concern, with no existing therapies to prophylactically treat adults traveling to endemic countries or those who may already be infected with Trypanosoma cruzi (Tc). This proposal aims to develop a vaccine-adjuvant combination comprising a DNA vector-based bicistronic vaccine (BCV) and a systemic small-molecule integrin activator adjuvant for the control of Tc infection and CD, and demonstrate preclinical proof-of-concept, efficacy and safety of this vaccine-adjuvant combination in preparation for a Phase I/IIa clinical trial.
