IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The T cell immune attack on pancreatic islet beta cells that causes Type I diabetes (T1D) might be due to abnormal development of T cells in the thymus, the organ that generates and educates T cells. We have used a unique human immune system mouse model in which human T cells develop in a human thymus to identify abnormalities in thymic T cell development and education when they are derived from T1D patient hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs). The goal of our proposed studies is to better understand the genetic and signaling abnormalities in T1D HSCs that result in the thymic selection and migration into the immune system of T cells with the capacity to destroy that patient’s own pancreatic beta cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative When developing new cancer treatments, many scientists use animal models in which human tumors are implanted into research animals (i.e. patient-derived xenografts or PDXs). Despite the popularity of these models, we lack understanding of how we bias our results based on the methods we use to make new PDXs (e.g. implanting tumor pieces under the skin of immunocompromised mice as opposed to implanting into the site of origin). To improve the efficiency of pre-clinical research, this proposal will provide a clear answer to this question in head and neck cancer by methodically studying the site of implant, the age of the tumor, and the influence of an immune system on the tumor biology, evolution, and treatment response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative The long-term goal of this project is to develop, characterize and validate genetically modified marmosets that exhibit brain pathology and/or clinical/behavioral signs compatible with sporadic Alzheimer's Disease (AD). These marmoset models are aimed at informing human AD across the full life span or throughout the disease- relevant stages and serve as tools to interrogate molecular disease mechanisms and identify therapeutic targets. Specifically, as APOE4 allele is the most important risk factor for sporadic AD, marmosets carrying a complete loss of APOE or a point mutation mimicking APOE4 will be generated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Mutations in the lamin A/C gene cause a severe type of heart dysfunction called dilated cardiomyopathy. The goal of this project is to investigate a novel mechanism that may normally protect heart muscle cells from mechanical forces but lead to damage when persistently activated in patients with lamin A/C gene mutations. This fundamental research could uncover new ways to treat this life-threatening inherited heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Young, middle-aged and older adults work together, recreate together, and share many of life’s emotional highs and lows with one another. Yet sometimes, while the positive and negative experiences may be shared across the generations, the memory traces later accessed may differ. Here, we test the hypothesis that an individual’s age relates to the types of features of past emotional events that are brought to mind initially, and over successive retrievals, and we elucidate the characteristics of the memory representations that underlie these behavioral differences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative  This project aims to decipher potential role of a class of histone methyltransferases, COMPASS H3K4 methyltransferases, in environmental-circadian alignment. If successful, the results will unveil the molecular mechanism of a fundamental biological process, i.e. how organisms synchronize daily internal circadian rhythms with external environmental cycles. It will also lay the foundation for therapeutic avenues for conditions associated with shiftwork, a type of environmental circadian disruption, such as obesity and cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this project, multifunctional biodegradable nanowires are being designed, manufactured and tested for their ability to interact with lung and nasal epithelial cells. Complexes that target an apically expressed cell adhesion molecule, β1 integrin, are being screened to identify nanowires that physiologically regulate airway epithelial function. One goal of this study is to evaluate β1 integrin as a target for the ability to improve the barrier function of the lung epithelium and as a novel therapeutic for chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyposis, a chronic disease with critically few treatment options.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Messenger RNAs (mRNAs) encode specific regulatory instructions in their untranslated regions (UTRs) that govern when, where, and how much protein should be made from each mRNA. Our studies will investigate how mRNA UTR sequences fold into specific structures, and how these structures impact mRNA regulation. Our results will provide insights into how mutations in UTRs contribute to disease, help improve our ability to design molecular therapies that target UTRs to control gene expression, and facilitate efforts to design synthetic mRNAs as medicines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Ribosome RNA (rRNA) modifying enzymes are important factors in the assembly and function of ribosomes, dysregulation of which is frequently seen in human hematopoietic disorders. However, whether and how the catalytic roles of rRNA modifying enzymes contribute to the physiology and pathology of human hematopoiesis remain elusive. Our research goal is to understand the catalytic roles of rRNA modifying enzymes in the regulation of cell viability and gene expression in hematopoietic stem progenitor cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Critically ill patients admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) are at the risk of developing sepsis leading to death, each hour of delayed recognition or treatment can contribute to significantly increasing the likelihood of death. If this application is funded, we will explore sensor-generated continuous physiological data streams to extract ‘physiomarkers’ that predict the onset of sepsis, aid in informing intervention futility (volume responsiveness) and support the discovery of novel sepsis sub-types. By discovering and modeling the mechanisms by which such physiomarkers predict sepsis, we can proactively recognize specific high-risk patients, appropriate resources at the right time to avoid significant morbidity and mortality, and begin treatments that improve outcomes in this critically ill and vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mucin proteins comprise mucus, which coats the surface of all epithelial cells for hydration and pathogen defense. Diverse viruses have evolved to attach directly to mucins, but due to varied mucin forms, molecular details of binding preferences and their outcomes on viral evolution, diffusion, tissue specificity, and replication are lacking. We will develop synthetic mucins of precisely defined structure to unravel how viruses interact with host cell surfaces, which will improve our understanding of viral diseases and open doors to new therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: To encourage early stage investigators from a broad range of backgrounds to join the dementia research workforce, the Alzheimer's Association proposes to employ its substantial organizational and research resources to develop and implement an annual, week-long, dual track (psychosocial and public health) Alzheimer's Association Interdisciplinary Summer Research Institute (AA-ISRI) on Alzheimer's Disease and Related Dementias. At the end of each annual institute, attendees will be able to apply psychosocial and/or community-level, public health theory and measurement of systems to research design questions, resulting in an increase in new interventions focused on improving quality of life and system-level research in communities nationwide. Outcomes for the institute will include improved quality of life and ability to handle stress for individuals living with dementia and their care partners and increasing system-level change in community level organizations, such as health systems, employers, and financial institutions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose a Molecular Biophysics Training Program (MBTP) that leverages the research and training experience of 27 faculty Trainers in three colleges and eight departments to create a unique training experience at the crossroads of the quantitative, molecular, and biomedical sciences. Students from three different graduate programs and many different backgrounds will have the opportunity to interact with and learn from each other and from the many experienced Trainers. This training will prepare graduates to address the biomedical challenges of the twenty--first century with truly collaborative and comprehensive approaches that address pressing needs in career development and inclusion of diverse groups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Direct electrical stimulation of the brain holds promise for patients with refractory neuropsychiatric conditions and in particular treatment-resistant depression but has been limited to delivering a fixed stimulation pattern and shown variable efficacy in clinical trials. We propose that one way to improve efficacy is to build a novel model- based system that adjusts the stimulation based on recording brain signals that are related to mood symptoms and modeling how ongoing stimulation changes these signals. We will develop this novel model-based system to enable personalized real-time stimulation and test it for acute control of neural biomarkers of mood states related to depression symptoms in human epilepsy patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Loss of heterozygosity contributes to cancer initiation and progression through the loss of the functional copy of a tumor suppressor gene in heterozygous individuals, leaving only the mutant copy. We have established and validated a system to study this phenomenon in stable diploid cells using a flow cytometry. Defining the factors that prevent or contribute to long-range loss of heterozygosity after double strand break formation will contribute to understanding of how these initiating events in cancer occur.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Every time a cell divides, it must duplicate the DNA that contains the blueprint of the cell. If the DNA replication process stalls at sites of damaged DNA, the cell must engage the protein coded by the BRCA1 breast and ovarian cancer gene, and its associated proteins, to prevent DNA damage, mutation and cancer. In work described here, we will use powerful new tools, developed by the Scully lab, to study how BRCA1 performs this work and to use these insights in an effort to discover new targets for cancer therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative  The U.S. is home to the largest population of Haitian immigrants in the world, yet little is known about Haitian immigrants living with HIV (HILWH) and their recent experiences throughout the HIV cascade of care. The purpose of this study is to develop, using mixed methods, multi-level formative data on perceived barriers and facilitators to engagement, retention, and viral suppression among HILWH. We will also adapt, pilot-test, and evaluate a multi-component intervention that addresses specific unmet needs leading to persistent HIV outcome disparities, including viral suppression, in Miami, Florida an epicenter of the epidemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mobile obesity interventions have the potential to reach a diverse population in need; however, while effective, have not resulted in weight losses obtained in in-person interventions. Newer digital approaches called Just-in- Time Adaptive Interventions (JITAI) that offer adaptive, personalized feedback `when needed' and in `real time' offer an opportunity to use digital health tools “just in time”. This study seeks to identify the optimal components of a comprehensive weight loss JITAI that results in weight losses that meet or exceed those in existing remotely delivered interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Functional status—a summary of a patient’s physical, emotional, and social wellbeing—is a key index that guides the treatment of older patients with chronic pain conditions. Clinical integration of smartphones promises to bridge the “digital divide” by offering new ways to measure functional status and expand access to real-time care in vulnerable populations who lack access to in-person clinical evaluations. Because 80% of Americans in their fifties and sixties own and use smartphones, we will define and implement a smartphone-based profile of functional status and pilot how such a digital biomarker profile might offer real-time clinical decision support in real-world patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Leptospirosis is a globally important neglected spirochetal disease conservatively estimated to cause more than 1 million cases annually with a 5-20% case-fatality rate, significant morbidity, and with public and military health and economic consequences. There is currently no safe and effective leptospirosis vaccine for humans, yet there are both global and US domestic needs for one. This Phase I STTR application proposes experiments to advance VM protein-based leptospirosis vaccines into clinical development for humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Vector-borne illnesses continue to be a source of worldwide morbidity and mortality, with ticks being the most important disease vector in the United States. In this proposal we will interrogate mechanisms that allow arthropods to harbor and transmit disease by building on our previous data and investigating the crosstalk between arthropod immunity and cellular stress responses, which functionally impact pathogen burden in ticks. Since microbial infections impart stress on host systems and cellular stress responses are well conserved across eukaryotes, we expect that our findings will uncover novel determinants of vector competence that are relevant to broad number of arthropod-pathogen systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Antiretroviral drugs can inhibit HIV infection, but cannot eliminate all the infected cells in the body that hide from the immune system. In order to cure HIV, we need to develop methods that accurately quantify the number of infected cells that remain hidden and explore new treatments that effectively target these HIV- infected cells. This project has scientific and public health relevance by deepening our understanding of how HIV remains hidden and ultimately uses this knowledge to develop curative strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Defense against RNA viruses depends on tightly controlled innate immune signaling initiated by RIG-I-like receptors and transduced through the adaptor protein MAVS. This project will investigate how RNA molecules and RNA-binding proteins organize the signaling platform that forms around MAVS to promote antiviral signaling. The proposed work will uncover new RNA-centric principles by which immune signaling pathways are regulated and has the potential to reveal new therapeutic strategies against viral diseases as well as autoimmune disorders.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One-size-fits-all approaches have failed to demonstrate sustained effects on childhood obesity, especially among low-income minority families, who experience constantly changing barriers to engaging in health behavior. Addressing obesity in these populations requires intervening in early childhood and situating interventions in the context of families and communities. Developing personalized childhood obesity prevention interventions with sustained effectiveness that support families in health behaviors despite dynamic barriers could address chronic disease risk and health disparities in low-income and minority communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Treatment response rates for social anxiety disorder are markedly lower than for other anxiety disorders, thus presenting an urgent need to identify novel therapeutic targets that can inform new interventions for this chronic, impairing, and difficult-to-treat disorder. In direct support of the NIMH Strategic Goal 3: Strive for Prevention and Cures, we propose to address this need by testing a developmentally-informed, mechanistic model of the escalation of impairing social anxiety symptoms in early-to-mid adolescence. Leveraging the expertise of our team in developmental psychopathology and experimental therapeutics, findings from this project will position us to pursue novel, developmentally-informed, brain-based therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Inﬂammation causes the release of oxidative agents, which activate blood coagulation proteins leading to a pro- thrombotic state. The work proposed here investigates the structural basis of how oxidation activates von Wille- brand factor, a key protein in the initial stages of blood coagulation. The results will help the structure-based design of therapeutics that are able to prevent thrombosis while minimizing the risk of unwanted bleeding.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative Activation of the Wnt pathway appears to be part of a regulatory mechanism orchestrated by cells of the central nervous system to resolve inflammation and favor repair. The proposed project aims to demonstrate that inflammatory signals at the neurovascular level induce Wnt production by endothelial cells and astrocytes, which will regulate myeloid cell function and promote anti-inflammatory responses that support repair and limit neuropathology. This project will ultimately help in the design of new targets to stop the inflammation and stimulate remyelination in multiple sclerosis by understanding how to regulate myeloid APCs response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Remodeling of blood vessels is a critical component of diverse vascular diseases. Recently, we  identified a pool of specialized progenitors in the walls of vessels in the lung that play a  critical role in this pathological remodeling, and initial studies suggest similar processes in  atherosclerosis. The proposed investigations characterize these progenitor pools, delineate the  mechanisms underlying their regulation in the context of vascular disease and thereby, facilitate  the development of novel therapeutic strategies.

PHR: The germinal center reaction generates high quality humoral memory to protect us from infection but can also be involved in diseases such as autoimmunity and allergy. PHR: RELEVANCE (See instructions): Ensuring that machine learning tools are demographically fair, even in settings where no direct evaluation can be performed, will further promote the monitoring of machine learning models for fairness in real-world practice of relevance for public health policy generally, and for large scale cancer screening programs in particular. The project includes a series of broader impact activities focused in promoting under-represented groups in science and engineering and dissemination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Epithelial cells in barrier tissues sustain frequent damage from a variety of external insults. The role of macrophages in regulating inflammatory responses and promoting epithelial repair following damage is poorly understood. The proposed work will elucidate novel mechanisms underlying macrophage-mediated regulation of inflammation and tissue repair.
